PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
support the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987 Bill to alter the constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation wide, independent radio and television service.
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers, about the proposal to Irradiate Food in Australia. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should
(1) block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia.
(2) ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium-137 and caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
(3) ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X ray etc.)
(4) ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent the Australian people from being seriously affected by yet another ludicrous charge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom.
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support.
(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 60 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, requesting that the Senate urge the Government to reform tax for pensioners:

SPEECH.PARA: SUSSEX INLET COMBINED PENSIONERS AND
SENIOR CITIZENS ASSOCIATION
P.O. Box 52, Sussex Inlet, N.S.W. 2540
Hon. Kerry Sibraa
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator
I am writing to you concerning the steadily deteriorating position of pensioners.

The decline in the value of pensions is well known, yet little is known about the influence of taxation on their living standards. Contrary to popular belief, pensioners pay tax. Not only do they pay sales and excise taxes like other members of the community, but those who earn more than $3.72 per week above the standard pension are liable for income tax. In the next financial year, unless reforms are made to the income tax system, pensioners will pay income tax on the pension itself.
More tax reform?

The Income Tax reforms undertaken by the Government in 1986-87 brought little relief to pensioners and low income earners. The recently announced review of the Corporate Tax system and of tax concessions in the cause of superannuation provide an opportunity to direct some benefits to people in greater need.

It is recognised that there may be some justice in rationalising the Corporate Tax system to make it comparable to our overseas competitors, however, there is a stronger case in our view to direct some attention to the needs of pensioners.

The Combined Pensioners Association has proposed an increase in the value of the Pensioner Tax Rebate from $250 p.a. to $700 p.a. This would enable pensioners to earn up to $40 per week above the pension, as allowed under the Social Security means test, without any losses through the income tax system.
The Pensioner Rebate has not been increased since it was introduced in 1982 and, through the effect of inflation, its value has declined by 46%.

The other matter of considerable concern is provisional tax. The policy of encouraging pensioners to invest their savings to supplement their meagre pensions is being negated through the threat of provisional tax.
These two key issues, the threat posed to living standards through the income tax system and provisional tax require urgent attention.
As a Senator representing the people of N.S.W. I urge you to support the calls of pensioners for tax reform. Pensioners deserve better treatment than they are getting at the moment.
Yours sincerely,
(Mrs) G. Driscoll
Hon. Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —These Orders vested in the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy a very wide and unreviewable discretionary power to remit certain fees. The former Minister for Resources, the Hon. Peter Morris, MP, has promised the Committee that to protect personal rights the exercise of this discretion will be brought within the jurisdiction of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Committee commends the Minister for his decision. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief description of the Committee's scrutiny and the Committee's brief correspondence in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Meat Inspection (Fees) Orders (No. 5 of 1987)

These Orders stated that the Secretary of the Department ``may, in a particular case, for a reason that the Secretary thinks sufficient, remit the whole or part of an amount of a fee payable under these Orders''. On its face this provision conferred a wide and prima facie, personal discretionary power on an official without any legislative criteria to assist with its fair and unbiased exercise. No avenue of merits review was prescribed that could underwrite the quality and consistency of discretionary decision making and remedy possibly unjust decisions. The Minister for Resources, the Hon. Peter Morris, M.P. explained that the purpose behind the fees remission power was to allow for fairness where fees and fee increases had not been properly notified. Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 19 November 1987 the Committee considered the Meat Inspection (Fees) Orders as amended (Amendment) (being Meat Inspection Orders No. 5 of 1987, tabled in the Senate on 2 November 1987). The Committee noted that new Order 18 vests in the Secretary a very wide discretion to remit fees. The provision states that:
The Secretary may, in a particular case, for a reason that the Secretary thinks sufficient, remit the whole or a part of an amount of a fee payable under these orders.

Given the width of this discretion, its subjective drafting, the absence of criteria and the apparent lack of any right to seek review, the Committee requests some further information on the purpose of the provision. It may be that the exercise of a discretion of this kind and width should be reviewable by the AAT.
The Committee would appreciate your comments and advice on the new order in the light of these points.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
MINISTER FOR RESOURCES
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Collins

I refer to your letter on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, dated 27 November 1987, seeking comments on new order 18 of the Meat Inspection (Fees) Orders, which was inserted by Meat Inspection Orders No. 5 of 1987.

New order 18 was made to enable remission of fees that are payable under the Orders where a misunderstanding has arisen as to when the fees are payable and where it would be inequitable to require persons to pay those fees, for example, where there has been inadequate notification of an increase in fees, or where there is confusion about the date from which the Orders apply. Due to the circumstances that may arise it is difficult to specify criteria which would meet all circumstances.

The order was introduced at this time to address a misunderstanding by operators and Northern Territory officials in relation to the date of the extension of the Meat Inspection Act 1983 to the Northern Territory and the date from which fees were payable. The lack of the right of review was an unintentional drafting omission.

I appreciate the Committee's comments and have instructed officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to prepare an amendment to the order which will include a right to review similar to that provided in other orders.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask him whether he unequivocally agrees with the comment made in the chamber on 17 February by Senator Burns in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . timber-getters and loggers in the past 100 years have not given a damn about our environment or about the trees and conservation of any part of this country. All they were concerned about was cutting down logs and making a quid. They were not concerned about future generations or if there would be anything left.

Secondly, does he unequivocally agree with the Premier of New South Wales that Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd has been raping and pillaging forests in New South Wales? If he does, will he now indicate that he will not grant a woodchip export licence to prevent this rape and pillage, or will he grant the woodchip licence and repudiate Mr Unsworth's statement? Thirdly, will he now protest in the strongest possible terms against the actions of the Unsworth Government and Minister Carr in permitting the devastatingly destructive clear-felling of pines in Kosciusko National Park? Will he be acting to halt this environmental vandalism or is the destruction of the environment quite acceptable to Senator Richardson if it is done by one of his Labor factional mates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I was asked whether I unequivocally agree with the statement of Senator Burns made in the chamber on 17 February. I did not hear the statement of Senator Burns on 17 February. It cannot be said that I have always agreed unequivocally with everything Senator Burns has said. Nonetheless I have agreed with much of what he has said. It is true that some timber-getters and loggers have acted without giving a damn. There is no question about that. Some have not.
—Say yes or no.
—I am trying to say that some have and some have not. It is that simple.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Boswell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Those with whom Senator Boswell is associated never give a damn about the environment, but there are others. The next question asked was whether I agreed with the statement of Barrie Unsworth that Harris-Daishowa had been raping and pillaging and, on that basis, would I or would I not grant it an export licence. Firstly, we need to assess what resource is available to Harris-Daishowa. That is what Harris-Daishowa itself is doing at the moment. Now that the Unsworth Government has announced its courageous decision to protect 80,000 hectares of southern forests in national parks obviously there may be some question about how much resource Harris-Daishowa has. When I have received a full report from Harris-Daishowa I will consider whatever role I have in the granting or otherwise of an export licence.

ANSWER.PARA: I was then asked whether I was going to protest against the Unsworth Government for cutting down pine forests-that is what we are talking about, pine forests-in the Kosciusko National Park. A number of issues are involved with logging in Australia generally. Over many years the environment movement has expressed, firstly, concern about the rape of our rain forests, secondly, concern about the rape of our natural forests and, thirdly, regret that we have planted pine at all. As far as I am concerned, pine plantations will be important to the future of the Australian timber industry. I see no doubt about that. I cannot, however, put pine plantations in the same category as our great natural eucalypt forests and, therefore, do not. I have no objection to the Unsworth Government's action in the Kosciusko National Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked Senator Richardson whether it is a fact that Australian Labor Party stated policy is not to permit logging in national parks and whether the `courageous decision to protect the environment by declaring national parks' in Labor Party terms simply means drawing boundaries around areas and then allowing one's Labor mates to log within them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The boundaries of the Kosciusko National Park were drawn many years ago. The pine plantations were planted many years ago. I would rail against any attempt to log natural eucalypt forests in national parks. I have always opposed that and will continue to do so. I have already answered the rest of Senator Puplick's question adequately.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to recent accidents involving Metroliner aircraft overseas. Has the Government been monitoring inquiries by aviation authorities into recent crashes of Fairchild Metroliner aircraft? If so, is the Government satisfied with the overall safety of the Metroliner, a type of aircraft which is used very widely on feeder air routes in South Australia and Victoria, in particular, to cities including Port Lincoln, Whyalla, Mount Gambier and Portland?

—The Government has been monitoring the crashes of Metroliners that have occurred overseas. We have been in close contact with the United States Federal Aviation Administration and the manufacturers of the Metroliner aircraft with a view to determining the cause of the accidents which have occurred recently. Preliminary information indicates that there is no cause for concern, however, about the integrity of the aircraft themselves. My Department is quite satisfied with the safety of the Metroliners operating in Australia. However, this matter will clearly be kept under close review to ensure that this situation remains.

—I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women to Labor's loss of the seat of Adelaide, to Senator Maguire's survey which shows swings against the Australian Labor Party of up to 26 per cent in that seat since 1984, and to the looming defeat of the Unsworth Government as clear evidence of the fact that Labor has lost touch with the community. Does the Minister accept that the issue of timed local calls in the Adelaide by-election had a particularly strong impact on women, many of whom are alone at home during the day or with small children, including sole parents who use the telephone extensively for help, advice and adult conversation? Is the Minister satisfied that when proposals come before the Government sufficient attention is paid to their impact on people and particularly women? If not, will the Minister recommend that each submission be accompanied by a community impact statement which assesses the effect of proposals on the community as a whole and especially on women?

—I welcome Senator Vanstone's question as an opportunity to remind Senator Vanstone and other members of the Opposition that of course the Office of the Status of Women is in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet precisely for the purpose that Senator Vanstone spelt out. The Women's Budget Statement is a document which quite clearly indicates the Government's commitment to--
—It is not read by the electors of Adelaide.
—Do you want an answer?
—Yes.
—Order!

—As I was saying, Mr President, the Hawke Government, in five years, has done more to raise the status of women than the Opposition could even contemplate. The mere fact that the Government has a Budget Paper that details the impact of the policies of every single portfolio on the women of Australia is ample indication of the Government's commitment to women. In terms of the specific question that Senator Vanstone asked, I am liaising with all of my colleagues in regard to the impact of policies on women. I will of course be liaising on the issue she raised but the Prime Minister has ruled out the introduction of timed local telephone calls, so the issue is as outdated as Senator Vanstone's policies for the women of Australia. I draw Senator Vanstone's attention to a recent opinion poll that showed that the Prime Minister of Australia, Bob Hawke, had a particularly high approval rating amongst Australian women. I do not have details of it with me but I am certainly very pleased to draw this opinion poll to Senator Vanstone's attention. Furthermore, if Senator Vanstone wishes to talk about the forthcoming New South Wales election, I would be very happy to talk about that issue in relation to the New South Wales Government's commitment to women's policies.
—I want to know whether you will consider the impact of the proposal on the community? That is my question.
—The honourable senator asked me for my response about Government policies in relation to women, and I would like to know--
—I want to know whether you have an impact statement.
—Order!

—Well, Mr President, perhaps Senator Vanstone would like to debate in this chamber precisely what Nick Greiner's policies are in relation to women. I have not heard one single word about what his policies are in relation to women. I do know that many women in New South Wales are totally opposed to Nick Greiner's stance on gun control measures, and I think we would have a very interesting debate in this chamber comparing the policies of Nick Greiner, if indeed he has any, because the Opposition is very silent on the question of its policies for women, with the performance of the Unsworth Government in relation to its excellent policies concerning women.

—I thank the Minister for her attempt at an answer but she did not answer the question. I did not ask about Nick Greiner; I did not ask about guns; I did not ask about the Prime Minister's popularity; nor did I ask about Mr Unsworth. The final part of my question, which should have given the Minister a hint about what I was asking, was: Does the Government appreciate that it is out of touch and will the Minister do something about this by ensuring that all submissions to government have attached to them community impact proposals, which would allow the Minister to assess the impact on the community and particularly on women? I just use the example of Adelaide to show that the Government is plainly out of touch at the moment. I want to know what the Minister is going to do about this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —If anyone is out of touch in this chamber, it is Senator Vanstone. Apparently she still does not understand.

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am being quite serious. Senator Vanstone still does not appreciate that all Government policies since 1983 have in fact gone through that precise process that she has now suddenly discovered in 1988. That is detailed in the Women's Budget Statement.
—Telephone time charging was a deliberate decision and you calculated the impact.

—I have never heard Senator Puplick make a speech about his concern for the status of women; so I think it would be appropriate if he were to listen for a change. It is very important to recognise that it was this Government that set up the Office of the Status of Women within the Prime Minister's Department, precisely for the reason that the honourable senator asked about today. I cannot help it, Senator Vanstone; it is the old teacher coming out. I may be able to teach a few of those opposite a thing or two about the status of women.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vanstone asked me whether the Government will consider its impact on women. Yes, we have already done this across every avenue of government policy. I suggest that she sit down and spend a little time reading the Women's Budget Statement. She will then see that this happens across all portfolios.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen a recent newspaper article in which the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mrs Grusovin, alleges that the cost to banks of deposits for less than $50,000 has fallen from 14.25 per cent to 10.25 per cent for a minimum of 90 days, and from 14.24 per cent to 9.75 per cent for a 30-day minimum? She called for banks to justify their failure to reduce credit card interest rates of up to 23 per cent in light of the fall in the cost of deposit funds to banks, saying that banks were `out of step' with the prevailing market. Does the Treasurer agree that this points to an oligopoly having control of credit card rates in a manner which is inconsistent with the competition the Government wants to promote in the financial market?

—I have seen what was not really an article but a news report; I am not sure when it was published, but it was recently, anyway. I am certainly not surprised, although I have not verified the figures, by the declines in interest rate paid on deposits to which Mrs Grusovin referred of between 4 per cent and 4 1/2 per cent. That is, of course, in line with the general fall in interest rates which has taken place in recent months.
—No, it is not, Minister.

—On short term loans, which is what these are, Senator Stone. Nor am I able to confirm that some banks are charging borrowers up to 23 per cent on credit card loans. I have not had time to do that. If that is the case and there has been no reduction in the interest rate charged by all or some banks on credit card loans which is compatible with the fall in short term deposits, the only thing I can suggest at this stage is that the people concerned should go to alternative financial institutions-that is, alternative to banks-such as credit unions and building societies, which I understand are providing similar credit facilities at lower rates of interest.

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware that a number of leopard seals have died on Heard Island, a part of Australia's Antarctic Territory, as a result of anaesthetics or tranquillisers administered by Antarctic Division scientists? Is the Minister aware that, despite seal deaths, the report of the Australian Antarctic research program 1987-88 states on page 80 that it is intended to continue this exercise over a period of years? Who supervises the activities of research scientists experimenting on living animals in Antarctica? Is there an ethics committee of the Antarctic Division? If not, are there plans to establish such a committee? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been leopard seal deaths on Heard Island, five of which I have been made aware of. Given that the purpose of Question Time is to inform the Senate, I should also confess that a number of elephant seals-so far nine that I have been made aware of-have died on Macquarie Island as a result of the use of anaesthetics to tranquillise the seals. The use of anaesthetics is part of the program to allow data to be collected on stomach contents and-near and dear to me in this place-blubber thickness, blood type and other work that is important in looking at seal populations.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that during last week I announced some action in respect of penguins and referred their injection with radioactive isotopes to a scientific committee, the news of these deaths has caused me some concern. There is no question that the death rate is higher than that expected. Obviously, there has been some underestimation of the effects of tranquillisers on seals when they go back into the herd and find that they are less able to defend themselves against the others. That being the case, I have issued instructions that the use of anaesthetics must be stopped pending a referral of this matter to the committee which is looking at the question of the penguins. I hope that if we can get that information through in the next few days-I think we are having some radio difficulty-we will be able to make sure that the process stops until there has been a proper evaluation. I should point out that all of these experiments are being conducted by highly qualified veterinarians, so there is no question of their being done by amateurs.

As far as the ethics committee part of the question is concerned, there is no ethics committee in the Antarctic Division. When I have received the results of the two inquiries that are now being made I might make a decision on whether there ought to be one.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is it the case that the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986, which was proclaimed on 1 July 1987, cannot be implemented until regulations are made specifying the control list of significant objects to be protected by the Act? Why have the regulations not been made and when are they expected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the regulations have not been made, and I should give some explanation. First off, obviously the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act aims to keep in Australia those objects which uniquely represent our culture. There are two categories: category A, containing those things which should never leave our shores, and category B, containing things which should leave our shores only after a proper evaluation. While the legislation is not retrospective, it will at least ensure that there will be no further depletion of items of cultural importance of the kind of which I am now speaking. It should also be noted that implementation of the legislation will put us in line with 60 countries around the world which have so far acknowledged the need for such legislation under the appropriate United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation convention. I would hope it will make us a nation keen to identify and protect our national cultural identity.

ANSWER.PARA: However, there have been some hold-ups in the control list of categories, and some disputes between departments. An interdepartmental committee (IDC) has been set up. I am very hopeful that we will get a positive response from the IDC within two to three weeks. The regulations will then be made and the legislation can be implemented. Obviously if that timetable is way out I will have to account for that here. I am hopeful that the matter can be resolved, and resolved quickly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of the gross under-representation of women among senior decision-makers in higher education, and in particular is she aware of the report by Professor Helen Hughes in the Times on Sunday of 14 February that there is only one woman vice-chancellor in Australia, only 3 per cent of the professors are women, and in science the number falls to 2 per cent and in engineering and economics and commerce it is only one per cent? I ask the Minister whether she agrees with the following comment of Professor Hughes:

QUESTION.PARA: Women who take part in intellectual debate in Australia have to be prepared to be treated as lepers.

Does the Minister share the concern of Professor Di Yerbury, Vice-Chancellor of Macquarie University, who, according to a report in the same newspaper, has told the Affirmative Action Agency that the Government's plans to divert resources to science and technology fields `could have major ramifications for the social sciences and humanities where women are more likely to be employed'? As the Minister responsible for enhancing the position of Australian women-which Senator Reynolds certainly failed to do in her answer to Senator Vanstone-what action will she take to ensure that the Government's alleged interest in the advancement of women is not cancelled out, at least in higher education, by another Government policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Senator Tambling's question because it gives me the opportunity to announce that I will be discussing just this issue with Professor Hughes on Thursday. I can assure all honourable senators and all women who have been expressing their concerns about a number of the issues just outlined that I will be addressing these matters as a matter of some priority. I think at this stage it is most appropriate for me to reassure the honourable senator that I do have a number of concerns, and I will be discussing them with Professor Hughes, on Thursday.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am disappointed that it is only on Thursday that the Minister will be discussing these issues with senior academic women in Australia. I ask her, further, what action she has taken in the past to ensure that planned higher education changes and the policies of this Government announced by Mr Dawkins are in fact consistent with the policies that both she and the Prime Minister have been advocating.

—All I can say is that this Government has done a great deal more than has the Opposition. It might be of interest to know that it was under the Fraser Government that, as an academic woman, I was retrenched. So I am in a very good position to understand precisely what the policies were of the Opposition and I have no qualms at all about addressing a number of the present issues.

—When does the Minister for Home Affairs expect to receive the report from the Australian Electoral Commission on enrolment movements in Federal divisions over the past three years? Can the Minister confirm whether there have been any significant variations in enrolment from the projections made by the Electoral Commission at the time of the 1984 redistribution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I expect to receive in the next two weeks the report from the Electoral Commission. That report, 3 1/2 years down the track from the redistribution, will comment on and show whether its predictions in 1984 on enrolment growth were right or wrong. Over a number of years the Electoral Commission has also put out graphs indicating the trend lines. Having read those over the last few months, it is particularly gratifying to see how closely the projected and actual enrolments are. When we established this section of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in 1983, we anticipated many problems that commissioners would face in predicting future enrolments because there is no scientific or proven statistical method by which this can be carried out with absolute precision. It is a little easier to do than picking Melbourne Cup winners-but not much.

ANSWER.PARA: For the most part, the trend lines are very encouraging. I expect that with that experience behind them, the next time there is a redistribution the commissioners will be able to do it with even more accuracy. There are one or two aberrations, but before I move to those let me say that only one electorate, the electorate of McPherson, is now outside the 10 per cent variance allowed. That is a very remarkable achievement in our electoral laws when we consider what happened in the past. For instance I will go back to 1966 when the seat of West Sydney had 29,000-odd electors and the seat of Bruce in Victoria had 120,000 electors. We had these 4 : 1 ratios consistently. Even after the 1966 election, the variation in enrolments in New South Wales was 32.15 per cent. So thanks to the support of not only the Australian Labor Party but also the Liberal Party of Australia for this part of the legislation when it went through-naturally, the Nationals did not support it-we can be gratified that those achievements are there.

In one or two cases I regard the result as disappointing. The seat of Scullin is one and there are one or two others in which predicted growth simply did not transpire. I know that the Commissioner not only has investigated in the theoretical sense by checking with as many sources as possible; he has also driven around the electorate of Scullin to try to discover the reasons why the growth did not occur. Any people who have had experience in drawing up submissions to the Electoral Commission-and I know there are a few in this chamber-predicting growth or otherwise, know it is not a particularly easy task. At least with that one criterion for redistribution being dominant, for the first time we have a very objective approach to redistribution-one that is missing in nearly every other country in the world and, in many cases, in State governments in this country. I hope that when those figures are released people will be able to acknowledge the excellent job done by those redistribution commissioners in terms of those predictions in 1984. Armed with that knowledge and a little more experience hopefully in the future the figures will become even more accurate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELF-RELIANCE AND CO-OPERATION: AUSTRALIA'S REGIONAL DEFENCE POLICY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, I seek leave to make a statement entitled `Self-Reliance and Co- operation: Australia's Regional Defence Policy', to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Since the publication of the Dibb report on Australia's Defence Capabilities 18 months ago, there has been much discussion of Australian defence policy and the key concepts that underlie that policy. This Government has fostered that discussion, seeking to encourage the exchange and development of ideas between the defence establishment and the community at large. As honourable senators are aware, this process culminated last year in the release of the policy information paper The Defence of Australia-the first White Paper on Australian defence policy for 11 years. The exchange of views is a two-way process and will, I hope, lead to a more thorough understanding of the substance of our defence policy among the broader community. My aim today is to continue that process by outlining the actions the Government is taking in our regional defence relations to reinforce the positive factors in our strategic environment.

Much of the public debate on Australia's defence policy since the publication of the Dibb Review has concentrated on force structure issues. In the statement to the House almost a year ago, on 19 March 1987, the Minister for Defence noted that this Government has established the course for a decade or more of development of a self-reliant capability for the defence of Australia. We have developed a force structure plan specifically tailored to Australia's unique strategic circumstances.

We are pressing ahead with the largest capital equipment program for the ADF in Australia's peacetime history. What has often been overlooked is that the same capabilities that we are developing for the defence of Australia are well suited to co-operation with our regional and other defence partners.

It is salutary to remember that Australia's self-reliant defence posture has been developed within the framework of our alliances and regional associations. These associations are of great importance to us. Relations with countries within our area of primary strategic interest are crucial, because it is within this area that developments can have the most impact on Australia's security prospects.
In October and November last year the Minister for Defence undertook a series of visits to some of our neighbours in South East Asia and the South West Pacific.

Those visits had three main purposes. Firstly, he wanted to explain to our neighbours the direction of Australian defence policy following the publication of our white paper, and particularly to explain how we see the development of our defence relations with our neighbours in the light of that policy.

Secondly, he wanted to learn from our neighbours how they perceive their own strategic circumstances and military needs, and to learn how they think Australia could best cooperate with them to protect mutual interests.
Thirdly, he wanted to discuss a number of specific proposals for defence cooperation between ourselves and our neighbours.
His talks in the countries he visited were very fruitful in all these respects, and as a result he believes we have now established a solid framework of defence relations with our neighbours.

I have sought this opportunity to address the House so that I may describe this framework of regional defence relations, explain how it fits into our overall defence policy, and outline the practical cooperative activities which will give our regional defence relationships real substance.

Close attention to our regional defence relations is important at this time, because many of the policies, assumptions and habits which for decades provided the strategic and operational basis for much of our regional defence activity have, over the past few years, been overtaken by important changes.

Not the least important of these changes has been our adoption, in the Defence White Paper, of a defence policy which defines a rigorous national strategy for Australia to achieve a self-reliant defence posture.
The Minister believes that our self-reliant defence policy is well understood by our regional neighbours as an effective and achievable program to meet our military needs.

In particular, he found rather less inclination among our neighbours than among people at home to confuse self-reliance with isolationism. This confusion is evident among many who have commented on the Dibb Review and the White Paper. Until it is understood that self-reliance requires, rather than precludes, active defence relations with our neighbours, the rationale of our regional defence cooperation will not be clear.
When people get confused about Australia's strategic circumstances, it is usually because they are applying the principles of the 1930s to the problems of the 1980s.

In the 1930s, Australians had a stark choice. Australia could either commit itself to the imperial system of naval defence, or it could develop land and air forces to defend the continent. Our strategic and financial circumstances enforced a clear choice between alliance and isolationism.
This view of our defence position persisted into the 1960s and 1970s in the debate over forward defence versus Fortress Australia.
But while the dilemma may have been genuine in the 1930s, it was much less clear in the 1960s. Today it is meaningless.
With careful planning, Australia can now maintain a defence force which can both defend our territories and approaches, and contribute to the security of our broader region.

Australia no longer needs to make a choice between self-reliance on the one hand and our network of alliances and regional associations on the other. We have the capacity-and indeed the requirement-to do both.

The lessons of history, geography and commonsense all show that Australia's defence posture cannot ignore the strategic circumstances of our neighbourhood. Even if we wanted to, we have no choice but to develop and maintain our own defence links with our neighbours as an essential aspect of our self-reliant defence posture.

We can no longer see our defence role in our region simply as an adjunct to our broader alliances. But that is no longer acceptable to us or to our allies, who will increasingly look to us to play a larger role in the region as their own resources shrink.
Nor is it acceptable to our neighbours, who look to Australia to play an independent role in our region commensurate with our size and resources.
Our self-reliant defence posture is essential to our role in the strategic affairs of our region, as it is also to our broader alliances.
It is very important to understand what that means in purely military terms.

The defence force structure which we have adopted in the White Paper as a blueprint for the Australian Defence Force provides Australia with an unprecedented capability to deploy military forces throughout our region and to co-operate with our neighbours in support of our security.

The development of Australia's self-reliant defence capabilities provides great opportunities. Our capacity for security co-operation in our region will expand as we increase our fleet with long-range ships, and submarines, provide the latest combat aircraft with airborne refuelling, improve surveillance capabilities, relocate major facilities closer to our neighbours in the north and west of Australia, and increase the firepower, mobility and deployability of our ground forces.

This is no accident. We regard it as an essential element of Australia's defence posture that the capabilities we develop to provide for our own defence should also provide us with the capability to play our part in maintaining regional security.

This has been obscured by a misunderstanding about the geographical delineation of our strategic interests. Our area of direct military interest, defined in the Dibb Review as extending 4,000 miles from east to west and 3,000 miles from north to south, identifies the area in which Australia must be able to exert-independently-decisive military power.
The clear definition of our area of direct military interest is central to decisions about the sorts of military capabilities we need to develop.

But the area of direct military interest does not circumscribe the regions in which Australia recognises that it has strategic interests, nor does it circumscribe the areas in which we recognise the need to develop defence co-operation with neighbours to achieve shared strategic goals.

Indeed, we have described a much larger area of broad strategic interest, covering one-quarter of the earth's surface and including all the nations of South East Asia and the South West Pacific. Within this area of broad strategic interest we intend to develop and maintain defence relations, co-operate in the development of defence capabilities, and undertake military deployments, visits and exercises with our regional neighbours.
As I have said, one of the major aims of the Minister's recent visits was to learn how our neighbours perceive strategic developments in our region.

He was struck by the much more balanced discussion of strategic issues among our neighbours than is often seen here. In Australia the strategic circumstances of our region are often discussed in a very negative way-in terms of identifying prospective military threats to Australia.

As an illustration of the prevalence of vague and simplistic threat perceptions that underlie this approach, I need only point to the reaction in some circles to last year's unacceptable political developments in Fiji. In response to these developments, some commentators called for a revision of Australia's defence policy. What was evident once again was a failure to distinguish between events we do not like and those which threaten our security. The point is that with no clear cut understanding of these distinctions we miss the appropriate political-military response. It is particularly important that we get that distinction right when we examine issues such as those arising from the Soviet position in Cam Ranh Bay.

History is replete with examples of the dangers of allowing this thinking to go unchallenged. Defence policy-makers and politicians since the war have often been led astray by responding to suggested threats to our national security based on inadequate strategic appreciations. The results have been disastrous to effective defence policy making.

This point is particularly apposite in considering the kind of defence relations we should pursue with countries in our region of broader strategic interest. We are indeed fortunate in that we share a region with neighbours with whom we have many common strategic perspectives. We recognise, however, that the region is continually changing and becoming more complex. Greater interest is being shown in the South Pacific by external powers than previously. We have all been disappointed by the political upheavals in Fiji and continued instability in the Philippines. South Pacific island countries are keenly aware of their economic vulnerability and this will continue to provide opportunities for countries with interests inimical to our own. At the same time, in South East Asia a number of our regional neighbours are developing, on a national basis, increasingly sophisticated military capabilities for external defence.

None of these developments in our region of broader strategic interest directly threatens our own security. But they demand that we adjust our thinking and cooperative activities to contemporary change. Regional strategic developments require careful analysis so that they are understood accurately. This is fundamental. For too long, the Australian public has been served up a distorted analysis of events in our region by those who are imbued with the shibboleths of past eras of strategic thinking.

The notion that Australia has a role to play as `regional policeman' in South East Asia and the South Pacific is the prime example of this outdated thinking. Those who advocate that Australia should still play such a role, totally neglect to consider that since the 1950s and 1960s the nations of South East Asia have impressed the world by the way they have met the challenges of political and economic development. As part of that extraordinary development, the nations of the region have developed their own armed forces to the point where they no longer look primarily to others to provide for their own defence.

In the South Pacific, the island groups have developed into independent nations with their own strategic perceptions and concerns. With the exception of the French territories and American Samoa, all of the island countries have moved from their former dependent colonial status to full independence or to political self-determination. More recently we have seen the rise of indigenous nationalism as the island states have developed their own and, in many cases, regional approaches to dealing with domestic and international issues. As the Minister noted in his statement in February last year, these processes are inevitable and reflect the growing international self-confidence and self-reliance of the island states.

In these circumstances, it would be entirely inappropriate and counter-productive for Australia to seek to impose its will on regional countries. Australia's role and its only proper role, is to act as a partner with our regional neighbours.
In pursuing this role, we have to recognise that it is a complex process, which requires the balancing of a diverse range of considerations.

With some nations in our area of direct military interest we have long-established defence relations going back many decades. In others we have just begun to develop defence relations with newly-independent nations. In the case of our long-established defence relations with some countries of South East Asia, the challenge is to adapt those relations to changing circumstances.

The changes on both sides make some of the old forms of co-operation outdated, while opening many new opportunities in other areas. Our aim in adapting to these changes with our South East Asian partners has been to preserve as much as possible of the underlying political framework of co-operation, leaving us free to reshape the actual content of co-operation as much as necessary.

Perhaps the clearest example of this process is the evolution of our participation with Malaysia and Singapore in the Five Power Defence Arrangements. The FPDA were established in 1971 between Malaysia, Singapore, Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom to support the security of Malaysia and Singapore after the withdrawal of British forces east of Suez.
Australia believes that the FPDA remain relevant to our objective of promoting regional stability and security, and we continue to support them.

But the material form of our support will soon change in some important ways. Next month, RAAF FA18 Hornet fighter-attack aircraft will deploy to Butterworth for the first time to coincide with the return to Australia of the Mirages before being withdrawn from service.

Under the FPDA's integrated air defence system, Australia has based Mirage aircraft at Butterworth in Malaysia for many years. This has been a substantial commitment, involving up to two-thirds of our total fighter strength.
The Mirage is now being replaced in the RAAF by the FA18.
The introduction of the FA18 has required us to re-examine all aspects of our operations and deployments, including the basing of aircraft at Butterworth.

We have concluded that the enormous capabilities of the Hornets could most effectively be exploited by basing all aircraft in Australia, and deploying them on rotation to bases in Malaysia and Singapore.

The technical reasons for that decision are important to understand. Firstly, the FA18 requires less frequent maintenance than the Mirage, which means that it can operate for much longer periods away from its support base.
On the other hand, the infrastructure required to maintain the FA18 when this is required is much greater than for the Mirage, because the new aircraft is considerably more sophisticated and capable.

Taken together, these two factors mean that it is much more efficient to centralise maintenance and other support facilities for the FA18, than to disperse those facilities around the different areas where the aircraft will be operating.

This policy of centralising support facilities does not restrict the scope of operations of the FA18, because it is much more easily deployed over long distances than the Mirage. It has much longer range, and it can be refuelled in the air. This means that an FA18 can be deployed from Australia to South East Asia in four hours-and it can then stay there without elaborate support for a significant time.

Lastly, we are developing a major base for the FA18s at Tindal near Katherine in the Northern Territory. Tindal is as close to Singapore as it is to Canberra. So the FA18s will never be far away from South East Asia.

These then are the reasons why we have decided, in consultation with the Malaysian and Singaporean governments, to alter the basis of our contribution to the air defence of this area when the FA18s are introduced. Instead of basing aircraft in Malaysia permanently, squadrons of FA18s will deploy to Malaysia and Singapore for a total of at least 16 weeks of the year. We will also commence rotational deployments of our F111 long-range strike aircraft to Malaysia and Singapore.

It is most important to understand that our decision to move from permanent basing of aircraft in Malaysia to rotational deployments from Australia is based on the technical characteristics and capabilities of our new aircraft, and is aimed at maximising the contribution these aircraft make to the security of the region.

A significant presence of several hundred Australian Defence Force personnel, including an army rifle company, will be maintained at Butterworth to support these deployments and other activities continuing there.

The Government believes that this program clearly demonstrates our continuing willingness to commit a significant proportion of our air force to the support of regional security through the integrated air defence system.
We also believe that the new arrangements will allow fuller and more appropriate co-operation with the growing capabilities and expertise of the Malaysian and Singaporean air forces.

These will not be our only aircraft deployments to this region. We will maintain a program of continuous rotational deployment of P3C long-range maritime patrol aircraft through Butterworth. Malaysia's and our own surveillance of the region provides a valuable contribution to regional surveillance efforts by monitoring the busy sea-ways of the South China Sea and the Straits of Malacca.

Across the whole spectrum of our defence co-operation in South East Asia, we are adapting to the growing sophistication of the defence forces of our partners. This has been reflected in a growing trend away from the old equipment-based programs in which Australia would supply the hardware and training to develop a distinct capability within another nation's defence force. That sort of program is no longer appropriate. Instead the emphasis is on service-to-service training and exchanges of personnel, with much greater scope for mutual benefit both to our neighbours' defence forces and our own.

The nature of our defence activities in South East Asia is also changing in the light of changes in our naval forces. We will expand our surface fleet with the introduction of new frigates and submarines.
The progressive transfer of half the fleet from their present base in Sydney to Western Australia significantly enhances the Navy's ability to deploy to South East Asia.

While the Minister was in South East Asia last year he proposed to the governments of Malaysia and Singapore that Australia would, if they agreed, establish a pattern of rotational deployments to our Five Power Defence Arrangements partners in the region.
This proposal received the support of both governments. The deployments will begin soon, and the rotational pattern will be fully established next year.

We will also substantially increase our naval contribution to the region by providing what will be in effect the continuous presence of a major combatant of the Australian Navy in South East Asian waters. While there, the Australian ships will train and exercise with regional navies, to the benefit of both.

Other new opportunities also arose during his visit to expand defence co-operation in the region. In Bangkok it was agreed to establish a series of combined exercises in Thailand by Australian and Thai army units at company level. This will add a new dimension to our defence co-operation with Thailand.

His visit to Brunei, the first by an Australian Defence Minister, gave him an opportunity to review the direction of our defence relationship with that country. We regard Brunei as an important member of our region, and are keen to develop our defence relationship with them.

We have been pleased to see that our defence relations with Brunei have developed substantially since Brunei's independence four years ago. Activities have focused on Royal Brunei Armed Forces training and exercising in Australia, but we hope to expand that with ADF visits to Brunei and other activities.

Although we have an increasingly substantial program of defence activities with regional countries, we have been disappointed to see some decline in the level of our co-operative activities with Indonesia. We regard Indonesia as a valuable security partner and continue to place importance on the maintenance of sound and constructive defence relations.

I would like to see our defence contacts broadened beyond the former focus on materiel-based projects towards a range of other activities such as exercises, senior level visits and personnel exchanges, which will lead to a mature and reciprocal relationship appropriate to two neighbouring countries. Such cooperation must, of course, be a two-way process and on the basis of mutual respect for the fundamental features of our respective social and political systems.

This year we will spend $18m on defence cooperation with South East Asian nations. Generally in South East Asia we remain a welcome partner. We must be sensitive to the fact that our friends have occasional differences in international outlook with us and we must be careful to ensure that our cooperation is seen in a regional context. We must also recognise that with developments in the defence forces of the countries of South East Asia our cooperation is very much of mutual benefit.

Our defence relations with PNG fall into a special category. Australia's defence links with PNG have their historic origins in the period of Australian administration of that country, and the establishment of the Pacific Island Regiment under Australian leadership.
The strength of our defence cooperation is based on that common historical experience and the abiding strategic importance of PNG for Australian security.

Since independence, Australia has maintained a large defence cooperation programme with PNG. In recent years that program has accounted for around half of our entire defence cooperation effort, costing over $20m. This year our defence cooperation programme with PNG totals $23m.

In the years immediately following independence in 1975, our defence cooperation with PNG tended to reflect the colonial defence arrangements before independence. In the mid-1970s there were still some 500 Australian service personnel on loan to the PNG defence force integrated into all areas of PNGDF activities.
Since then Papua New Guinea, has evolved an independent defence force drawing on the skills and resources of the PNG people.

As the PNGDF has evolved, our defence co-operation program has evolved with it. Australian service personnel integrated into the PNGDF have been largely replaced by PNG nationals, and the focus of our efforts has moved to training, advisory and materiel assistance.

This process of evolution from a colonial defence relationship was finally concluded late last year with the signature by our two Prime Ministers of the joint declaration of principles. That document includes clauses on defence which mark the beginning of a new phase of our defence relationship with PNG. Those clauses mark the maturing of our defence relationship to a full and equal partnership between sovereign nations.
Importantly, the defence section of the joint declaration begins with the recognition that Australia and PNG are each responsible for their own defence.

Honourable senators will recall that other clauses relate to important elements of our defence cooperation activities, while the last clause expresses our intention to consult at the request of either party in the event of external armed attack which threatens the national sovereignty of either country.

I regard the defence section of the joint declaration as an important statement of our enduring support for the security of PNG, and as a significant symbol of the growth of our defence relationship to full maturity.
As such the declaration is a credit to the PNG Government which initiated it.

The PNG Government's defence initiatives have not been limited to the diplomatic front. They have developed a series of policies to which we are glad to respond in formulating our cooperative programs.

One example is the PNGDF's engineering activity. Prime Minister Wingti and his Defence Minister, Mr Pokasui, are keen to expand the role of the PNGDF in such activities. The ADF has a long involvement in engineering in PNG, for example in the long term deployment of an army engineering unit to Mendi.

While the Minister was in PNG last year the expansion of our engineering assistance to the PNGDF was raised, and it was agreed that we would work in conjunction with the PNGDF on an increased range of engineering tasks for infrastructure development.

Another important initiative arising from his visit is our agreement to upgrade the facilities of the Papua New Guinea defence force patrol boat base at Manus Island. That facility has clear importance to the significant work done by the PNG defence force maritime component in resources surveillance. The improved facilities will allow us to deploy, for extended periods, Royal Australian Navy patrol boats to Manus Island and the Department of Defence is currently examining the operational aspects of these deployments.

This initiative, combined with increased deployments of Royal Australian Air Force long range maritime patrol aircraft to cover the northern area of PNG's exclusive economic zone will ensure that our cooperative effort in maritime surveillance will be extensive and efficient.

These initiatives are being taken against the background of a very large and diverse defence cooperation relationship which includes an annual series of combined exercises, training in Australia for over 200 PNGDF personnel each year, and a wide range of in-country technical and advisory support, consultancy and project activity.

In recent years we have been glad to see a number of other countries, particularly the US and NZ, develop their own defence relationships with PNG. We welcome this diversification of PNG's defence cooperation to include our allies. It provides valuable additional assistance to the PNGDF, and is clear evidence of the growing maturity of PNG's international defence relationships.

At the start of this speech I spoke of the great changes in our region which have required us to restructure our defence relations. Of those changes none has been greater than the emergence, over the past 15 years, of a complex community of independent nations in the South West Pacific.

In historical terms the creation of this community is very recent. We in Australia are only now coming to know the individual countries which have appeared to our north and east as distinctive entities, with separate traditions, resources, and policies.

Last year in a statement to the House the Minister announced that we would be placing a high priority on developing these defence relations-indeed that we would give them the same priority as we give to our long-standing defence relations with PNG and the nations of South East Asia.

In the defence area we are only beginning to establish relations with the island nations. His visit to the Solomons, Kiribati, Tuvalu and Vanuatu last year was the first by any Australian Defence Minister to any of these countries.

But we have made a very good start. We have responded to the clearly-expressed priorities of the island nations by undertaking, in cooperation with New Zealand, an integrated approach to helping the island states to exercise the most fundamental element of nationhood-sovereign control of their lands and waters.

Last year's events in Fiji have the potential to pose long term problems for our cooperative defence activities in the South Pacific, especially our longer term objective of promoting a network for regional maritime surveillance. Defence cooperation with Fiji remains suspended and its resumption is dependent on future developments in Fiji. In recognition of the important interests we share with Fiji, the Government will continue to keep that relationship under review.

The central pillar of our effort to assist the South West Pacific nations is of course the Pacific patrol boat program. Three boats have now been handed over, two to PNG and one to Vanuatu. This year boats will be presented to Western Samoa, the Solomons and PNG.

We have been pleased by the way the boats have been received, and by the way they are being put into service. In Vanuatu, for example, the Government has been so impressed with the work the boat has been doing that it has asked that we send up a RAN patrol boat to stand in while the RVS Tokoro returns to Townsville for scheduled maintenance. We have been delighted to respond, and HMAS Cessnock will spend over six weeks in Vanuatu.
As the program has progressed we are improving the boat and the package of training and support which goes with it.
For example, learning from our early experience, we have decided from now on to install airconditioning in the Pacific patrol boats, and to retrofit it to those already delivered.

We are also taking a flexible attitude to the specific needs of different recipients of the boat. For example, the Cook Islands has asked us to look at installing extra freezer capability in their boat, and we have been glad to respond. Vanuatu has asked for some armament to be fitted, and that has been done.

In view of their special budgetary problems, Kiribati and Tuvalu have asked us to look at ways of extending the support package for the Pacific patrol boat to enable them to join the program. Again, we have agreed to see what we can do.

One of the most important elements of the PPB programme is the deployment of RAN officers and technical experts for extended periods to each participating country to assist in establishing and operating these vessels.

These are the men who will make the PPB program work, and they are doing an outstanding job. They are laying important foundations of goodwill and competence upon which our defence relations with these countries will be built.

Next month the Department of Defence, in association with the New Zealand Department of Defence and the South Pacific Forum Fisheries Agency, is sponsoring a maritime surveillance seminar in which all member countries of the South Pacific Forum will participate. The Seminar will discuss operation and procedural aspects of maritime surveillance activities in the region. It will provide an opportunity for regional country representatives to gain insight into the policies and operations of other regional countries and will allow participants to exchange views on these developments.

During the Minister's visit to the South Pacific, island leaders expressed their appreciation of our cooperative defence activities and particularly of our Royal Australian Air Force long range maritime patrol flights, which have been increased, and our Royal Australian Navy ship visits.
As more Pacific patrol boats are brought into service by regional countries, increased opportunities will be taken by the Royal Australian Navy to exercise with the Pacific patrol boats.

The progress that has been achieved to date in this area puts us closer to the realisation of our objective to assist regional maritime cooperation and eventually to establish a network for regional maritime surveillance based on cooperation and compatible national efforts. As a further step towards this objective, the Minister announced during his visit to the Solomon Islands that he would have his Department examine the possibility of making available a maritime surveillance aircraft to be at the disposal of Forum Island countries to meet their immediate surveillance needs.

Other elements of our defence cooperation with South West Pacific nations include civil engineering projects, often in remote locations, and assistance with communications. The ADF also gives important assistance to our South West Pacific neighbours in national emergencies like cyclones. This assistance is very important, and much appreciated.
This year we have budgeted $16m for defence cooperation in the South West Pacific.

If anyone should entertain any doubts about the importance of the nations in our region to Australia's own security, I would recommend them to visit, as the Minister did late last year, the islands of Guadalcanal and Singapore.

Guadalcanal is now the site of the capital of the Solomons, Honiara, and a visit there can be recommended to anyone for its charm and peace. But no one with a sense of history can go there and not be awed by the immediacy of the great battle that was fought there 45 years ago this year. That battle was a battle for Australia, and Australians fought in it-as the wreck of HMAS Canberra lying in Ironbottom Sound, attests.

Singapore has, if anything, an even starker strategic message for Australians. The fall of Singapore in February 1942 was the darkest moment Australia has known in 200 years, and underlined unambiguously that Australia's security is tied to the security of South East Asia.

But equally a visit to these places today teaches that we must adapt our defence cooperation with our neighbours to the changes in our region. The policies of the 1950s will serve us poorly in the 1990s.

I believe the policies we are adopting and which I have sketched to the House today, will serve us well in promoting the security of our region through cooperation activities with our neighbours, and I commend them to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had this statement, entitled `Self-Reliance and Co-operation: Australia's Regional Defence Policy', been read to the Senate and set to music, we would have heard the tinkling of music boxes in the background playing nursery rhymes, because basically that is what this document is all about. It is most remarkable not for what it says but for what it does not say about important issues of military concern to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, let me go through some of the issues that the paper discusses. Its failings are exemplified by the fact that it fails to recognise the steadily declining influence of Australia in recent years in the South West Pacific and the Pacific region generally. This Government has adopted an introspective attitude in respect of defence matters; it is concerned only with the defence of Australian territories. The statement speaks little of the problems in the broader area of the Pacific region, which I will come to a little later. We find this approach of the Government a wide divergence of attitudes in the area of foreign affairs and the area of defence. Although we have a vast shortage of money to be spent on defence for the Pacific region, we find that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, is running around Africa dishing out large sums of money, totalling altogether some $100m, for the purpose of currying favour in that arena. Yet for the whole of the Pacific area, our most vital strategic area around Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, the Solomons and the broader areas around the micro-states of the Pacific, we have been able to find only a measly $58m in this current year. In fact, we have even cut back on our aid this year to Papua New Guinea. We find money going instead to, for example, no less a country than Mozambique in Africa.

This is evidence of our lack of capacity to establish any kind of reach-out ability in the Pacific region. Over the last 12 months we have all observed some very important, significant and somewhat worrying changes in the government of the island state of Fiji-right in our own sphere of influence in this area of the Pacific. Yet our Government could not put into the water one landing craft able to undertake any activity that might have been required in that area because of this Government's total inability to find sufficient funds to equip our forces properly. Is it any wonder that the countries of this area are not full of confidence in the Australian Government's attitude? They know that they need assistance, they want assistance from Australia, but they also know that under the Hawke Labor Government this country is not capable of delivering that assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many members of the Government are opposite, Senator?

—I can count two. Australia, of course, is obviously part of the future of South East Asia and of the Pacific region. Yet our whole effort, dedicated to facilitating the cooperation of our defence forces with the nations in this part of the world, is minimal. I will return to that point a little later, because it is mentioned in somewhat interesting terms in a latter part of the statement just put down by the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). Those countries are reading the signs that Australia is simply not serious about defending this part of the world. I repeat: Mr Hayden is taking his cheque book off to Africa and spending $100m of Australia's money while we cannot even find more than $50m-odd to promote defence co-operation with our near neighbours. That is against the background of some of the serious omissions from the statement. There is not one word here about the vast developments of the Soviet navy in the Pacific, about the developments of fishing contracts with some of the micro-states of the Pacific region or about what is happening in Vietnam or Kampuchea and the tensions developing in that area of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one word, however, about the base at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam that has been established as a southern port for the Soviet navy-one word, that is all. Cam Ranh Bay is mentioned but no conclusion is drawn, no attention is drawn to its existence and no comment is made on the abilities or otherwise and capacity of the Soviet navy to use that base more effectively than its current forces in Vladivostok further to the north. Clearly the existence and development of the Soviet navy in the Pacific and Indian oceans has been of the greatest concern to our allies the United States (US) and should be of the greatest concern to this Government. However, in this so-called statement, this nursery rhyme of a statement, we find not one word about that problem.

Let us also consider the developments in the Philippines. We have all known of the seething changes there in the last two years as a result of the change of government from the Marcos regime to the current regime. Yet underlying all this there has been speculation about the changes that may occur in the existence of US bases in the Philippines. Those bases at Clark Field and Subic Bay are vital to the total defence co-operation between the United States and this country in this part of the world. Speculation has existed about the future of those bases. But there is not one word, no comment whatsoever, in this paper about what the Government considers about any possible developments in that area which may affect Australia's strategic thinking. Yet speculation is building that some change to US bases in the Philippines may be occurring as a result of Department of Defense cutbacks in expenditure in the United States, brought about by the very high budget deficit of the United States and its growing severe problems. We hear not one word about that. I find it absolutely remarkable that the Australian Government, facing these challenges in this part of the world, is not prepared to tell us what it is thinking and how it is developing policies in this area to encompass these difficulties that obviously are lying in the path.

Australia has to face facts in the defence arena. It is a huge country, a large land mass, as we all know, with a very small population. Yet we are surrounded by countries in the reverse situation, with large populations but relatively small land masses to defend. We need to work, therefore, on the development of our relationships with those countries, with the Indonesians, Malaysians, Filipinos and so on. Indonesia perhaps is a classic example of the way we should be addressing these problems. Do we in the Senate know, does the Government admit-does it say it anywhere-that we do not have one student from the Indonesian armed forces in our staff colleges? Nor have we had any for the last two years. Yet in previous times we encouraged that kind of cooperation, liaison and interrelationship with our immediate neighbours, for our mutual benefit.

We see also that the Australian Defence Force is largely underutilised. We could be using it to assist those countries in our near north and the Pacific to build roads, bridges and infrastructure, given our capacity to do so with our Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF), Royal Australian Navy and Army personnel. But we do not develop that capacity, which would be a very important training and information seeking arm if we get involved in that exercise.
