We should be encouraging more joint exercises with the nations in our immediate vicinity but, again, there is no mention of that in this statement. We are too timid to talk about it. Maybe it is because Mr Hayden, the Foreign Minister, has greater sway over the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, in this matter. Instead, we get travel talk and nursery rhymes.

The ministerial statement talks about the force structure that is being developed from the recommendations that came down in the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities about 18 months ago. It is claimed that this is a plan which is unique to Australia's defence and strategic circumstances. In about 1983-84, Mr Beazley or his predecessor in defence said, `Yes, we are going to maintain a growth rate in real terms of expenditure on defence of 3 per cent'. Ever since the Government made that statement there has been a fall in our expenditure; in fact, the current financial year sees a fall of one per cent in Australian expenditure on defence. This will be affected by the blowing out of the cost of the new submarine contract and the well-known difficulties with the development of the frigate contract, which will absorb more and more money in the future at the expense of other parts of the Defence Force.

This statement lacks substance; it is merely a series of motherhood statements with no new initiatives whatsoever. Among the minor comments which sound like initiatives is the reference to the rotating of the new Hornet aeroplane with its deployment to Singapore and Malaysia. This is a backward step, given the reduction of the Mirage squadron presently situated in Butterworth to a force on a rotational basis. It will fill only a 16-week period throughout any calendar year in those two areas. We are also, apparently, going to maintain the Orion force, the submarine reconnaisance, through Butterworth; but this is something that we have already heard about. It is nothing new as far as we are concerned.

As a result of this statement, let us look at some of the things we intend to do in Thailand. We see that there will be more exercises with Thai forces. It is now five years since this Government came to power and in that time we have not had one exercise with those forces in that part of the world. This shows how much credence we can give to the statements from the Minister-none at all. There is a reference in the statement-no more-to the use of the PC3s, the Orions, over New Guinea and its approaches. Where are the forces coming from to undertake that kind of work? There are no explanations and no statement has been made as to the future direction; there is just some kind of broad commitment which, in the end, does not amount to any kind of commitment at all. All these things are prefaced with maybes and considerations of future developments. The largest capital expenditure program in history is apparently being undermined by cost overruns and by expenditure and control problems with these various projects.

We read of increases which the Government has cleverly devised from the use of figures to demonstrate that somehow the Defence Force is increasing its numbers, but the fact is that in the most important areas of officer services, pilots in the Air Force and so on, there actually has been a decline in the number of these very well trained officers and those other people whom the Defence Force mainly relies upon. In the last six months 117 pilots have resigned from the RAAF. If we have read the newspapers of recent days we would find it extraordinarily difficult to understand how the Air Force can keep its new force of FA18 aircraft in the air because it is simply not training pilots quickly enough for them to be able to take over the positions of these people who are resigning. These pilots, of course, are taking up more lucrative positions in private commercial aviation. Some are working with Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, others with Qantas Airways Ltd, and so on. One thing that is helping them along the way is the threat over superannuation that they may or may not get as members of the Royal Australian Air Force.

All this has come at a time when the word on the Government's lips in defence is supposed to be self-sufficiency, but it is just another name for introspection. What we should be doing is looking outward towards the Pacific and Indian Oceans and developing a strategy based on that, despite the Government's policy of withdrawal and isolation. The Government admits in the statement that the allies are looking to us to play a larger role. Then they are served up this little bit. What, for instance, will we be doing with airborne refuelling? We have talked about that, and heard that talked about, for quite some time now. When is it coming for the F111s? We have not heard any more about that. What about improving surveillance? It is a shambles, as we all know. We have no airborne radar. The Jindalee is still 10 years away, yet the hours for the PC3s, the Orion force, carrying out its activities over the Indian Ocean and the northern approaches, have been reduced from 1,200 to 700. This is a sign of increased surveillance, of improvements in our capacity, the development of confidence with our near neighbours? The Government must be joking.

Our area of direct military interest is defined in this paper as a general area of 7,000 kilometres by 5,000 kilometres. In the paper the Government says that we must be able to project independent, comprehensive military power in order to provide for our direct security. That is a vast area, as all honourable senators will admit. Yet, the Government, in this statement, or in any other statement, will not define the countries or land masses it is designed to cover. The Government just speaks broadly about a square or rectangle across the world's maps and does not speak at all about our strategic interests in respect of individual areas that might be encompassed by it. We obviously cannot establish a clear view of what the Government's strategic thinking is when it will not get down to tintacks and tell us exactly what it has in mind, and this is against the background, as I mentioned earlier, that we could not even find the capacity to land troops in Fiji if we had had to do so last year.

It is clear that this gross overgeneralisation of our situation in this country that the forces immediately in our vicinity somehow are all looking to us and have confidence in the Australian development of its defence forces is absolute nonsense. They are all screaming for help. The expenditure of many of them on defence is underdeveloped and they are clearly looking to Australia. The best example we can point to to show the nature and depth of the problem is Papua New Guinea which is already starting to establish military contacts with both New Zealand and the United States of America. That clearly does not demonstrate clear confidence in Australia in this part of the world, yet we are spending $100m in Africa instead of paying attention to our immediate needs in our own part of the world. We are committed-and it is not mentioned too much-to some expansion of our defence forces, in our surface fleet with frigates and our underwater fleet with new submarines. The point about this, of course, is that that is merely a replacement of craft already in existence; they are not new additions to our force. Consequently, nations in this vicinity have no confidence at all as to where we might be headed.

We are spending $23m in Papua New Guinea, yet Papua New Guinea is vital to the future defence of this nation. Why is it that we continue under this Government to spend $100m in Africa? We should be doing more about Manus Island. Some reference is made to that in this statement, but very little. We need to increase our effort in trying to train the forces of countries in our immediate vicinity. We need to be providing engineering assistance to those nations nearby, and we have a capacity to do that. Above all, we should be expanding our joint exercise program with those foreign nations.

I believe the future rests on about three main points. The first is that we need to be less concerned about allocating money to countries outside of our region, such as those in Africa, and more concerned about increasing expenditure and developing assistance to areas in our immediate region. The expansion of our defence co-operation program is really the basis of the development of a truly effective defence force in this part of the world. We must make more and greater use of our Defence Force capacity, both from the point of view of self-interest and in order to provide greater help for our allies and potential allies in this part of the world.

All we can really conclude about this statement is that it is a lot of twaddle. It is full of nursery rhymes. It suggests no real initiative. Had the Minister for Home Affairs presented a statement that said that the Government intended to increase expenditure in this part of the world and reduce expenditure in Africa and had he provided us with some definite idea of the future directions of the Government's strategic thinking, we would have a clear view of the Defence Force arrangements the Government had under consideration. This statement offers us nothing. Not one extra cent is to be spent on new developments in these areas. Is it any wonder that countries in this region continue to ignore us and our defence capabilities?

I conclude by referring to a couple of statements made on pages 26 and 27 of the statement which I believe characterise the level of thinking of, and the Mickey Mouse approach adopted by, the Government in this statement. Let us look at what has been put down as one of the major expenditure items designed to assist development of co-operation in the defence arena. On page 27 of the statement, this sentence appears:
For example, learning from our early experiences, we have decided from now on to install air-conditioning in the Pacific patrol boats, and to retrofit it to those already delivered.

That will be a great step forward in the establishment and development of our strategic interest and the capacity of our forces in this part of the world. The second sentence to which I draw attention is this, and this is a real doozey:
We are also taking a flexible attitude to the specific needs of different recipients of the boat.
That refers to the boats being given to some nations in this area. The statement continues:
For example, the Cook Islands has asked us to look at installing extra freezer capability in their boat, and we have been glad to respond.

This document, which is supposed to be taken seriously, is trying to give us some sort of idea of the strategic thinking of this Government in this area of the world. With the Soviet navy at our doorstep operating out of Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, with tensions developing in Vietnam and Kampuchea, our magnificent response in terms of expenditure on equipment and the development of co-operation with the nations in this area is to ensure that the Cook Islands boat is fitted with a freezer and that air-conditioning is installed in the patrol vessels that will operate in this area. That absolutely throws the focus onto the big issues that this country is addressing. Quite clearly this is the level of attention that this Government is paying to our defence forces. The Government is incompetent, it is hopeless, and it is time that it went.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that there are some aspects of the statement presented by the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) with which I can agree, though I obviously take issue with the basic premise on which this defence statement rests, and that is the concept of self-reliance within the alliance framework. That is a contradiction in terms. I do not believe that we can be self-reliant and independent in our defence capabilities while we are involved in this alliance with the United States of America. That is not to say that we do not need regional agreements with countries in our own part of the world. Of course we do. I am glad that the Minister in his statement stresses the need to reject the views of those who still live in the era of forward defence or those who are alarmist in their predictions about invasion paranoias for this country. That is simply an excuse to argue for more equipment for their particular branch of the armed services. Such equipment represents a sort of Defence Force wish list.

SPEECH.PARA: I have long argued for a greater understanding of our neighbours within the Asia-Pacific region. That position has also been taken by the Australian peace movement which has co-operated closely with the nuclear free and independent Pacific movement since it was set up in 1975 and the campaign for demilitarisation of the Indian Ocean. Paradoxically perhaps we have shared with this Government the views expressed in the 1981 report Threats to Australia's Security, their Nature and Probability, and the view that there is no invasion threat to Australia and that any country, other than the United States or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, that wished to mount such an invasion would take at least five to 10 years to prepare for it.

I believe that what Australia should be looking forward to is self-reliant defensive defence; that is, a genuine self-defence policy which does not involve Australia in buying very expensive and highly sophisticated equipment, particularly from the United States, which does not serve the defence needs of Australia but which suits our alliance partner very well indeed for the joint exercises in which we engage and the continual war games that we play with the United States defence forces, many of which have very little to do with the defence of Australia. That is particularly so when it is considered that many of them take place in the central Pacific area, they involve the United States nuclear navy chasing hunter-killer submarines and I believe they are not relevant to the defence of this part of the world.

I recognise, however, that after 200 years of this great threat paranoia, which is still uppermost in the minds of many Australians, it is important that the Minister addresses this issue. A news poll conducted on 6 November last year indicated that 40 per cent of Australians still think Australia will face a military threat over the next 10 years, with Indonesia and the Soviet Union identified as the main likely sources of the threat. Australian National Opinion Polls conducted a poll on 23 January this year which showed that 73 per cent of those polled thought the most likely threat to Australia within the next 10 years would be from terrorism, 48 per cent thought it would come from small-scale raids, 28 per cent from attempted invasion and 20 per cent from nuclear war. Of course, there is no defence whatever against the latter, except to get rid of the weapons which could cause such devastation.

I note, too, that the Minister expressed his disappointment with that poll that showed that 53 per cent of those surveyed still believe that Australia could not defend herself effectively. The same number identified self-reliance within an alliance framework as the main plan for defence at present, while 34 per cent chose primarily reliance on allies, presumably referring to the United States. Clearly the Government needs to continue with public education on this matter in order to sell its own self-reliance program. However, as I have already said, I would prefer it to be outside the alliance framework with the United States, and I believe that is a possibility. Also the Government must learn more about the south-west Pacific. There are indications that that has been happening. As the Minister stated, there have been many changes in the Pacific islands in the last few years. Yet it is still sad that so few Australians can ever identify most of these islands, let alone pronounce their names or know anything about their political systems or their security needs.

My chief concern about his statement is that there is too much stress on military co-operation and no mention of other forms of co-operation, which I believe to be far more important than the sorts of things that the Minister is talking about. I am glad that there is an acknowledgment that South Pacific island countries perceive their security more in economic terms than in military terms. Indeed, the main threat they perceive is from the continued United States and French colonial presence, referred to by the Minister, along with French nuclear testing programs on Mururoa Atoll. Their economies are highly vulnerable. I am therefore puzzled why Australia chooses to increase its military aid to the South Pacific and decrease its economic aid.

We cannot look at this defence statement in isolation from what is happening in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It is sad for many Australians who are particularly concerned about our relationships with our Asian and Pacific neighbours that we are choosing to increase military aid and to decrease economic aid. That is what our neighbours are calling out for more than anything else-their own economic independence and security. I fear that it is largely our obsession with East-West concerns at the expense of North-South perceptions of our island neighbours that results in this happening.

This was clear at the time of the Soviet fishing deal with Kiribati, which Senator Messner has just referred to. These were fishing agreements. They were about the Soviet Union actually paying for the fish it was taking out of those waters instead of, as the American Tuna Boat Association had been doing for years, plundering, in fact stealing, those fish from the territorial waters of the Pacific island states. Kiribati is an island nation very few Australians had even heard of until the Soviets actually offered to pay for the fish they caught there. The American Government realised the damage that was being done to its strategic interests by the poaching of the American Tuna Boat Association and finally brought it into line but, even so, with a very miserly deal. Vanuatu also got a lot of hostility thrown in its direction for wanting to be economically self-sufficient as well as politically non-aligned. The Libyan threat was drummed up to pull Vanuatu into line. Both of these island nations have a population less than half the size of Canberra. There are others even smaller. Mercifully, most of them do not not even have armed forces that we feel we have to co-operate with.

I find it particularly ironic that the patrol boats we are providing are mostly used to chase poaching American trawlers like the Jeanette Diana, which was caught and impounded by the Solomon Islands four years ago, or the one apprehended by Kiribati last year. Perhaps we should use our alleged special relationship with the United States Government to get it to put the economic security concerns of our neighbours above the profits of the American Tuna Boat Association's members and its lobby in Congress.

Looking towards South East Asia, I note that the Minister refers to the developing military sophistication of many of the countries in that region but does not refer to the development of the national security state or the diversion of resources away from the poor into the hands of the military elite in these countries. If any honourable senators have ever visited the slums of Jakarta or Bangkok they might question the need for expensive planes like the F16s from the United States or the massive increase in military expenditure by Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore and Brunei in the last 10 years. Between 1974 and 1983 Malaysia increased its defence expenditure by 159 per cent, while both Thailand and Singapore increased theirs by 145 per cent-enormous increases in military expenditure considering that most of their own people live in poverty stricken conditions. Brunei spent most of all after achieving independence but at least it has its oil wealth to pay for it.

On the subject of South East Asia, I ask honourable senators to consider the plight of the people of Kampuchea, whose country is perhaps the poorest in the world and who are the victims of the East-West stand-off and great power politics when what they desperately need is development aid. Militarisation is a disease that affects both East and West. Both the United States and the Soviet Union, as well as China, bear a heavy responsibility for allowing the situation in Kampuchea to continue. Again, I feel that Australia could play an even more constructive role than the one we are already playing. The Kampuchean people acknowledge the fact that the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, has done a very good job in trying to bring sense into the region, in trying to achieve a non-military solution to the problems of Kampuchea.

If we spent more on training our diplomats in foreign languages and negotiating skills than on buying expensive military hardware from the United States or other countries, we could achieve an even greater reputation as a peace-builder in the region of South East Asia. It is worth noting, while we are looking at figures in this statement, that in 1985 we spent only $21,400 in providing training in negotiating skills for our diplomats. We could spend our money much more constructively on something more positive than more military hardware, whether in terms of defence co-operation or for our own defence forces.

In many of the countries of South East Asia and the South West Pacific region there are growing movements for social justice which are treated as subversive by the elites who use their security apparatus to crush them, as we have seen in Malaysia and Singapore in the last year. This is the national security state. I feel very loath that Australia is providing them with more military assistance, even if it is in training personnel rather than in defence equipment and military hardware because a lot of the training and hardware we are providing is used to oppress the people who are seeking justice in their own countries.

I am also perplexed that Australia is supposed to double its defence exports, as we were told in the Cooksey report which appeared in December 1976 and which has not even been debated in this chamber. Cooksey suggested that we should double our defence exports as a way out of our balance of trade problems, with no questioning on the immorality of providing weapons to our neighbours so that they can oppress their own peoples. We should be moving away from equipment-based programs in South East Asia towards service-to-service training and exchanges of personnel but, even more importantly, considering security in non-military terms.

For me, real security can best be promoted by people-to-people understanding, by increasing our level of economic aid where appropriate, by promoting understanding through cultural exchanges, by increasing the budget for Radio Australia instead of slashing it, and by learning Asian languages instead of European languages in order to promote understanding as well as for promoting business opportunities and for increased regional co-operation at a non-government organisation level rather than at a military level. Australians have a threat paranoia directed towards Asia because for so many years we have refused to acknowledge our real place in the world. Instead we have continued to see ourselves as a distant outpost of Europe and North America.

If we are to spend money on promoting regional security, there are countless better ways to spend $18m in South East Asia, $16m in the South West Pacific and $23m in Papua New Guinea than some of the ways which have been suggested in this statement. We have to stop thinking of security in terms of military security and the East-West framework and realise that what really matters for the vast majority of people in the South West Pacific and South East Asia is economic security and thinking in the North-South framework in terms of development rather than fostering the regional arms race.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating `Self-Reliance and Cooperation: Australia's Regional Defence Policy', a statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). On one more matter we see the Australian Labor Party adopting Liberal-National Party philosophies. Only last week we debated a Bill to convert Australian Airlines to a public company to facilitate its sale so that we can start to engender some competition in Australia's internal airline system, which is a reversal of the Labor position of opposition to this move. When Labor came to power it repealed the Bill which the Liberal Party had put in place in 1981. Now we see-surprise, surprise!-that the Minister for Defence at last has discovered that Australia is not an island unto itself. He has moved on from a Mr Lange position, which he has been happy to embrace for the five years he and his colleagues have been in government, that somehow or other Australia could live in its own little isolationist corner of the world and be quite immune from what was going on around it.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us on this side of the chamber are very grateful that the five years of the xenophobia, the isolationism and the latent pacifism of the Labor Party officially has been turned around. The Labor Party has recognised what we on this side have said all along-that the security of Australia rests with and is inextricably bound up with the peace and security of our neighbouring nations and that their peace and security is our cheapest and best form of defence. We are part of a region and we cannot be excised from it. That carries with it obligations to be conscious of the needs and sensitivities of other nations in the region and to look after their interests as much as we can. All we have seen from this Government is concern for people such as the Vietnamese Government and the Marxist regimes of Africa that have no relevance at all to Australia's direct security and cannot reinforce it in any way. The people who matter in the South Pacific and in the South East Asian area have been scorned and isolated by this Government.

I have read the Minister's speech three times. It is a very poor statement, as Senator Messner said. As soon as one reads it one realises that the Minister is not talking to the Parliament; he is not talking to the Australian people; he is talking to the Australian Labor Party Caucus. That is why it is such an intellectually bankrupt speech. That is why such poor examples are in it: he is trying to convince his colleagues such as Senator Burns and Senator Jones that they really have to change their traditional way of thinking and to see Australia as part of the community of nations in our region. I hope that the changes that we see in the statement are permanent. There is a long way to go, a lot of development to be done, but at least it is a start.

The statement unfortunately starts by quoting the Dibb report. There have been few more unfortunate publications foisted on Australia than the Dibb report. I think it is sad that the Dibb report is resurrected in this way. Outside Australia Dibb is seen as being the official spokesman and reflecting an official Government point of view. The Dibb report is a very inept document. It is very inept from a diplomatic point of view. It takes no cognisance of the sensibilities of our neighbours and of course it is quite juvenile in its military concepts. As I said at the time it was presented, it is an insular, isolationist doctrine. It did enormous damage to Australia's relationships in the South East Asian countries and in the South Pacific because anyone reading the Dibb report saw the strident isolationism. They saw that Australia was not concerned with the fate of Papua New Guinea, Indonesia, South East Asia, Fiji or anywhere else. They saw the doctrine portrayed in the report was of the sea air gap, the moat around Australia, the doctrine of denial and all those other juvenile military concepts which Dibb put forward. Our neighbours found the report very offensive.

The report had a particular impact on Indonesia, our closest neighbour. Those of us who follow Indonesian affairs and who visit that country are conscious of the sensibilities and the need to develop good relations with Indonesia and to maintain them because, like it or not, Australia and Indonesia share the same part of the world: they will never move away. However great are the difficulties between us culturally, economically and on religious and other grounds, we have to get along. I believe we can get along if we put a bit of effort into our relationship with Indonesia and run things in a different way from the way in which we have run them under the Hayden foreign affairs business.

Let me say when talking about Indonesian relationships that I think Australia is extremely fortunate to have the Ambassador we have there at present, who labours under enormous difficulties. The Hon. Bill Morrison ranks with the great ambassadors Australia has sent to Indonesia. I think historically some of our best ambassadors-people such as Tom Critchley, Dick Woolcott, and Mick Shann, to name just a few of them-have been brilliant practitioners of diplomatic skills for this country. I make no qualification to the capabilities of the present ambassador, Ambassador Morrison-I think he is a superb representative for us-but his job is made unnecessarily harder by the insensitivity of the present Government in this country.

One of the themes that emerge from the statement with great emphasis is that somehow or other there is now a self-reliant capability in defence which has been developed by the Labor Party. That is a specious claim. The move towards self-reliance has been a progressive move in the Australian defence posture since the end of the Second World War. The significant turning points for that were the end of the Vietnam War and the Guam doctrine by Nixon. Governments before this Government had embarked on a path of developing self-sufficiency in the Australian Defence Force. It is quite erroneous for the Government to claim credit for this as a policy initiative of its making. That claim is no more true than the claim that it makes that it was the Labor Government under Whitlam that withdrew Australian forces from Vietnam. That decision was made by a Liberal Government about 18 months before the Labor Government came to power.

It has taken a long while for the Labor Party to realise that the environment in which Australia is situated has changed, and changed dramatically. There is no doubt that this realisation is the factor that has led to the publication of the statement today talking about the need for regional support. We have only to look at New Zealand. It has destroyed the ANZUS agreement. It has gone off on its pacifist, isolationist path, which has had a significant impact on its ability to influence affairs in the diplomatic arena in the South Pacific. Somebody mentioned Vanuatu earlier. There are still instability and problems within that country. New Caledonia is still festering about self-government. There was the incident in Fiji last year. This Government had such a poor intelligence service that it not only did not know the first coup was on, it also did not know the second coup was on.

The situation in New Caledonia looks very serious. There is an alliance between some Indonesians and some significant people in the New Guinea Government. I will return to this later. Obviously and demonstrably there has been a marked shift away from the closeness that existed between New Guinea and Australia. In Indonesia we are seeing a slightly different view of Indonesia's position in relation to the region. The way in which it moved with great rapidity to establish a commercial operation in Fiji after the coup showed that the Indonesians see themselves as having a role regionally that formerly was occupied by Australia in the South Pacific. We have the uncertainty of what is going on in the Philippines and the steady growth of the communist New People's Army there. In Malaysia there are religious struggles between the fundamental Muslim groups and the Malay community which do not bode well for stability in that country. Australia is one of the littoral states adjoining the Indian Ocean and we have seen the enormous and unexplained growth of the Indian Navy in recent years, a growth which is moving India into being a major maritime power for no apparent reason.

With all of these changes in the region we have a clear sign that the United States influence, the main peacekeeping military force in the region, is diminishing. With the huge deficits in the United States economy now it simply cannot go on meeting the level of defence expenditure it has met in the past. Furthermore, there has been the resignation of Mr Weinberger, who was very aware of the growth of the Pacific rim countries and the need for a United States presence in the region, and his replacement by Mr Carlucci, who is far more interested in European affairs. One of the consequences which I want to talk about at some other time of the intermediate-range nuclear force agreement between the Soviets and the Americans means that the American focus will be more on Europe than on the Pacific through the next decade. This means that the need for an improved defence capability for Australia and the need for Australia to be able to project power militarily as well as diplomatically through the area is now considerably increased.

The sad thing is that all these things were foreseeable. But the Labor Party is always five to 10 years behind the game. A lot of these things simply cannot be recovered. It does not matter how sincere the recanting of former ideas is, time is lost and human events go on. We must have the capability to project Australian military force around the region to support friendly governments. For example, we could have been asked to go to the aid of Fiji. If the democratically elected government had asked Australia to go there to reinforce its position in a military sense in the face of the coup, we would have been absolutely incapable of doing that. We should have been able to do it, but we advertised to the whole world that we could not do a damned thing about it. There had been such a run down of the Australian defence forces that we could not have met that charge if it had been asked of us. One of the things that it is pleasing to see in the statement is the recognition by the Minister on page 9 of the folly of trying to base a defence posture in this country on threat scenarios, and I hope he takes that to heart and applies it.

The latter part of the statement deals with the need for alliances. I would have liked to have seen more devoted to the ANZUS alliance, which is not mentioned in this statement. It is still fundamentally the most important guarantee of stability, not in terms of Australian security but because the South East Asian nations derive enormous comfort from the fact that Australia and the United States of America are joined in a mutual defence pact. One of the pacts that is mentioned is the Five Power Defence Agreement, which involves Malaysia, Singapore, Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom.

A particular point of reference in the paper is the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) station at Butterworth. The RAAF has maintained a unit at Butterworth. It was formerly of two fighter squadrons and it is now down to one, and in a few months time the remaining squadron is going to be withdrawn. The RAAF has been there since 1971. I argue that the Butterworth involvement has been of enormous value to Australia and that very few people in Australia appreciate the significance of it. I would argue for the retention on a permanent basis as opposed to the rotating system that is being proposed, of at least one squadron at Butterworth. The area is enormously important strategically. Butterworth is very close to the Strait of Malacca, which is probably the busiest waterway in the world. Most of the trade of the developing Pacific rim countries-for Japan, China, Taiwan, Thailand and the Philippines-with Europe comes through that narrow waterway between Sumatra and the Malay Peninsula.

The politics of the region are very complex and Australia's presence there for nearly 20 years, or longer if we go back to the time of the Malay emergency, has been welcomed. Despite what might be thought around the halls of the Australian Labor Party the Australian military commitment in that region would be welcome to stay on. While we stay on there is no problem, but once we pull out it then becomes very difficult for us to go back without being seen as an intruding power going where our business does not necessarily take us. But while we are there we are welcomed. I think we should maintain our presence there. Not only is it an important part of the world in a political sense; it is important militarily. The United States has its major bases in the Philippines, in Subic Bay, but even if it loses those and moves further north and east it will have to transit that area to get to its facilities at Diego Garcia and move into the Persian Gulf if there is ever any need for the Americans to be committed there. The existence of an Australian military unit at Butterworth gives them protection on that flank against possible threat from Soviet intervention. It is also enormously important from an intelligence gathering point of view. All the Soviet traffic that goes into the Indian Ocean, coming out of its Pacific ports, passes through an area where it can be surveilled from Butterworth.

Most importantly-I come to the psychological element-is the fact that Australia is prepared to put its money where its mouth is. Putting several hundred service men and women in an area to live with the Malaysians in the South East Asian community has enormous benefits to us when we look at the Five Power Defence Agreement. They can see the tangible effect of these policies when we actually go and live with them, and that cannot be underestimated.

I cannot understand why the Minister argues for the FA18 aircraft not to be based there. He very correctly makes the point that these aircraft can be supported and have far lower maintenance requirements in the field than any other type of aircraft we have ever operated. That is perfectly true. That is one of the reasons we bought them. They are able to operate away from bases, to operate really from a bare base concept-just pump fuel into them and re-arm them and there is a very long time between servicing checks. That being so, there is no reason why a squadron-it need not be a full strength squadron of 18 aircraft; it could be a reduced squadron of 12-could not be based there permanently. It could be supported quite readily from the central maintenance facilities that have been established at Williamtown. Perversely, the Minister says that we cannot do that. If he is correct we are never going to be able to use those aircraft in a wartime situation when they will be deployed around Western Australia or the coast of the Northern Territory or somewhere around the Pacific region or the South East Asian area. If we cannot support them in peacetime, we are not going to be able to support them in time of an emergency. The argument simply will not stand up. The aircraft could be supported there, and I believe we should do that.

One of the saddest parts of the statement is the neglect of the South Pacific area, which the statement tries to correct. Militarily and diplomatically we have neglected the South Pacific region because somehow or other it did not fit in with the great Marxist dream of the world community of nations that Mr Hayden had. He is far more ready to go to Vietnam and tell the people there how to solve their problems with Kampuchea, and enrage countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, than he is to look after the people like the Fijians or those on Kiribati. Nothing more dramatically demonstrates this inability to see our priorities correctly than the way he treats Papua New Guinea. Papua New Guinea has turned to the United States Army for training, and that would have been inconceivable 12 months ago. No-one would have believed that Papua New Guinea would have done that. It is against the whole tradition of the Pacific Islands Regiment, officered and trained by Australians since its inception, and the legacy of the Second World War, when the New Guinea troops were fighting alongside and in Australian units and acted as guides and supported them. We have had that close association for decades, and we now find that the Papua New Guinea Government has turned, as a matter of choice, to the United States Army for some help and advice.

We had the mix-up with Indonesia, where General Murdani came in and gave a huge donation to Brigadier Ted Diro. It was an even bigger donation than the donation given to Mr Mick Young. It was absolutely staggering. There is no way that General Murdani gave that donation to Brigadier Ted Diro without knowing that it was to buy influence in a political sense, and there is no way that Diro accepted it without knowing the political implications of taking such a huge donation. The former Chief of the Defence Force, Brigadier Huai, was dismissed because he leaked in advance the agreement between Australia and Papua New Guinea on the defence alliance we have with Papua New Guinea. We see the intrusion of Indonesian power politics from the Indonesian military machine quite strongly in Papua New Guinea, and we see that only because Australia's influence now in Papua New Guinea is moving to a position of being of very little importance. That is a consequence of the policies of this Government.

One of the things that have turned the New Guinea Government against us is the thoughtless way in which we have cut aid. We did say that we would reduce the aid program, but some of the things we have done to New Guinea have been done without any warning. We have chopped millions off grants to it. Naturally, it feels a bit friendless, disappointed and disillusioned. At the same time, as Senator Messner said, Mr Hayden is running around all of those tin-pot Marxist regimes in southern Africa giving away up to $100m for people who simply have no--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are you talking about? What are these tin-pot regimes?

—Look at the editorial in the Australian of Tuesday, 9 February, headed `Question over aid to Mozambique'. I am sorry that Senator Ray started me on this topic because he will get a lecture. The editorial reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision of the Australian Government to promise $6 million worth of aid to Mozambique was insupportable from the very beginning.

It talks about the failings of that Mozambique regime and the way in which it has no relevance to Australia. That is perfectly correct. Our responsibilities lie in the South Pacific and in the region to our north and west. If we are to give money away, let us give it to countries such as the Philippines and to the Philippines Army. Before the Left starts to fly up in high dudgeon about this, let me say that the only way in which the communists will be prevented from taking over in the Philippines is for the Philippines to have an effective army. There is a legitimate argument under the defence co-operation program for payment to be made to the Philippines so that its army capability can be improved, however much it offends the far left of the Australian Labor Party.

This paper, which comprises 31 pages, says very little except that the region around us is important and the security of that region is important. The great deficiency of the paper is that there is no tangible support for the development of regional alliances and regional military capability. There is this delightful passage towards the end of the paper where the Minister says something about sovereignty.
. . . in co-operation with New Zealand, an integrated approach to helping the island states to exercise the most fundamental element of nationhood-sovereign control of their lands and waters.

He is talking about the patrol boat program. Talk of sovereign control of the land and waters is very fine. That is perfectly true, but we certainly do not have sovereign control over our own land and waters because this Government does not spend enough money on defence, while it is spending so much on capital equipment. This is not an act of free choice by the Government; it is a consequence of the contractual situation that it inherited. By freezing the defence budget, the percentage of money devoted to capital equipment has gone up from about 17 per cent at the start of this decade to a figure now in excess of 27 per cent. This means that the money devoted for the conditions of service of Australian service men and women has been cut back so that we now have a great crisis with the greatest level of resignations that this country has ever seen. We have lost the ability to provide for our own defence and to have sovereign control of lands and water. We simply do not know what is going on around the northern part of Australia. Not only have we lost this ability now, but we have lost the capability for a generation. We have lost those experienced people who have served for 10 years or more in the Service in the various specialities-on the sea, in the air and on the land. There is no way that we can recover from that in the short term. That is the fallacy of this whole paper.

While we are talking at last about the need to support the region we find that our own military position is one of bankruptcy. There is no recovery from it in the short term. It will take at least 10 years of hard work to get back to the capability that we should have today. We must have more money. The defence vote is clearly inadequate. All we get from Mr Beazley is a hand-wringing exercise. He says, quite incorrectly, that a Liberal government would not increase the defence vote. He said that no government that came to power in this country would be prepared to put more into defence. That is not true and there is no way that he can prove it is true. We need to increase the defence vote if we are to look after the responsibilities that the Government has to this country and the region. But in so far as this paper shows a recognition that the defence of Australia does not start with barbed wire on Bathurst Island-the way that Mr Dibb saw it-in so far as the Government is starting to see the need for decent relationships with our neighbours, in so far as it is seeing the need to support them, to help them and to work with them for common goals, then this report has something going for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon referred to the fact that this ministerial statement did not refer to ANZUS. The fact that this statement does not refer to ANZUS by name does not mean that ANZUS is not writ large throughout the pages of this report. It is a shame that the report does not deal directly with ANZUS in terms of our obligations to our allies and how they interact with our obligations to our regional neighbours. In fact, throughout the statement these two separate terms are referred to. It refers to regional and other defence partners, as opposed to our alliances. It is quite clear that what we feel about our alliances is different from what we feel about our regional associations. This is the part of the statement that I would like to look at now, because it is important, when we are talking about security in the region, that we understand for whom the security is meant. Whom are we securing and for whom are we securing them?

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that if we look at neighbouring countries in our region, we find that we have done very little to prevent the lessening of their sovereignty and the worsening of their economic and political circumstances. Belau continues to be bullied by the United States, the French still carry out their imperialist games in New Caledonia, the coup in Fiji is denying democracy to the people of Fiji, and so on. There is a lessening of security for smaller countries within the region, despite talk about developing the ability to maintain regional security. For example, New Zealand has been accused by Senator MacGibbon and others of destroying ANZUS. Of course, New Zealand did not destroy ANZUS. New Zealand merely said that it would not have nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered warships in its harbours. The United States and Australia decided that that was enough to kick New Zealand out of ANZUS. Prime Minister Lange stated repeatedly that he believed in ANZUS, he wanted New Zealand to remain within ANZUS. The other ANZUS partners decided that the prohibition on nuclear-armed and powered warships was enough to throw New Zealand out of ANZUS.

What were Australia's responsibilities in that situation? New Zealand is a neighbour and a close partner, economically, in the region. Why did Australia participate in the bullying of New Zealand over its anti-nuclear decision and do the job for the United States of trying to talk Lange out of that decision of his Government? It was because the primary and most important part of our defence arrangements is our alliance with the United States. Senator Collins has said at another time that he supports the alliance, and I suggest that, if the Government believes that its alliance with the United States is the important factor in its defence arrangements, that is fine. I may not agree with it, but it is fair enough for a government to decide with whom it will be allied. If the primary alliance is with the United States, that should have been canvassed in the statement. There may be a conflict over Fijian interests, for example, or a conflict because of our support for and regional association with some South West Pacific nations. If there is a conflict between their interests and our interests in terms of our alliance with the United States, just which way will Australia move? Will it move in the direction of maintaining and protecting our alliance with the United States, or will it see its role in the region, its regional responsibilities, as paramount? Will it support our neighbours in such a conflict of interests?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is predicated on the belief that we have a master-servant relationship with the US. It is not. It is a partnership.

—If I might digress for a moment to respond to Senator Ray's interjection, I do not believe that we have a master-servant relationship with the United States in that sense. I do not believe that the Pentagon pulls the strings and Bob Hawke jumps, but I believe that there is a partnership in the sense of two friends walking down the same road together, because Australia has chosen to walk down a particular road with the United States. Nevertheless I do believe that, although a friend, the United States is bigger and more powerful, and can be very persuasive. Should Australia decide that it wants to walk down a different road, I am pretty sure that then we would see Australia pulled sharply back into line. I am not suggesting that at this stage the Hawke Government is a puppet regime of Washington, but I am suggesting that, were any Australian Government to decide to walk down a different road, we would soon see just how independent we were able to be.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with walking down the same road with the United States is the very problem I have just outlined. The United States is not the only other player in the game. The United States is not our only friend. Other nations in our region look to Australia for support. When these countries look to us for support and there is a conflict of interest concerning whom we should support, the question I ask is: What do we do then? Do we support the United States and its intentions or do we support our neighbours in the region? It seems to me that until now we have always gone the way of supporting our big brother or big friend or however one wants to characterise our relationship with the United States.

The other problem with the statement, as I see it, is that it is preoccupied-as indeed most of our defence arrangements are-with capital equipment programs. It seems to suggest that peace and security is the same as a military stand-off. In my view, security is not a military state; it is being secure from hunger, secure from economic exploitation, secure from political oppression and secure from environmental holocaust. There is no point in living in an armed camp and being secure from invasion if we are visited by plague, pestilence and political oppression within our country. That is no security at all. If we truly believe in security within the region, not only should we be talking about defence arrangements but also we should be saying to our friends and neighbours that we will support them economically, we will support them socially and we will support them culturally. Senator Vallentine outlined a range of options, including cultural exchanges, economic co-operation and those other aspects of our relationships with our neighbours, which seem to have been forgotten.

If the only relationships we maintain with our neighbours are military ones, alliances, we cannot blame our neighbours if they decide that someone else is militarily more capable of defending them. Of course we did that with Great Britain. Great Britain was our great friend and protector for a long while, and then we decided that the United States was the better option.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sent us some of our best citizens, didn't it?

—It did. We chose to rely on one military force as opposed to another because we felt that in the South Pacific region the United States was capable of defending us more easily. So it should be no surprise if our neighbours make such a decision too. If our only relationship is a military one and our only co-operative ventures concern defence, we cannot expect anything else. It seems to me that the security of our region would be best brought about by the development and the maintenance and security of democracy in the region. It is hypocritical to talk about maintaining security in the region and yet allow elected governments to fall, allow small countries to be bullied by larger countries outside the region and contribute to the grand superpower strategies which are leading to the sorts of economic exploitation and political oppression that we see. I agree with Senator MacGibbon on one point--
—Say it slowly.

—I hope the honourable senator does not have a heart attack. Senator MacGibbon said that peace and security is the best form of defence. I would say three cheers to that if what he meant by peace and security was all of the things that I have mentioned-that it did not involve military options, that it meant being secure in the knowledge that people would be fed, secure in the knowledge that there would be a roof over one's head, secure in the knowledge that there would be education for one's children, secure in the knowledge that we would not be economically exploited and secure in the knowledge that it was not all going to be blown away in a nuclear or environmental holocaust. But it seems that this statement talks about regional security in the sense of securing the region for the Western alliance, making sure that none of the countries in the region fall to the dreaded prospect of independent foreign policies. Heaven forbid that they might be anti-nuclear as well!

SPEECH.PARA: This report fails in many aspects. One is that it does not talk about the region in terms of a region that we belong to; it talks about a region that exists around us somehow, somehow separate from us but around us and close to us so we have to take notice of it and do something about it because it is there. But it does not place us in the region as part of it. Once we begin to see ourselves as being part of the region and equal with the people in the region, the less we will succumb to the temptation for us to take over the imperialistic role that is gradually being ceded by the United States. The United States empire is waning. There will be a vacuum in the south-west Pacific to our north. It seems to me that the defence arrangements we are coming into are securing our place in the future as the regional superpower which will become the protector and exploiter of the region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now considering a ministerial paper tabled a couple of hours ago under the title of `Self-Reliance and Co-operation: Australia's Regional Defence Policy'. It has variously been described as a twaddle, emanating from cloud-cuckoo-land and other fairly vague criticisms. I can identify with those vague criticisms but, nevertheless, I would like to be a bit more specific. I would like to address some comments not only to the content of the statement but also to the process by which we received it and the circumstances under which we are now considering it.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not expect the parliamentary process to be perfect. We all accept its imperfections. We are certainly witnessing one here this afternoon; the fact that in one chamber a Minister can read a statement for 45 minutes and in the other chamber, with relatively little warning, it is tabled. We have had it for a couple of hours. We did not know we were going to get it.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there are no speakers on the Government side.

—And there is nobody excepting the duty Minister and the Acting Whip on the Government side of the House. It is an incredibly imperfect process and we should feel an obligation to tell the people that not only is the content ineffective and inadequate but also the process by which we were presented with it is appalling. I am fascinated by the contradictions in terms of Australia's defence that I find in reading the statement, between the statement and the realities of what is out there. A long time ago I reached the conclusion that politicians quite clearly should not be the formulators of defence policy. I am still at a loss to know who should be but this process and this product today certainly reinforce my earlier assessment that it should not be politicians-and, above all, it should not be the Government of today. Let us turn to what the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has told us in this statement.
—Who the hell else is going to do it?

—I am at a loss to answer that. The evidence before us here certainly suggests that it is not being done very adequately by the government of the day. Let us turn to the key document, the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities.
—You don't want to leave it to the generals, do you?

—I am going to offer some comments about that at the end of my statement. The Dibb report is cited as being a very constructive document which has stimulated great discussion throughout Australia. The discussion about Australia's defence emanating from the Dibb report has been deafening. I saw three or four attempts at public forums. I do not believe there has been the slightest real discussion emanating from the Dibb report.

SPEECH.PARA: I make some observations about the Dibb report and this document before us today. They are based essentially on very conventional thinking about defence. We have been locked and continue to remain locked into defence models which, naturally and reasonably, are historical. But they do not have to be totally historical or continue to reflect excessively the models of World War I, World War II, Vietnam and so on. They do not reflect any dynamic lateral thinking. I cite what I mean by lateral thinking and the lack of it by taking one specific and one more general example.

Recently we have seen the extraordinary situation in which the surveillance of our north coast, which honourable senators would agree is not irrelevant to the defence of our country, was almost handed over to a private enterprise company that was incapable of getting three aircraft into the air on the day it was asked to achieve this. As a result of this embarrassment the question has been shuffled off to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. Senator Coulter and I have made a submission to that committee, which we would consider to be at least lateral in its proposition-a bit imaginative. We have proposed that the purchase of 20 aircraft of Canadian make, the CL215, which is an amphibious aircraft, would be a very positive, constructive and imaginative approach to the surveillance of our coast in that it would give a capacity not only to carry out surveillance but to intercept and take constructive action. That is an example of the specifics of what we mean by lateral thinking.

I would like to take a broader example of what we mean by lateral thinking about defence, what we mean by putting behind us the models of World War I, World War II and Vietnam, and thinking in terms of models which address the defence challenges of the next three, four and five decades. I will quote from the preface to a report of the World Commission on Environment and Development, which makes a pertinent observation which I will link in a moment to defence. In its opening paragraph, it makes this observation:

Most of today's decision makers will be dead before the planet suffers the full consequences of acid rain, global warming, ozone depletion, widespread, desertification, and species loss. Most of today's young voters will be alive.

In that group of decision makers that presumably the Commission is referring to are people such as our Defence Minister, who is pitching his level of analysis in time frames which suit his political party and the aspirations of government-time frames of three months or three years. This Commission is addressing the much more demanding time frames of three, four and five decades. This ministerial statement is grossly inadequate because it does not address time frames beyond months-at most, several years. In other words, it is lacking in imagination. We do not deny, fail to accept or reject obvious statements of our need to be self-reliant. Of course we need to be self-reliant. We admire the positive thinking on page 5 of the ministerial statement. I ask how this is for a bit of positive thinking:
As a result of the Dibb report, this ministerial statement and this Government's progressive defence policy, the Minister stated:
With careful planning Australia can now maintain a Defence Force which can both defend our territories and approaches, and contribute to the security of our broader region.

Australia no longer needs to make a choice between self-reliance on the one hand and our network of alliances and regional associations on the other. We have the capacity-and indeed the requirement-to do both.

I think that is probably what Senator Messner was referring to when he said that this was twaddle. It is certainly what I am referring to when I am drawing the comparison between a statement like that and the realities of what we have on the ground now in terms of defence capacity. I hope that at least some honourable senators have read the article by Commodore Alan Robertson in the latest issue of the Pacific Defence Reporter. Commodore Robertson is a recently retired senior naval planning strategist and he describes our defence capacity as being absolutely and utterly impotent, laughable and a national disgrace. This is from somebody who recently vacated a career where he was able to observe at first hand and was frustrated by the policies of government after government.

I am sure that honourable senators would have noticed and observed the statements in the media recently of Air Chief Marshal Evans, who made the observation that we are not capable of determining whether aircraft are crossing our northern coastlines and, if so, what they are or what they are here for. Recently retired Air Chief Marshal Evans made that statement. Honourable senators may be aware that recently retired Rear Admiral Guy Griffiths is now deliberately seeking opportunities to be a guest speaker and divulge to more and more Australians the utter incapacity of our defence forces.

Honourable senators are probably aware that today at the Canberra College of Advanced Education there is a seminar being attended by eminent ex-servicemen, present serving officers and distinguished veterans who are investigating, enunciating and exploring the extraordinary dimension of the wastage from our defence forces and why it is occurring. Honourable senators are probably aware that right now a committee of this Senate is exploring exactly the same questions because we are in crisis in terms of our defence.

Our Defence Force is in tatters. It was described by Senator MacGibbon several weeks ago as a Defence Force which is incapable of defending Bondi Beach on Saturday afternoon. I got up and qualified that and said, `Perhaps that might be excessive', but certainly our present commanders have said in the light of recent military exercises that our Defence Force is incapable of defending a major metropolitan centre against sustained conventional attack. In fact, it is not defence against sustained conventional attack that we really should be addressing ourselves to. What I am citing is the extraordinary contradiction between the statements and propositions inherent in this ministerial statement and the realities of what is out there and being explored today by seminars and standing committees. The public must become aware of the fact that we are in crisis.

This ministerial statement is a snow job. It sits alongside the Dibb report as part of a process of depriving the Australian people of the realities about the inadequacies of our defence. It talks about playing a leading role in the strategic defence of our area. Playing a leading role is a function of credibility. If we have an incredibly demoralised and impotent Defence Force, how on earth can we play a credible leading role in the regional defence strategies of the South Pacific? It is a laughable proposition. I have cited the statements by Commodore Alan Robertson, Air Chief Marshal Evans and Rear Admiral Guy Griffiths.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Colonel Blimp.

—No, I have not cited Colonel Blimp. I have cited people who have recently served in this Defence Force and who are totally aware of what a disgraceful situation the present government and previous governments have allowed it to deteriorate to.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Senator Wood addressed quite reasonably, as did Senator MacGibbon, the proposition that our greatest assurance of security is to further the peace ethos and that we should identify with the peace ethos. We should not become without vigilance-of course not; but we should identify with the ethos. We should promote the ethos through constructive foreign and aid policies. As we do so we engender the security of our region by raising our credibility, instead of saying that we have a credible Defence Force. That is ludicrous.

We read about rotational deployments of what we have got-rotational deployments of our FA18s and rotational deployments of our inadequate naval defences. Rotational deployments have caused the state of morale in our defence forces over a period of 2 1/2 decades--

TALK.START.PARA: —Musical chairs.

—Musical chairs. Give them all an overseas posting; placate them with a few extra allowances; dislocate their kids so that after they had served for 20 years in the defence forces, been to Malaysia three times and had their kids in 15 schools they can walk away demoralised and then probably have to suffer a 2 per cent reduction in their Defence Force retirement benefits payments as a result of having given 20 years of their lives.

SPEECH.PARA: This ministerial statement denies the realities. It is not the truth. It is dishonest. What is more, it has been delivered to us in a manner which denies constructive, real debate in the community. It is a part of the ongoing disguise. It is a part of the pretence. We must raise this issue of defence, civil and military, to become a major issue on the political agenda. If we cannot achieve that it will continue to languish and deserves to continue to languish.

I recall a statement by Jim Cairns at the time I was a university student when he propounded a thesis about spheres of influence. He said that it was folly for us to go onto the mainland of South East Asia because in the long term the spheres of influence would prevail, that this part of the area fell within the sphere of influence of China and in the ultimate, the end reality, that would be the outcome of all the military and aid tragedies and the other dimensions of what proved to be a farce. That is what I mean by a bit of lateral thinking. If we had accepted that proposition 20 years ago, I frankly do not believe that the yellow hordes would have rolled over this nation. I think that perhaps we would have been able to address our defence much more rationally and much more realistically.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not rolled over it.

—Of course they have not. The fact is that if the bomb goes up-I mean the big one-what we will need most in this nation is a civil defence organisation, which is something we have not got and something we have never truly addressed ourselves to. By lateral thinking I mean that this Government-and this Opposition if it becomes the government-has to be prepared.
—Identify the threat.

—There isn't one. Can't the honourable senator hear what I am saying? In fact, there isn't one and, therefore, a much more rational approach to defence would be to attend to needs which in fact do not see us fighting our bushfires, maintaining our coastal patrols and funding our state emergency services by selling lamingtons and jams on street corners while we spend $7.6 billion a year on a Defence Force which is impotent, demoralised and propped up by papers such as the one we are asked to address ourselves seriously to today.
—I would not want to be defended by the Democrats.
—The honourable senator will not have to be. The Government will have to construct its own rational, sensible defence organisation.
—You will never be in government.
—I do not think we will be in government in the foreseeable future, but at least I am here trying to make a constructive suggestion to somebody who is in government.
—There is not one of them doing it. There is not one Labor speaker.

—Of course there is not. They are not even here to enter into the debate. They are not debating it in their Caucus; they are sitting back and being fed on this sort of rubbish. That is exactly what is happening with the defence of this nation.
—Are you the MacGibbon Democrat?

—The Minister is just sitting there shooting off meaningless statements. He sits and concentrates for three or four minutes with all his intellectual energy, and then he blurts out one of these utterly meaningless gems.
—Three or four minutes of intellectual energy is all he can exert.

—I could not agree more. Earlier I suggested it might be feasible to put together think-tanks which at least are objective, think-tanks which are experienced, think-tanks which do not have vested interests like politicians and governments grasping onto power.
—What do you want-another coup?

—No, I am saying that Air Chief Marshal Evans, now he is out, and others who were in my office the other day described themselves during their period of service as being basically unionists who had to defend their own self-interest. When they sat down around a table, when they made submissions to Cabinet, it was all about defending the structure of their own services; it was all about getting a few bucks in the defence allocation. Now that they are out, now that they have the insight from having sat around those tables, perhaps people like Air Chief Marshal Evans, Rear Admiral Guy Griffiths-and I am not mentioning Colonel Blimp-and people like Commodore Alan Robertson, and many many others, might be able to spell out, as they are now doing, to the Australian people what the realities are.

SPEECH.PARA: As a matter of fact, Rear Admiral Griffiths has produced an excellent paper. I do not know if honourable senators have seen it. He is now going around the country delivering it, and it makes a damn sight more sense than the one the Minister for Home Affairs has tabled here today. At least Rear Admiral Griffiths starts off by considering realistically what the major strategic factors are. He said there are at least four major strategic factors around which we should build our defence strategy, and he refers to it, of course, quite critically, as being a strategy of deterrence. That is what the name of the game is in defence: it is to deter; it is to avoid; it is to prevent involvement. It is not getting involved that we have to concentrate our strategies on.

Rear Admiral Griffiths cites these as the critical fundamental strategic factors; first of all-and, of course, there is nothing new about this-we are, first and foremost, an island; secondly, we are rich in resources, but not self-sufficient. Thirdly, Australia is vitally dependent upon trade for both exports and imports and for overall national development. We are near neighbour to over half of the world's population; and, lastly, we are surrounded by a vast maritime area. Those factors in fact seem obvious, but they are the premises from which we have to proceed to build a strategy of deterrence. Rear Admiral Griffiths then says that the next thing we have to do to identify what are our national interests, not some imagined national interests but what are really the national interests. First and foremost is the security of the population and the services and industries in this country; secondly, the security of our offshore resources; thirdly, the security of our outlying territories; and, lastly, the security of our seaborne trade. He cites these four as our major national interests.

From these he defines a number of quite simple objectives from which things will logically begin to flow, not from the models of World War I, World War II, Vietnam, but from a logically reasoned out argument which progresses to what should be the clear definable objectives of a strategy of deterrence. The first objective should be to maintain our regional stability; secondly, to influence and control developments in our area, to control what is happening in our area; thirdly, to deter the development of adverse influences; fourthly, to prevent an attack on our vital sea transport and on Australia; and, lastly, to support alliances which contribute to our national and regional security. As Senator Wood earlier cited, that last objective has become the first objective of the last two governments that have formulated the defence policies that now see us to be in the straits in which we find ourselves.

So what I am really saying is that we have an antiquated mentality; we have the wrong people being listened to in terms of formulation of defence policy; we have a lack of lateral thinking; we are ignoring the broader global dimensions of defence; and we are still seeing it in terms of rifles, ships, trucks and helicopters. But, in fact, it may be much broader things than that. I quote once again from the report of the World Commission on Environment and Development an interesting observation. Page 7 in the preface states:

The recent destruction of much of Africa's dryland agricultural production was more severe than if an invading army had pursued a scorched-earth policy. Yet most of the affected governments still spend far more to protect their people from invading armies than from the invading desert.

We are locked into mentalities about what is defence and what is the future, and how we should expend dollars in our own defence; we cannot see what is right before our very eyes, that it is issues of peace, security, development and environment that are all locked together. This shallow ministerial statement, together with the conventional thinking of the Dibb report, is not going to move us forward one jot. Unless we get people of more imagination than we are witnessing from the present Government-and they may be sitting on the Opposition benches; I trust to heaven they are-we are going to find ourselves utterly defenceless. We are almost there now. As somebody said to me-and it was a statement that got me into politics-when it comes to government we get what we deserve. We deserve what we get. The better the democracy we live in, the truer that observation is. We are finding ourselves with governments that are expecting us to accept the tripe that is trotted up today as a ministerial statement. It simply stands in stark contradiction with what is out there. We are almost defenceless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating this lightweight statement from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) entitled `Self-Reliance and Co-operation' and subtitled `Australia's Regional Defence Policy'. I have listened with interest to this debate. The previous two speakers have had something to say that was worth hearing, although I cannot go along with everything they said. I agree with them when they say that the Government has produced a document which we would hardly need to spend any time considering if it were not for the seriousness of its subject matter. The coalition parties believe in peace through security. Obviously we shall have to send Senator Wood a copy of our policy to show him how we believe that peace through security can be achieved. It is interesting to listen to the yapping that has been coming from the new Minister for something or other on the front bench. He has been left minding the shop for the moment, but I do not think the boy will be left doing that much more often.
—He is the Minister in favour of uranium these days.

—He is the Minister in favour of uranium? What is his name? Is it Senator Cook? I think that is his name. The Minister who at present is representing the Government in the chamber has been yapping about threats for some time, and a pretty ignorant sort of yap it has been, too. He asked Senator McLean to identify the threat. If anything shows up the Minister's ignorance, it is his yapping about identifying the threat. I wonder whether honourable senators on the Government side bother to insure their houses. I presume that they cannot identify where the threat to their houses from fire will come from, but I presume that they take due precautions against such an occurrence. I presume that they insure their houses. I presume that they cut any long grass and other vegetation away from their houses. I presume that they would remove any inflammatory material that might be stored near their houses. They may not know where the threat is coming from but they protect themselves against it. And so should Australia and this Government defend this country against any threat. It does not have to be an identifiable threat. A responsible government will defend its citizens. That is why it is so sad to look at this so-called statement from a Minister who has a reputation-I do not know that I should say whether it is deserved or underserved-for having some intellectual capacity.
