As far as I can see, this statement is a rehash of the Minister's Press statements over the last six months. Perhaps it is meant to be some sort of justification for this South Sea frolic. However, it is sad that he says this in the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the same capabilities that we are developing for the defence of Australia are well suited to co-operation with our regional and other defence partners.

What capabilities? The fact is that Australia's capability is severely limited. At last Australians are starting to be aware of this. They are waking up to the fact that this Government is leaving them defenceless. Our insurance policy in the hands of this Government has been squandered. I think it has run off to the casino with it. The squandering of that insurance policy has been brought about largely by government decisions and priorities. It is not just a question of inaction. The Government has embarked upon a deliberate policy to change the balance in our Federal Budget so that defence does not receive a proper share of the total budget; and there has been a misallocation of resources within the defence vote.

I have no quibble with the essence of the Minister's statement. It regurgitates the announcements that the Minister has been making over the last few months. I simply draw attention to some of those announcements. They include such matters as the formal arrangement with Papua New Guinea, the Pacific patrol boat program, regional maritime surveillance and co-operation, the presence of a major combatant in South East Asian waters, joint training and exercises, civil engineering projects, assistance with communications and aid in civil emergencies. We do not oppose those things but we do not think they go anything like far enough. The statement is full of good intentions. Really it is not up to scratch. The proposal for rotational deployment of FA18 and PC3 aircraft to Malaysia and Singapore is really a case of musical chairs. We need to have in those countries a permanent establishment, as we have had in the past. I think my colleague Senator MacGibbon said earlier that it had been a great thing for our working relationship with our neighbours that so many servicemen had worked with them on a daily basis and had not just flown in and flown out. We were not a now-you-see-us, now-you-don't kind of defence force.

What is set out in the statement are just good intentions; they are not hard commitments. Last year when I was in Singapore I had some briefings on the subject of our five power defence arrangements, and I had briefings on foreign affairs and defence matters generally. I must say that I was terribly disheartened to observe the real lack of interest that that country had in things Australian generally and the irrelevance with which we as a nation are treated in that part of the world. I know that that attitude is not unique to Singapore, but it is something about which we should be desperately concerned. We should be doing something much more meaningful to redress and turn around that attitude.

These token measures, these peanuts if you like, that are being scattered around the Pacific and South East Asia are all the more obscene when it is realised, as some of my colleagues have already said, how much money this Government seems to be able to produce out of its pockets when it is to be scattered around to its left wing friends in Africa. We are to spend $100m in that region, but we cannot find money to defend this country or to enable us to work properly in defence co-operation and civil aid co-operation with our neighbours. We need to implement more substantial measures than those outlined in this thick but thin paper-thick in terms of the number of pages but thin in terms of substance.

We could put forward many suggestions about ways in which we could co-operate with our neighbours. Some of those matters have already been canvassed by some honourable senators who have already spoken in this debate. I think it is of critical importance to provide civil assistance. It is one of those goodwill means by which we can help people in the way in which they particularly need assistance in their own community. We do not have to provide straight-out defence aid in order to contribute to the peace and security of our region. We have within our defence forces many skilled personnel who could be put to good use in providing civil aid to our neighbours. Not nearly enough is being done in that area. The provision of such aid is good for our neighbours and it is equally good for the training of our own personnel. It provides them with skills and gives them practice in the sorts of jobs that often they will be expected to do in wartime but which have a distinctly useful application in peacetime.

We do not train in this country nearly enough of our neighbours. We should be much more generous in bringing students to this country for training, as well as people who need defence skills. We have engaged in a lot of that activity in the past. I do not think we are doing nearly enough now. In fact, when I was in Singapore this is one of the matters that was discussed. Once more we are seen as being irrelevant. We are not providing the form of military training that some of those countries finds relevant to their purposes. For goodness sake, they are going to Britain and America for that training rather than their neighbouring country, Australia. What a commentary that is on what they perceive they can get from our training. Equally, many more training opportunities should be provided for Australian defence personnel in our neighbouring countries. There has been a decline in the level of our co-operative defence activities with Indonesia. The Minister admits that himself. Fortunately he says that he is a little sorry about it. But if he were sorry about it I would hope that he would be doing something about it. Much more attention should be given to such activities and there should be a more meaningful co- operative involvement in such activities.

I welcome the Minister's comment in the statement about combined exercises with the Thai forces. That is the sort of activity in which we could be constantly engaging with our neighbours. It would be good for all of us. It is not just a question of refining defence skills; it is a question of trusting each other and learning to work together. I believe that there cannot be too much of that. Much more could be made of the five power defence arrangements if we showed ourselves willing. It seems that we are not really trusted by our neighbours in those arrangements. They consider that they do not need to do much more than give them occasional formal recognition. The arrangements do not have life and breath in them. We need to get a little fire into those arrangements so that they mean more to us and more to our neighbours.

I very much regret that we do not have more land forces in Malaysia. On the same basis that we should have permanent Air Force units there we should also have more substantial land forces there, once again for the variety of training it offers our troops and also for the co-operative effort and trust that develop with the defence personnel in those countries where often to be a stranger is to be suspect. We are the same in this country. Most people in any country are suspicious of strangers. One of the best ways to break down suspicion is to get to know each other by working together. It contributes to regional security.

The Minister, in this statement, recommends the deployment of patrol boats to Manus for extended periods. That is the sort of thing we could be doing much more of. I cannot quite understand what the Minister is getting at on page 18 when he talks about the provision of a continuous presence of a major combatant of the Australian Navy in South East Asian waters. He says that while there the Australian ships will train and exercise with regional navies to the benefit of both. When I first read this I thought, `My goodness, maybe the Minister is getting a bit imaginative. Maybe he is talking about establishing a fleet in being in the region whereby the small navies of the region'-and I count us in that-`could all contribute some ships to peacekeeping duties in the oceans of our region'. But I suspect that that is not what the Minister had in mind. He perhaps would have been more specific if that is what he had intended.

There is some virtue, however, in considering such a fleet. Once more it is a question of practising together on a constant and regular basis. We have continuing increases in the Soviet presence in both the Indian and Pacific oceans. The Indian Navy is being built up largely at the cost of the Soviets and is certainly being established with Soviet-built vessels. Jane's Fighting Ships, for example, has recently said, `Why is this so? There is no good reason for an increase in the Indian fleet in the Indian Ocean to such an extent'. Such developments add to tension in the region. A fleet in being, composed of contributions from regional navies, could well be a stabilising influence in our region.

Let it not be thought that, by not mentioning it in any detail, I do not believe that our alliances with our immediate neighbours and our larger friends are not vitally important. They are. But I believe that we should not be so dependent upon them that we do not pay more attention, firstly, to being self-reliant and, secondly, to co-operating meaningfully in our region. It is not enough to visit the South Pacific Islands talking about co-operation. We need to be seen to be capable of defending ourselves against the low level threats we are most likely to face in the foreseeable future otherwise we do not have a hope of being taken seriously and considered as a responsible neighbour by our own neighbours. They are not taking us seriously because they can see that we do not have these capabilities. The Minister makes much of our ability not only to defend ourselves but also to give meaningful defence co-operation in the region. We do not have the capacity to defend ourselves effectively, which must affect our ability to co-operate in a defence forum in the region. We are currently demonstrating the very opposite of what the Minister said. He said:

With careful planning, Australia can now maintain a defence force which can both defend our territories and approaches, and contribute to the security of our broader region ellipsis. We have the capacity-and indeed the requirement-to do both.
We certainly have the requirement to do both; we do not have the capacity to do both. It is to the Government's shame that, after all this time in office, we do not have the capacity to do both.

I now want to raise the problem areas that relate to our lack of capacity. They need to be well understood and clearly spelt out. Firstly, I would like to draw attention to the ability of others to intrude into our waters. What sort of an impression do we give when six fishing boats can be off our shores for days, when one can get away and others can be deep into our creeks before they are caught?

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't know how many were there.

—No, they do not. That is the worry. To think that we, a country that should be able to defend its own shores, does not even know how many trochus fishermen we had in our creeks on the north-west of Australia. Those are creeks and river areas where information about tidal flows, shoals and shipping conditions are of critical importance to anybody who would ever have an ulterior motive towards this country. Those fishing boats provided an ideal opportunity for intelligence gathering. Who is to say whether trochus gathering was the only purpose for those visits?

SPEECH.PARA: We simply cannot prevent this. We simply cannot detect it in time to catch the boats. It takes four days for our patrol boats to steam from Perth. Our Customs Service boats were stretched to the limit by this last handful of boats. We had the fiasco over the coastal surveillance contract for civilian responsibility. It is clear to me that this area should be under defence command. Our present ad hoc arrangement is not good enough. It is clear that the job is not being done properly. I quote from a working paper of the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre, entitled `The Northern Territory in the Defence of Australia: Naval Considerations', by Commander Youll, in which he said:

. . . we have traditionally applied a fragmented, committee (spread the blame) approach to northern littoral surveillance and response . . . it is debilitating of the limited national resource not to vest the surveillance of our northern approaches in the Defence Force who have the legal, knowledge and resource primacy in the task, both as a national responsibility and in terms of regional expertise.

At present we are unable to prevent people from intruding into our waters and coming right onto our land. We are also unable to prevent intrusion into our air space. Only in November last year Air Commodore Tex Watson was reported in the Australian as saying that 80 per cent of the high level air space and 99 per cent of the low level air space to our north is not watched. We have a RAAF capacity in the north limited to air traffic control radar and air defence radar in Darwin which cannot see over the horizon. Admittedly, we have Jindalee in the pipeline but it has many snags in it. It will be a long time before they are ironed out. Our information gathering has to be improved. We need to obtain airborne early warning and control aircraft. The Government has not bitten the bullet on that. These things are vital to preventing our air space from suffering the intrusions which are going on now and which we have no ability to check.

We also have a problem in dealing with the mining of our shipping lanes, choke points and ports. At this stage we are unable to prevent it. Darwin, Cockburn Sound and Sydney are all vulnerable. We have the vulnerability of our naval and merchant shipping. We have little or no air protection, especially anti-submarine warfare protection. We have an Air Force which, presumably will be involved in other tasks when the Navy or our merchant shipping need defending. The Government has made noises about looking at conversion of commercial shipping for defence tasks in time of an emergency but that is all. I understand that the Navy has shown so little enthusiasm for the matter it has not been given a real push along. I understand that Sir Peter Abeles is chairman of a committee that is supposed to be doing something about this. I would very much like to know where that committee has got to on the matter. We need to be able to refuel both the FA18s and the F111s. The Government has not taken a decision in that area. There are 40 guided missile destroyers sitting in Cam Ranh Bay that are closer to Darwin than are the three Australian ones sitting in Sydney. It is appalling to think of the vulnerability of the north and our shipping in the northern areas. The Minister is conveniently overlooking this lack of capability.

I could go on to deal with several other areas such as our lack of amphibious capacity that was mentioned earlier. We are vulnerable to low level incursions. These are the attacks which will come without warning. The Government is constantly talking about our having warning of this, that and the other thing but I believe the most likely threats that face us will come as low level threats without warning. For example, we could have a number of simultaneous harassing attacks known as fait accompli. I refer, for example, to the North West Shelf oil and gas platforms, the northern Royal Australian Air Force bases, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Christmas Island, Darwin and Papua New Guinea all receiving sharp, effective, ruthless attacks at the one time. I do not believe we have the manpower to deal with a number of simultaneous low level attacks.

I wonder how the Government would deal for instance with a 747 aircraft arriving in Darwin with 400 tourists who turn out to be terrorists and who dash about grabbing our vital installations. I am talking about people who are super-well trained. What could the Government do about that if the terrorists held Darwin to ransom? Do we leave them be in Darwin? Do we forget about them? Do we have a sort of Darwin line? If we can deter these low level threats, if people believe that we have a deterrent capacity, then Australia has a chance of getting a warning time of any major attack. So our seen ability to defend ourselves from those sorts of attacks is protection for us from larger attacks.

Mr Beazley says that he is proud to have the largest capital equipment program for the defence forces in Australia's peacetime history. He forgets that in order to deter and to fulfil responsibilities he needs manpower as well as equipment. This is where our greatest vulnerability lies. Our manpower is short and it is short for a couple of reasons. First, the Government has set ceilings which are too low. I find it a matter of great shame. The Government should throw in the towel if it cannot do better than this. It has deliberately reduced numbers in the defence forces this financial year to the extent that the second tier wage rise for the Defence Force was able to be funded out of the costs savings in reduced numbers of men. It is dreadful to cut back the defence forces to finance a second tier wage rise. That says nothing about the needs of the country to be defended. These ceilings have been cut back and whittled away until we now have an inability to manage even low level threats. Secondly, we are losing experienced people because service people are voluntarily leaving. They find that there is not the satisfaction any more in serving this country and protecting us. I do not intend to go into that in great detail now. As honourable senators know, I have given a lot of attention in the two years I have been in this Parliament to this matter.

This Government needs a commitment to its personnel in the defence forces. We are currently spending about 42 per cent of the defence budget on personnel. That is far too low. That is largely responsible for the present demoralised situation. It is not just a question of pay: it is a question of meaningful employment; it is a question of worthwhile training; it is a question of family conditions; it is a question of career development and it is also a question of leadership by senior officers and by the Government.

If the percentage of the defence budget was changed so that personnel represented nearer 50 per cent of the budget we would be getting something like the right break-up in the defence budget. I believe we need to increase the manpower ceilings in the defence forces by about 6,000 over the next four to five years in order to allow the necessary tasks to be done and also to provide an expansion base that may be needed in the future. The ceiling cuts that we have been seeing over recent years are totally dangerous for this country. If we can be seen to be doing something effective about our defence forces perhaps countries in the region will have some confidence in us because they will see that we mean business to defend ourselves as well as to contribute to their defence and their well being.

Before I conclude I would just like to draw attention to a few figures which may interest honourable senators. I personally found them quite interesting. We have all been the subject in recent times of a campaign by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) about its projected cuts in funding. Honourable senators would recall that the ABC says that per capita it gets 8c a day. On my calculations the ABC did not in fact get quite 8c. However, that figure set me thinking. I found out that the defence forces budget gets $1.25 a day. That is what we give the defence of this country. That figure equals 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product. Mr Dibb said in his report that we should be spending 3 per cent. The Government agreed at the time but did not come up with the goods. If we spend 3 per cent that would mean an extra 10c a day. An extra 10c a day is all that we would need to bring us up to the 3 per cent that we really need as steady funding for defence. We seem to be able to afford $3.80 a day for social security and welfare. Can we afford not to spend an extra 10c a day on our defence, not just for ourselves but also for our regional stability? When Minister Beazley can demonstrate that our system is under control and that we are doing our part in preventing hostilities by deterrence, then we will be taken seriously in the region. Then Australians will be able to take the Defence Minister seriously and any reports that he might see fit to put before the Parliament. Until then, this statement is just window dressing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is addressing a defence paper entitled Self Reliance and Co-operation: Australia's Regional Defence Policy. The paper and the trip to the region by the Defence Minister (Mr Beazley) both should be seen for what they are: that is, a reaction to our dismal regional standing following events in Fiji and an attempt to make sure that we are seen to be interested in South East Asia and the South Pacific. The paper is a somewhat pitiful attempt at self-justification. It attempts to camouflage the shortcomings and misjudgments that had been made by this Government in its defence planning. It adopts a new catch phrase of `regional defence co-operation', which is now going to be lauded. It follows other catch phrases we have had over the last couple of years as this Government has claimed to develop policy in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: I criticise this statement and the premises upon which it is based on two levels: first, in relation to this Government's strategy upon which it is based and its attitude to joint regional defence and, secondly, our lack of capacity to contribute in any meaningful way to joint regional defence.

I would suggest that the error in this strategy really commenced some 18 months ago with the release of the Dibb paper-a paper that rapidly became known as the isolationist paper. That paper again advocated a return to the outdated concepts of Fortress Australia, a belief that we could isolate Australia from events in the region and the world. It was what some might refer to as the ostrich approach-that if we buried our heads in the sand Australia could still be protected by its island status. The Minister was correct when he said in this statement that the Dibb paper caused considerable discussion. That is true. There was much discussion and criticism, as a result of which the Government somewhat hastily backed off. The next stage in this scenario was then developed, and that was the Government's self-reliance policy, which it put down in the form of its White Paper on defence. It therefore took a step back from the Dibb scenario to what it referred to as self-reliance. That was of course criticised less because self-reliance in itself is not a bad goal, if it can be achieved, but, as we would all know, self-reliance is something that can never be totally achieved by this country.

I suggest that even in the rationale of a self-reliance policy there was a continuation of the attempt by this Government to distinguish Australia from its friends, and therefore in some way it is not all that similar to the original isolationist policy from which it developed. Both have that factor of wanting to distinguish or separate Australia from its regional and other friends. But what follows from that, I would suggest, is a loss of influence beyond our shores, and therefore a lessening of our capacity to influence peaceful outcomes. I respectfully suggest that peace is the best form of defence and, by the way, also the cheapest. Needless to say, the reaction of our friends and neighbours in the Association of South East Asian Nations and in the Pacific region has been one of despair. Their comments have certainly been couched in diplomatic terms but nevertheless they have indicated a growing belief that Australia is abdicating its responsibility as an influence for peace and stability within our region.

Following the papers and the Government's thinking were a series of events which caused it, I would suggest, to rethink the direction it was taking. We had the events in Fiji where Australia experienced, not once but twice, an embarrassing failure of its intelligence capacity. We saw a democracy within our region, which we had always assumed to be secure, fall at the point of a gun. I hope that this Government then realised that we had lost the capacity to influence events in that country. At that time an election was pending in Vanuatu and there was some Press and diplomatic speculation that a similar event could occur there. Thank goodness that did not come to pass, but it again underlined the fragility of the Pacific democracies and our impotency in relation to influencing events.

A number of events then occurred in Papua New Guinea (PNG) that caused us to wonder as to the future security of that country, and I refer to one which was subsequent to Mr Beazley's trip. That was the report earlier this month of an imminent coup that might take place in that country. That the warnings were taken seriously indicates something in itself. When we look at the very disenchanted former head of the army and Defence Minister in Brigadier Diro, and when we look at an alliance with the sacked immediate past Chief of the PNG Defence Force, Brigadier Tony Huai, one can see a scenario developing that would give Australia reason for concern as to the future security of Papua New Guinea from internal disruption.

When Papua New Guinea has looked for help it has traditionally looked to us. One can only speculate why in recent times it has been turning to the United States of America for military assistance, in the form of Green Berets on the border to act as advisers, when in the past it has looked for assistance of that type from Australia. I suggest that this reflects a loss of confidence in Australia and in Australia's willingness to assist it through the difficult period ahead that it faces. I reflect very briefly on the wise comments of my colleague Senator MacGibbon when he referred again, as a number of us have in the past, to the short-sighted policy of this Government when last year it unilaterally slashed its aid to Papua New Guinea. It was not that the sum of money was of such great significance. What was of such great significance was that it showed Papua New Guinea that it was dealing with an Australia that it could no longer trust or rely upon. I suggest that that loss of confidence has had ramifications, and will have long term ramifications, such as those we are now seeing reflected in such events as Papua New Guinea inviting American servicemen to play a role that has traditionally been played by Australians.

I have suggested that events in the region have indicated the shortcomings of the Government's so-called self-reliance policy. There is no doubt that those events caused the Defence Minister to take this trip to our neighbours and to reassure them that they were not forgotten. I would suggest that the truth is that they were largely forgotten, that the emphasis of this Government's policy is moving away from regional alliances and associations and away from agreements with our friends for mutual defence and support, and that a trip around the region is not going to change the facts. I certainly do not see anything in this defence statement that is changing the facts or even the perception of those facts.

As I have indicated, the new initiatives in this paper, the initiatives that I look for to show that the Government in fact had turned a page and recognised the deficiency in its policies, are simply non-existent. Therefore when we look at page 2 of the statement and see the Government's attempt to argue that its whole policy of self-reliance has in fact been postured on development within the framework of our alliances and regional associations, we can look at that only with disbelief. If it seems so shallow to me, I can only be concerned that it would obviously seem so shallow to our neighbours, and that is something that I very seriously regret. They are told that they are to accept the statement as an assurance. They are not going to see any changes in substance which can give them the confidence that this Government has had a change of policy or in fact is more seriously going to take into account their regional security interests and our regional security interests. As evidence that there has been no change of attitude at all I need only to refer to quotes from Mr Paul Dibb-I remind honourable senators that he has been elevated to the position of Director of the Joint Intelligence Organisation, in which capacity he spoke and therefore no doubt reflected Government policy, because he is unable in that position to speak in any other way-who is reported as referring in the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 February to his assessment of:
. . . a low chance of regional war spreading and getting out of control.

That is the old low level threat scenario upon which he based his earlier report, and from which some of us thought this Government had departed. We are entitled to be somewhat confused because from that base he states:
The great destructiveness of conventional weapons will also encourage restraint although there is a greater likelihood of low level conflict for political or limited territorial gains.
He says that there is a greater likelihood of low level conflict. He continues:

Nevertheless, the Australian Government face challenging questions of assessment. What will Indonesia be like after Suharto? What will be the result of a communist Philippines? Instability in Papua New Guinea? The hegemonistic designs of India in South Asia? Why does India need such a large navy?

These questions are being asked by the head of our Joint Intelligence Organisation-the person who talked about a low level threat scenario, who based his whole paper on a belief that we live in a benign region and that we have the benefit of an immunity provided by distance. He continues:
Another difficulty in assessment are the vast shifts occurring in the economic balance of power in Asia. They may have a fundamental impact on the region's security in the 1990s.

I suggest that the chances are that they will have a vast impact on the region's security in the decades ahead. It is very difficult to predict a reasonable security and threat scenario for this country in the future.

Mr Dibb appears to be reiterating his original low threat scenario, but then confuses us all by suggesting that perhaps there are many other factors that we should be taking into account. If we are taking them into account, I suggest that we should be looking far beyond the policy of self-reliance, because clearly it will be insufficient. What we should be looking at now is how we can influence these events in the region that he postulates with question marks in a way that will lessen the potential of their developing into scenarios that pose a direct threat to us and to our friends within the region.

How can we do it? We can do it in a series of ways: by having a reasonable defence capacity, which I will get to in a moment, and by a whole series of other outreach programs, be they active and meaningful aid programs-and I mentioned the deficiency in relation to PNG-competent diplomatic initiatives, trade initiatives, cultural exchanges or educational support for those within our region who do not have the same resources. In other words, by a whole package of means we are able to influence change for the better, but to do so we need that package and in the package we need to re-establish the goodwill which is a pre-requisite to be able to influence the other states within our region. Even if we accepted, to some extent, what Mr Dibb said-that is, that we live in a benign environment-I suggest we should then be asking: What should we be doing to maintain this benign environment? A self-reliance policy certainly is not the answer.

As I have indicated, I have not yet looked at our military capacity to help maintain favourable conditions within the region. I refer, in other words, to our defence outreach program, which I will get to in a moment. I have simply been looking at failures in the Government's attitude-failures that do not earn the respect of countries in the region, which we should have earned by demonstrating our commitment to assist with their regional problems. I also suggest that we could have demonstrated a genuine willingness to contribute to and be part of the region by listening to their viewpoints in the preparation of our defence planning.

We should recognise that our regional neighbours are developing their own military capacities to a point which would, inevitably and understandably, give them a greater sense of pride and independence. They therefore feel that they have much to offer by way of suggestions on how best to safeguard the region. It is a pity that in the development of these papers this Government did not listen to some of these suggestions. There can be more open exchanges at operational levels between the military forces of Australia and those of our neighbours-certainly more than has been outlined in this paper. There can be more Chiefs of Staff exchanges and more high level planning meetings or discussions on such matters as freedom of movement through the Strait of Malacca and the other important sea lanes. Our neighbours are understandably surprised when this Government persists in its isolationist defence policy and puts Australia in danger of becoming impotent and redundant in our own region.

That leads me to the question of our defence capacity. Do we have the capacity to contribute at that level to a more secure and safe environment without our region? I suggest, on any objective assessment, that the answer has to be no. Let me remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President-and it indicates attitude as well as capacity-that this was the Government that withdrew our small force of helicopters from the Sinai. It did so largely because it did not believe in defence outreach, but also because we were told that without that small helicopter force back in Australia we had no capacity to move our rapid deployment force.

This is the Government that is withdrawing our permanent presence in the form of a fighter force from Butterworth base. This has been alluded to at length by my colleague Senator MacGibbon. We are given in this paper a complicated justification for that which is inconsistent with what the Senate has been told in the past. If I remember correctly, Senator Gareth Evans seemed to have some responsibility to make statements in this area. It is clear to us that it has been withdrawn for two reasons: the first is a lack of resources and the second is the earlier political judgment of this Government that it did not want to be involved in having a permanent fighter force outside Australia and within our region-in other words, in a permanent outreach situation.

This is the Government that disbanded the Fleet Air Arm and therefore our capacity to extend influence of fixed-wing aircraft over any distance. This is the Government that allowed our personnel figures to run down to critical levels, as has been put to the Senate by Senator Newman today. I remind the Senate that we have 20 PC3 Orions but we do not have the personnel to operate more than 12 or 13 of them. I also bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that the flight hours for those Orions have now been reduced from an average of 1,200 to 1,400 hours per year to a record low of 700 hours in this financial year. So we do not have the professional staff to man the aircraft, to maintain the aircraft or to fly the aircraft. In any event, because of cost constraints their time in the air is being cut down to record levels. It is not surprising that that is happening because, as you are well aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, funding for defence is down. In real terms funding for defence in this last Budget is down by one per cent. We on this side of the chamber say that this indicates misplaced priorities.

Our ships are now spending less time at sea because of fuel restrictions which have limited steaming hours and reduced operational training. I ask: Was the tragedy of HMAS Otama last year really just a series of unfortunate events or did it reveal something about the state of our submarine service? I believe that the statement issued by Admiral Hudson gave the true picture away when it referred to the low level of skill and experience on the Otama at the time of the tragedy. Only last week Air Marshal Funnell admitted that the Royal Australian Air Force was unlikely to be able to raise a third FA18 squadron. There are now only 12 pilots to a squadron when there should be 18. With the two under-strength squadrons and those pilots that remain obviously being younger and less skilled, one doubts whether the Minister's plans for rotating FA18 squadrons between Tindal and Butterworth will ever come to reality. Even if it does remain a genuine plan in the Government's mind, there are many in the Air Force who say that, as a matter of practice, it will not work and it will be a false economy. The dismantling of the permanent maintenance facilities will add to the financial outgoings in this project.

With 170 pilots being lost to the service last year, when for the last 20 years we have lost an average of only 47 pilots, one can see the critical state to which our Air Force has fallen. There is still no sign of extending the refuelling capacity of our F111s, and the Minister has a great cheek to talk in this statement of our now having aircraft that are capable of being refuelled in the air when in fact we do not have the facility to carry out such refuelling. We have to rely on our friends. Also, there is no sign of an airborne early warning capability. So one doubts the genuine ability of our Air Force to meet its responsibilities as set out in this defence paper.

Exercise Diamond Dollar was worth every penny it cost in that it revealed that our one and only division can sustain operations for only five to six weeks. As honourable senators would know, Defence Force wastage is presently the subject of a committee inquiry, suffice it for me to say a loss of 13 per cent of our Defence Force in one year translates into a loss of some 9,000 skilled officers and men. Male officer resignations have doubled from a 10-year average of 5.4 per cent. It is interesting to note that as from last July, when male officer resignations passed the 10 per cent level, statistics ceased to be made available.

What I am saying in summary, therefore, is that even if this Government had the right attitude, even if it took joint regional defence responsibility seriously and believed in that concept-which it does not, as indicated by the lack of substance in this statement and the lack of serious reference to it in previous statements-we would not have the defence capacity to meet that responsibility. I therefore regret that this paper does not come clean. It is not a statement setting out that the Government realises the error it has made and realises that this is simply rhetoric aimed at self-justification. I regret that the statement does not acknowledge that the Government has let down our regional friends and allies, that it does not accept our regional responsibilities and does not recognise that regional sensitivities are important. I regret that the statement does not set out a program for building into our Defence Force a capacity to make a worthwhile and meaningful contribution to joint regional defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing this evening the parliamentary statement by the Minister for Defence, Kim Beazley, which the Minister has titled `Self-Reliance and Co-operation: Australia's Regional Defence Policy'. If this is a policy statement, something is terribly wrong with the Australian Labor Party. I believe the statement would be far better renamed `Beazley's Bunkum and Bull' because it is an insult to the intelligence of this Parliament. It is a totally inadequate set of guidelines for our regional neighbours to be able even to look at and take reference from, and as far as every Australian citizen is concerned it is a disgraceful compromise of the defence forces of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also worth noting that of the 32 Labor Party senators, not one has had the guts to back up Minister Beazley. The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), who tabled the statement, merely had it incorporated in Hansard and not one other member of the Labor Party in this place has been prepared to speak on this important document. I believe there have been some eight speakers today-a number from the Opposition, Senator McLean from the Australian Democrats, Senator Vallentine and Senator Wood. I certainly would not agree with the standards and viewpoint put forward by Senator Wood or Senator Vallentine, which is quite contrary even to that of the Labor Party. Their view is basically that we can solve these sorts of problems in the preschool; we can teach the children that we do not need to fight and can keep them in some sort of special creche for the rest of their lives. That is a totally inadequate defence policy.

I am bemused by the fact that this statement sets out to look at our regional defence policy. I read the document through and kept asking who I could send it to in the Northern Territory electorate, which has a strong interest in the defence of our nation, and how would that person respond to the statement. What would be the issues that would have an effect on the defence community in the Northern Territory, as well as the business community and the general population? What would be their interests? In fact, the more I read the Minister's statement the more I am sure it would be perceived as nothing but a puzzling and irrelevant document.

I look at it from a Northern Territory perspective. The Territory does have very high involvement in Australia's defence establishment. It holds a strategic position not only in Australia but in all of Asia. The Northern Territory has the existing facilities of Pine Gap and the Jindalee communications base, the Tindal Air Force base, the Royal Australian Air Force base in Darwin, the Army's Norforce, and naval patrol operations as well as naval and other communications facilities. This statement contains no integration of these facilities with the Government's supposed policies and objectives for, as referred to in the title of the statement, Australia's regional defence policy. If any member of the defence forces in the Northern Territory were to read this report, he would wonder what his role was in the mosaic, the picture, that he is meant to have some firm understanding of.

The business community, particularly of the Northern Territory, relies on a strong regional defence policy. There is no security effort for that business community, or for mining and tourism interests. What about oil exploration in the Timor Sea and the Cartier and Cocos (Keeling) islands? There is no substance in the statement on which the fishing industry of northern Australia can rely, and of course there is a special link between the Northern Territory and the Cocos and Christmas islands, out in the Indian Ocean. They are totally ignored by this statement. There is no reference to the strategic matters regarding these areas. There is no mention in the statement of industrial support and how that would link up or tie in, and there is no reference whatsoever to the infrastructure of the urban community planning that must go hand in hand with any proper and rational defence policy.

Mr Beazley's statement is nothing but a series of paragraphs, pulled out of a word processor, that have obviously been accumulated from many other speeches. Obviously Mr Beazley, as the Minister for Defence, is now far too busy in his new role as Leader of the House. Perhaps he ought to re-look at his role, because he is in danger of becoming the ringmaster of the Barnum and Bailey circus if this is the quality and standard of work he is to put out. Mr Beazley refers near the beginning of his statement to the actions that the Government is taking in our regional defence relations, and further on refers to a strategy to achieve a self-reliant defence posture. I cannot find the substance to back up those initial statements by the Minister. Sure he says that there has been in recent years a concentration on the force structure of the Australian Defence Force and a concentration on capital equipment, but then the Minister goes on to talk about our regional priorities as a matter of relying on the lessons of history, geography and commonsense. But this document is totally devoid of any commonsense. It is totally lacking it. I will give a simple example of the Minister's own words which are so much like those of the Government-so out of touch. He says:
Our area of direct military interest-
which is referred to as being-
4000 miles from east to west and 3000 miles from north to south-

that is miles, not kilometres. He is so out of touch that his language has not yet caught up with the right vocabulary. All the nations of South East Asia and the south-west Pacific form the very broad area of our strategic interests. The Minister goes into a lot of detail on page 9 of his report. He says that the series of visits he undertook-the junkets, very obviously-had as an aim:
. . . to learn how our neighbours perceive strategic developments in our region.
He also says:
I was struck by the much more balanced discussion of strategic issues among our neighbours than is often seen here.

For heaven's sake, how long has he been the Minister for Defence? The Labor Government has had control of this portfolio for some five years yet the Minister comes out with statements like that. As Senator MacGibbon said earlier in the debate, there is not one instance in this report on our regional defence policy that points to any firm and consistent relationship with the United States of America. There is absolutely no mention of the United States of America as having any relevance to our regional defence policy. On page 10 of the report the Minister says:
. . . the region is continually changing and becoming more complex.

But then what is said? Beazley does not look at the factors which lie behind this statement. The questions are therefore posed: If the region is continually changing, if it is becoming more complex-and I can accept those statements-what are the sociological pressures that are building up, what are the population forecasts, the economic influences, the technological advantages and disadvantages and influence of the emerging Asian countries and nations? Can the Minister not look some 20, 30 or 40 years ahead of where we are today, instead of being totally patronising and pappy. The Minister spends a few paragraphs referring to our capital equipment plans, to the FA18s that are coming and to the fact that a whole new base is going into Tindal in the Northern Territory. He talks about a few planes for surveillance across the top or in some of the Pacific areas. He talks about a few ships for naval excursions.

But let us look at what this statement is. It is about regional policies. If we get down to analysing it by country and the regions with which we have this intimacy, what comes out? For Malaysia and Singapore the Minister talks about a small aircraft presence, the army rifle company and rotational deployments. All the Minister talks about in relation to Thailand are army exercises, joint and in small numbers. He talks about Brunei and training. When he talks about Indonesia he does not talk about anything. He leaves a whopping great question mark hanging over the entire regional issue. Why has he done that? Surely as part of the development of this policy he is well aware of not only the Government's defence policies but also the foreign affairs relationships and the terribly important role that we must have in a partnership with Indonesia.

I had the privilege yesterday of meeting the new Indonesian Ambassador to Australia, Mr Roesman. We sat down and talked about the very things that I would expect to be in this report about Indonesia and its long term plans and pressures and what it is fearful of. Indonesia would be far more fearful of countries to the north than it would ever be of us. When the Minister talks about Papua New Guinea he concentrates on training, advisory assistance, army engineering and naval facilities on Manus Island. Those matters are small-infinitesimal-in this area. There is no structural tying together of what the statement is about.

When the Minister talks about Fiji he has to admit we have put our relationship into suspended animation and had to review our relationship-but that is all it is, a review. There is a patrol boat program for the south-west Pacific islands, but if we look carefully at what is in the section on page 27 of the report, we see that the Minister does nothing but trivialise this patrol boat and naval presence in the south-west Pacific. The Minister said:
For example, learning from our early experiences, we have decided from now on to install air-conditioning in the Pacific patrol boats, and to retrofit it to those already delivered.
He goes on in a similar sort of manner:
For example, the Cook Islands has asked us to look at installing extra freezer capability in their boat . . .

We are trivialising a policy on regional defence when we get down to talking about a few air-conditioning units and a few freezers. When we talk about our relationship with New Zealand, the Minister says that is getting into bed, or as he says:
. . . in association with the New Zealand department of Defence and the South Pacific Forum Fisheries Agency-
the Department-
is sponsoring a maritime surveillance seminar in which all member countries of the South Pacific Forum will participate.

The level of defence debate and discussion with New Zealand is such that we now have to rely on seminars. This is typical of where the Labor governments in New Zealand and Australia have got to, that on an important issue such as defence, we have got down to pulling in the fishing agency and talking about maritime surveillance. Concerning Vanuatu, Kiribati, Tuvalu and the Solomon Islands, again there are simple words of co-operation. The Minister admits to succumbing to the `charm and peace' of Honiara when he visited there. I say to the Minister, `Come on!'. Senators MacGibbon, McLean, Newman and Hill shared my frustration with this report. The Minister's diary of travel does not go to the core of the defence issue. Nor does Mr Beazley share a view of what our regional neighbours think of us. He visited them and discussed things with them. Is he going to leave the matter entirely to Mr Hayden?

What do the countries to the immediate north or in the South Pacific have as expectations of us? Where do they perceive any short or long term threats? What do they see as the long term options and where do we fit into partnership with them? What are their perceptions of the role of India, a country with 800 million people; of China with 1,000 million; Vietnam with 60 million; and Russia with 300 million? Thirty-three per cent of the world's population is immediately to the north of our so-called region. There is no mention of India, China, Vietnam or Russia and how they have any impact on the development of our regional policies. That is not even mentioned or picked up.

I am disappointed that Minister Beazley has gone to water. The Australian Labor Party, very obviously, is adopting the New Zealand policy line on defence. If Beazley cannot manage, can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden? He is chuffing around the Middle East at the moment. What sort of statement can we expect from him when he returns? Will it be couched in terms similar to this, that he is succumbing somewhere to the charm and peace of a particular place? I anticipate that when Hayden gets back there will be a formal statement to this Parliament. The debate in this place should be decent, of a high calibre, of a high standard and from all parties. I think the worst feature of what has happened here today was the total deficiency, inadequacy and abrogation of its duties of the Labor Party in that not one senator from the Labor Party was prepared to speak on this important subject.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 will amend the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, the Postal Services Act 1975, the Radiocommunications Act 1983, and the Telecommunications Act 1975.
The principal changes made in the Bill are intended to:
streamline the procedures by which OTC, Australia Post and Telecom Australia can enter into hedging contracts;
enable Australia Post and Telecom Australia to issue securities not guaranteed by the Commonwealth;
clarify and strengthen the law relating to the sending of explosives and other dangerous goods through the mail;
confirm the Minister's power to test equipment as part of the process of issuing licences under the Radiocommunications Act;
place the practice of type-testing radiocommunications equipment on a statutory basis; and

provide a statutory power to prohibit the supply, operation or possession for the purpose of supply or operation of devices intended to cause interference with the legitimate use of the radio frequency spectrum, or likely to cause interference to radiocommunications in such a way as to endanger life or property.
Various other amendments of the four Acts of a purely formal or technical nature are also included.

The amendments to the Radiocommunications Act 1983 relating to testing are expected to provide a very small increase in revenue through testing fees. All other amendments are expected to have no financial impact.
I will deal first with the amendments to the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, the Postal Services Act 1975, and the Telecommunications Act 1975.

The Commissions established by these three Acts (respectively OTC, Australia Post, and Telecom Australia) each have power to enter into hedging contracts as part of their normal trading activities. Each Commission must also obtain the approval of the Minister for a contract involving the payment or receipt of money in excess of a specified amount. At present each of the three Acts contains a definition of `proposed contract' the effect of which is to require the respective Commissions to await Ministerial approval of a trading contract before entering into a hedging contract in respect of it.

Given the speed with which currency values can fluctuate, it is commercially vital for the Commissions to be able to enter into hedging contracts as soon as the trading contract is negotiated, otherwise the benefit of the hedging contract may be totally lost. The Bill therefore amends the three Acts to permit this.

Secondly, the Postal Services Act 1975 and Telecommunications Act 1975 presently require securities issued by Australia Post and Telecom Australia respectively to be guaranteed by the Commonwealth. This obligation is commercially unnecessary and is inconsistent with the flexibility that exists with other non-prescribed forms of borrowing, and the Bill therefore removes it. These amendments will place the two authorities in the same position as other Commonwealth business enterprises (other than financial institutions) where guarantees of borrowings may be provided at the discretion of the Treasurer.
Thirdly, the Bill amends the Postal Services Act 1975 to clarify and strengthen the law relating to the sending of explosives or other dangerous goods or substances through the post.

Honourable senators will remember the explosion at the Brisbane Parcels Centre in January 1987 which seriously injured a postal worker. This incident focused attention on the need to significantly tighten the legislation relating to the carriage of explosive or other dangerous substances in the mail. The proposed new section makes it an offence to send explosives through the mail and provides for acceptance of dangerous or deleterious substances on conditions determined by the Commission. The current section 100 of the Postal Services Act 1975 does not clearly differentiate between those items which are prohibited from transmission by post and those which may be conditionally accepted. The proposed new section also significantly increases the penalties for such offences.

This proposed new section 100 is but one of the measures being taken to minimise the risks to postal workers through the carriage of dangerous goods in the mail. Australia Post is working closely with unions on a comprehensive preventative program that includes training programs for staff receiving parcels, contact with companies likely to be sources of dangerous goods, especially explosives, and work to secure the co-operation of other postal authorities.

The Bill amends section 58 of the Telecommunications Act 1975 to increase the monetary penalties from $40 to $500 in relation to disciplinary action. An increase of this order was one of the recommendations contained in the report of Mr F. H. R. Vincent QC, on a review of allegations against Telecom Australia. The level of the monetary penalty proposed is in line with a similar provision in the Public Service Act following amendment to the Act in 1986 as apart of the Government's streamlining reforms.
Fourthly, the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946 is amended to correct a drafting error, and the Telecommunications Act 1975 is amended to render its language gender-neutral.
Next I shall describe the amendments to the Radio- communications Act 1983. There are two major and several minor amendments.

The first of these amends the Act to provide a statutory basis for the issue of a certificate to be called a `type approval certificate'. When issuing licences for the operation of radiocommunications transmitters or receivers under the Act, the Minister or his or her delegate is required to take into account the effect on radiocommunications of the proposed operation of the transmitter or receiver, and therefore needs to know the characteristics of the transmitter or receiver. The purpose of the amendment is to permit manufacturers or importers of equipment to submit samples of equipment for testing and obtain a certificate to the effect that the equipment has no undesirable effect on radiocommunications. Where such a certificate is issued in respect of a particular model of, say radiocommunications transmitter, the holder of the certificate will be authorised to affix a statement to each example of that model that such a certificate has been issued. When issuing licences covering the operation of equipment for which a type approval certificate has been issued, the Minister will have no need to examine or test the equipment further.

The sections of the Act covering licensing of radio- communications transmitters and receivers are to be amended to place beyond doubt the Minister's power to require applicants for such licences to submit the proposed equipment for testing, if necessary.

The second major amendment is to give the Minister power to prohibit particular devices, where the devices are either expressly designed to interfere with the legitimate use of the radio frequency spectrum, or where a device substantially interferes with, or substantially disrupts or disturbs, radiocommunications in a manner likely to endanger the safety of persons or cause substantial loss or damage. The power is to be exercised only after publication of the details of the proposed prohibition, and the giving of reasons for it, and following consideration of any representations which may be received in answer to the notice. Once made, the declaration of the prohibition is to be published in the Gazette and tabled in the Parliament as if it were a regulation. Once a device is prohibited, its supply or operation or possession for the purposes of supply or operation is an offence, subject to fines of $1000 for a natural person or $5000 for a body corporate.

This amendment is designed to protect legitimate users of the spectrum from certain devices which are available overseas and may be imported into Australia. Control of such devices under the standards power is not appropriate since standards are intended to apply only to devices which are licensable, and it would be inappropriate to make standards for devices which would never under any circumstances be licensed. Moreover, a standard only applies to devices manufactured or imported after the date on which the standard was made, and therefore does not catch devices manufactured or imported earlier. The mere possession of a prohibited device will not in itself constitute an offence, however, so that a person who owns a device which is subsequently prohibited will commit an offence only if the device is actually used or sold to another person.

A less important but still significant amendment is to the provision of the Act allowing a licensee to authorise another person to operate the licensee's equipment. Cases have arisen in the past where fears have been expressed that a person whose licence had been cancelled for breaches of the Act or Regulations might arrange to obtain access to another transmitter by way of such an authority.

This amendment therefore provides that a person whose licence has been cancelled cannot lawfully be authorised to operate another transmitter of the same kind as the licence was issued in respect of, for a period of three years, unless that person has been issued with a new licence subsequent to the cancellation. Further, if a person is currently licensed to operate a transmitter, and also holds an authority from another person to operate another transmitter of the same class, if the former person's licence is suspended or cancelled, the authority lapses at the time of the suspension or cancellation.

The Bill also amends the Act to extend the range of offences subject to fines in lieu of prosecution by adding to it offences against subsection 65(9) of the Act; that is, offences in the nature of using radiocommunications transmitters for harassing another person by causing interference with radiocommunications. As with other offences subject to fines in lieu of prosecutions, the maximum fine that may be imposed in this way is one-fifth of the sum prescribed as penalty by the Act.
The Bill makes a number of minor and consequential amendments to the Act, and also amends it to render its language gender-neutral.

The Bill represents further evidence of the Government's commitment to efficiency and sound commercial practice for major government business enterprises such as OTC, Australia Post and Telecom Australia; to the safety of Australia Post's employees and legitimate users of the postal services; and to efficient and equitable use of the radio frequency spectrum, which is a scarce and valuable resource.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act 1972. The principal amendments bring the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act into line with the Public Service Act 1922, as amended by the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Act 1986, in the areas of promotions, transfers, appeals, forfeiture of office and attachment of salary. Provision is also made for the transfer of staff from the Commonwealth Teaching Service to certain other Commonwealth authorities.

The Commonwealth Teaching Service established under the principal Act is divided into three parts, or `components'. The two largest components are the ACT schools component and the ACT TAFE component. The schools component consists of teaching staff employed in Commonwealth schools, mainly in the Australian Capital Territory. Teachers employed in ACT TAFE colleges belong to the TAFE component. Staff are made available to the educational institutions in each component by the notional employer, or `relevant authority', of the component.

Turning first to the question of promotions and appeals: seniority has been removed as a factor in determining the most suitable applicant for a position, leaving efficiency as the sole determinant. The definition of efficiency has itself been broadened to allow a relevant authority to consider an applicant's potential for future career development and his or her ability to perform the duties of other positions at the same level. In addition, the relevant authority in each component now has the option of promoting or transferring an officer on the advice of a joint selection committee comprising an independent chairperson and either two or three other members agreed between the relevant authority and the appropriate union.

Measures have also been taken to reduce the number of appeals. New provisions inserted by the Bill exclude appeals in two situations: firstly, where a person is promoted to a position by a relevant authority acting on the advice of a joint selection committee; and secondly, where a person did not apply for a position. The appeal process has itself been streamlined by removing the need for a Promotions Appeal Board to make full inquiry into the claims of the different parties to the appeal and by substituting a requirement that the board make only such inquiries as are necessary to enable it to form an opinion as to the most efficient of the applicants. It is expected that these changes to the promotions and appeals systems will significantly reduce the time taken to fill positions and there should in general be less recourse to an increasingly lengthy and costly appeal process.

There is currently no provision in the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act, or in the determination and awards governing conditions of employment in the Commonwealth Teaching Service, for terminating the contract of an employee who has been absent on unauthorised leave for an extended period or who has left the service without submitting a resignation. Provisions in the Bill similar to the forfeiture of office provisions in the Public Service Act remedy this. Persons retired under the new provisions will have access to a two-tier review process. The manner of application for review will be prescribed by regulations under the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act. It is intended that a relevant authority's decision not to reappoint a person will be reviewable by the Merit Protection and Review Agency.

The amendment of the Act to allow a proportion of an employee's salary to be deducted to satisfy debts incurred by the officer will provide a firm legal base for existing practice. Administration costs will be defrayed by the charging of a fee at a rate prescribed by regulations under the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act.

Finally, new section 50a, inserted by clause 11 of the Bill, empowers the Minister to transfer staff to another Commonwealth authority where the function performed by the staff is taken over by that authority. The section will allow staff to be transferred from the Service to the proposed ACT Institute of TAFE and the proposed Canberra Institute of the Arts. Ordinances establishing the two Institutes are scheduled to commence in early 1988. The Government proposes to consult with employee representatives about applicable conditions of service before staff are transferred under new section 50a. Conditions of service of staff transferred under the section would remain broadly comparable to those applying immediately before the transfer. Fundamental entitlements, such as superannuation, maternity leave and long service leave, would also be preserved.

No additional costs are expected to flow from the implementation of this Bill. Some minor savings are expected to flow from a reduction in the number of appeals required to be determined by Promotions Appeal Boards.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when this debate was interrupted by the adjournment I was in the middle of my speech. Honourable senators will excuse me if I recap on a few of the points I had already made last night in order to give them the main thrust of my argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I had mentioned that the Child Care Support Bill was introduced to enforce the collection of maintenance orders issued to non-custodial parents. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised that by 1990 there will be no child living in poverty. However, he did not tell us that the employers were going to bear the main brunt of collecting the money that he promised to supporting parents. The employers have already been lumbered as free collectors of internal revenue. Other collection services provided free by the employers are pay as you earn taxation, Medicare payments, sales tax, fringe benefits tax-here the employers pay the bill as well-and prescribed payments tax. Another collection services is the voluntary deductions requested by employees.

The penalties all seem to be on the employer. I cannot find in this Bill any penalties for the people who fail to pay maintenance. The penalties seem to be on the employer who, whether by neglect, design or otherwise, fails to collect maintenance payments. I will list them. Under clause 47 (1) there is provision for a penalty of up to $5,000, 12 months imprisonment, or both, for failure to furnish particulars in the approved form, within the first seven days of the following month. Clause 47 (2) provides that when a deduction has been made from wages and salaries the employer must give written notice to the employees. Failure to do so, even if no deduction is made, attracts a penalty of $1,000. Clause 47 (3) provides that an employer must notify the Registrar in an approved form if an employee leaves his employ. The penalty for failure to do so is another $500.

Clause 57 provides that employers are not to prejudice employees because of maintenance commitments. Employers generally have more to worry about in running their business than to discriminate against any particular employee for reasons of this nature. There is a penalty of $2,000 should it be proven that there is discrimination. This point can be used against an employer to start trouble if an employee thinks that he may have been unjustifiably dismissed. Clause 60 refers to the incorrect keeping of records, which could be unintentional or a slip of the pen when there are bookkeepers and junior office girls around the place. That attracts another penalty of $2,000 for the employer. Clause 61 refers to access to premises and requires the employer to provide all reasonable facilities and assistance for an inspector to come in to see what the employer is up to. Again, there is a fine of up to $2,000.

Then there is a secrecy provision. In a large or even a small firm many office staff-some senior and some junior-have access to records and if one happens to be guilty of an indiscretion there is another penalty; that is, the penalty about secrecy. The explanatory memorandum provides that this clause will impose an obligation of secrecy on officers who work in these areas. The explanatory memorandum states:
For that purpose, an `officer' includes a person who, although not actually appointed or employed by the Commonwealth, performs services for the Commonwealth.
I presume that the officer mentioned there is the employer. It continues:
In recognition of the serious nature of any breach of this provision, the Bill provides for a fine not exceeding $5,000, or jail for a period not exceeding 1 year, or both.
