TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill is another imposition which means that the employer has hidden costs. The figure by which wages are multiplied when charged out against a job is already 1.85. In other words, if it costs $100 for a days employment, $185 has to be charged against that job. The Bill will leader to higher costs either for services or for production, and it may lead also to the elimination of some employees. Though the Bill does not go quite as far as the defeated Australia Card legislation in putting all the emphasis of penalties on the employer, nonetheless it has gone far enough. I wonder just how much consultation was had with the employers before this Bill was brought before the Senate. In conclusion, I honestly hope that the Bill will work and bring the irresponsible to face their responsibilities instead of relying on the public purse. I hope that couples will think a little more before entering into relationships without thought to the consequences, and thereby hit their purses.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment that the Opposition has before the House, which is mainly aimed at those who are already meeting their commitments, was mentioned a few times last evening. Only 30 per cent of maintenance payments are being collected. This Bill will reduce the 70 per cent not being collected to about 30 per cent, but the 30 per cent who are paying already have honest agreements, and those agreements are working. I do not see why they should be subject to this sort of Bill so that they have to put their affairs into the public eye in front of the Registrar and, what is more, in front of an employer. Believe it or not-and contrary to what Senator Coates mentioned last evening-some divorced couples, some separated couples, and some couples who have been in de facto relationships and have separated remain good friends.

Senator Coates said that anyone receiving a payment was not happy to receive it from a former boyfriend, husband or whatever, would rather get it through the mail from a Government enterprise. I do not subscribe to that view whatsoever. As I said, some of those who have made arrangements between themselves are paying far more towards the upkeep of their children, because they are interested in their children, than any Family Court would settle upon. They have been doing that and will continue to do that, and I cannot see for one minute any reason why those people should be brought under the jurisdiction of the proposed Registrar. I know that Senator Peter Durack in times gone by tried to bring forward this sort of Bill, but for one reason or another it was not successful. I compliment him on the work that he has done in the past on the Family Law Bills and also on the Bill before the Senate. As I said, I hope it does work and that it will reduce the pull on the public purse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Child Support Bill, which, as all honourable senators would know, is part of a package the Government is bringing forward to try to cut back the amount of public money that is used in supporting children who ought to be supported by their parents. We had an interesting speech earlier from Senator McKiernan. I think he was the first Labor speaker to contribute. Some of the matters he raised I shall refer to as I speak. He, of course, gave us initially his usual exhibition of his fascination with opposition. He rarely begins a speech without talking about the Opposition and what it should do and how it might go about its business. He seems to be almost mesmerised by opposition, and I guess it will not be long before he will be here to enjoy it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is accompanied by an explanatory memorandum which I would say is one of the most comprehensive explanatory memorandums that I have seen and goes a long way towards assisting in coming to terms with the thrust of this Bill. It sets out in its general outline the areas that are covered, explaining that it is for the collection of maintenance payable by either court order or agreement between the parties in relation to either a child, children, or a spouse. It establishes a Register and a Registrar, who will be the Commissioner of Taxation. It identifies a debt to the Commonwealth that is the substance of such agreement or order payable by one parent to the parent who in fact has the custody of the children.

The Act itself indicates that a number of areas will be dealt with by regulation-a great number of areas in relation to exemptions and other matters. I will certainly be looking very closely at the regulations as they come before the Senate, because I think they are extensive; I think we will need to be very certain that anomalies are not created in relation to some of the exemptions and the way the Bill is introduced. I say that in no sense as a criticism, but I think honourable senators ought to be aware of the number of significant areas which are left to regulation. But, as I said, the explanatory memorandum is indeed helpful in understanding the thrust of the Bill and the way it is being developed, and I would say at this stage that it is because of one aspect of the Bill that I very strongly support the second reading amendment which we have put up.

I believe there are several reasons why it ought to be supported, and I would hope that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) would have another look at those aspects of the Bill which I will address in speaking to our amendment, because I regard them as significant. I regard the Bill without them as being excessively costly to administer and excessively intrusive. The explanatory memorandum goes into some detail about the financial impact, but that perhaps would be the area in which I think it is weakest in explaining what moneys will be raised. It does mention the figure of $7.6m in 1987-88 and goes on to explain future years. It refers to those figures as net figures without in fact giving any details of the cost to the Commonwealth of administering this. I would suggest that the cost in fact will be very high indeed.

I hope that at some stage we will receive more information about the actual costs and the real savings that will result from this Bill. I think it is a pity that more information has not been supplied to enable us to look at it. The cost, of course, goes much further than what it will in fact cost the Commonwealth to administer. The costs will be added to the parties, and there is at least one extra procedure that has to take place in the registration of the Bill. That perhaps is the least of the costs. The most significant area of extra costs-and I would invite honourable senators to recall the matters that Senator Panizza has just referred to-is the cost to employers.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was expressing my support for the Child Support Bill and my very strong support for the amendment moved by the Opposition. I believe there are very valid reasons why that amendment should be supported. I had commented on the cost of administering this proposed Act, which I believe will be substantial. It is hoped that those details will be made known to us in due course. The impact statement on the financial aspects of this matter indicates the Government's expectations as to net benefits but does not deal with the actual costs. The Minister may be able to give us more information about that aspect later in the night.

SPEECH.PARA: The real costs of administering this scheme will be borne in fact by the employers. Senator Panizza has already referred in some detail to this aspect. The extra cost to employers will be substantial. Senator Panizza has dealt with the clauses of the Bill and referred to the proposed penalties, the work that employers will be required to do and the impact of that upon them. In many instances in the end the general consumer again will pay for the support to be provided in this area. However, I do not think we should underestimate the impact that this scheme will have on a small firm. It will be an extra burden on a firm which already employs professional accounting staff, but for many smaller businesses it will impose an extreme burden. Such businesses are already working flat out seven days a week in an effort to make ends meet and survive. They are doing their own bookkeeping and running that side of their operations. We really need to have regard to what we are doing when we ask such businesses to be involved in this scheme, especially having in mind the added burden of the penalties they face if they do not keep to the timetable that is to be imposed upon them. The very least the Government could do to compensate them is to make significant tax cuts to business as a means of offsetting some of this extra burden.

This is not the first impost that is being placed on business. Already business has to deal with sales tax, petrol stations must deal with petrol duty, and generally businesses must deal with tobacco tax and excise and provide information to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I could spend the rest of the evening detailing what business already has to do to support government in doing what it wants to do. All that is quite apart from having to pay income tax and imposts of that nature. The burden being placed on business should not be overlooked. I suggest that the Senate or some part of the Parliament should establish a committee to monitor the impact of all aspects of this legislation, but in particular its impact upon employers. There is no doubt that the social security payout is enormous. I think the explanatory memorandum deals with that aspect.

We should now be seeing the benefits that will flow from the abolition of the abuse of social security payments that has gone on for a very long time under section 75 (2) (f) of the Family Law Act. It is not doubted that many hundreds of thousands of arrangements have been put in place using that section as the basis for keeping the maintenance payment by the non-custodial parent to the very minimum to ensure that the recipient remained eligible to receive the maximum pension available. In future maintenance orders should be made on the basis of the ability of the parent to contribute to the support of a child, and the social security payment should be used for its true purpose.

Significant improvements would have been effected to the Act had the Government supported Senator Durack's Bill when it was before the Senate in 1983 and 1985. It is a pity that that opportunity was missed. Certainly, as has been pointed out, this Bill goes much further than Senator Durack's Bill, but Senator Durack's legislation could have been amended in any event when the Government finally got around to it. But at least it is being done at this time. I was intrigued at Senator McKiernan welcoming Opposition support for the Bill. In fact, one might also say that the Government is finally getting around to supporting this legislation.

The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in his second reading speech, said that 70 per cent of those who are supposed to be receiving maintenance are not receiving regular payments. It is my view that the Bill ought to be redrafted to incorporate the amendment moved by the Opposition. If a person wants to receive a pension or wants to dip into the public purse, of course that person's order or agreement must be registered. If a person does not want to receive a pension but wants his or her maintenance payments to be collected by the Registrar, of course the agreement must be registered. But if a person does not want to receive a pension and does not want his or her maintenance payments collected by the Registrar, I think it is offensive that that person must still have the agreement registered. It is almost as though Big Brother is keeping track no matter what.

It is expensive to require the registration of all these extra agreements. It is intrusive of the Government to be involved in those agreements. If a person subsequently wants the Registrar to enforce an order or a person wishes to apply for a pension, surely procedures can be laid down whereby that person is able to register the agreement and for that agreement to operate from that point onwards. It is totally unacceptable to me and it is intrusive of the Government to word clause 23 as it appears in the Bill. Clause 23 (2) reads:

The payee of the registrable maintenance liability shall, within 14 days after the day (. . . called the `relevant day') on which the order is made by, or registered in, the court or the agreement is registered in, or approved by, the court, furnish to the Registrar a duly completed approved form in relation to the order or agreement.
As an aside I would say that in many instances that is one of the areas in which the litigants will be put to extra expense because of the legal costs involved. Clause 23 (3) reads:

. . . the payee is not required to furnish the form to the Registrar if the payee, within that period of 14 days, elects, by furnishing a duly completed approved form to the Registrar, not to have the registrable maintenance liability enforced under this Act.

Under both of those provisions the agreement must be registered. That is the point that the Opposition's amendment is trying to make. Why does the Government need to be so intrusive as to try to insist on including that provision as well? I think that is the big flaw in this legislation. Clause 23 (4) indicates that the Registrar, having received a court order or an agreement, must himself enter it in the Child Support Register within 28 days. Of course, that is appropriate. He must do that so that he is able then to deal with the order or agreement in the appropriate fashion.

Where the payee of a registrable maintenance liability who is required to furnish to the Registrar a duly completed approved form fails to do so within the period specified, the Registrar shall, even though the form has not been furnished, register the liability under the Act by entering particulars of the liability in the Child Support Register. I was intrigued as to how he would do that until I read in clause 112 that an order having been made by a court or a maintenance agreement having been registered, the court shall within 28 days send a certified copy of that order or agreement to the Registrar. So the Registrar will receive that information in any event. While that provision remains, the couple who comes to a perfectly reasonable, civilised settlement of their divorce and the arrangements for their children's maintenance and who puts that settlement into an agreement cannot be left alone. That agreement must be registered and it must come under the eagle eye of the Commissioner of Taxation who will be administering this Act.

I cannot repeat too often that that is intrusive and offensive. Surely people should be allowed to be divorced with dignity and to reorder their affairs in a way that suits both of them, and they should be allowed to live their lives without this sort of intrusion. As I said, if one wants to dip into the public purse to help support children this information must become known. There will be many instances where the pension will be virtually the sole income of a custodial parent. Many custodial parents are low income earners and no other maintenance will be payable. In discussing this matter we should not forget that this group makes up a substantial number of those in receipt of the pension at present.

This clause provides for a penalty of $1,000. If a man or a woman is attempting to evade paying maintenance, if they do not have the money or they have got themselves into debt, a fine of $1,000 will virtually be laughable. It is not a real sanction in attempting to get people to accept their responsibilities. Throughout the Bill there are huge financial penalties, which will be burdensome for small businesses and others, but there does not seem to be any regard for trying to make the system work, other than trying to make it look as though one is trying to make it work.

There are other provisions about the courts sending the maintenance orders on. The Bill goes on to deal with the debts due to the Commonwealth and how they shall be distributed. As I said, I support the principle of the Bill and I certainly hope that it will work. However, there is one major flaw in it which I hope the Government will correct. It is interesting to note this statement in the Minister's second reading speech:
The government is committed to ensuring that by 1990 no child need live in poverty.
The child support scheme is central to achieving that objective.

That is one aspect of this legislation that cannot pass without comment. The Government seems very significantly to pin its hopes on this legislation, along with the family assistance package which was brought in recently, to meet its commitment that no child will live in poverty by 1990. We all know that the family assistance package has been significantly eroded for the many thousands of families whose rent has very smartly been increased. There are many other ways in which the Government needs to deal with the reasons why many children are living in poverty or very poor circumstances. As recently as December last, the chairman of the National Committee of Non-Government Organisations for the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless, Bishop Peter Hollingworth, indicated that 850,000 children were living in poverty, mostly because of the high housing costs their parents are forced to pay. Over 700,000 Australian households are living in poverty after they have paid for their housing. Some people are paying up to 60 per cent of their low incomes to provide shelter for themselves and their children.

The Smith Family quite recently confirmed these figures. In October last it released figures showing that after five years of the Hawke Government 700,000 more people are living in poverty. In any event, the Bill we are dealing with tonight will not solve the problem foremost of these people who are not likely to get much in the way of maintenance outside the pension. One hundred thousand Australians are homeless and 20,000 of them are teenagers or younger children. One hundred and sixty thousand people in this country are on public housing waiting lists. The Australian Council of Social Service, as recently as November 1987, painted a similar grim picture.

The Government claims that the family assistance package is designed to help solve these problems by the target date of 1990 but, according to the studies done by the Social Welfare Research Centre on the impact of the package, in 1990 400,000 children will still be living in poverty.

There are many other areas of concern: the Government's housing policy, the cost of mortgage repayments for many low income earners who have been enticed into buying as a means of trying to prevent the cost of rent going up, the drop in the number of housing starts in 1986-87, the predicted fall that is expected for this year and the amount of interest that people are paying on their mortgages. These are all major factors contributing to child poverty. They will not be redressed by the Child Support Bill. There are other measures which the Government must take.

I refer to the question of health care. Many of the families we are concerned about are not in a position to take out private health cover. They are forced to rely on the Medicare system. Approximately 100,000 Australians are on waiting lists in need of surgery. Those who have income are paying 1.25 per cent of their income, in spite of promises that they would pay only one per cent. This goes nowhere near the actual cost. They are really paying 3.15 per cent by way of levy. The rest goes in through the taxation system. Taxpayers are paying a very high price for a very poor service. Since Medicare was introduced items have constantly been removed from the Medicare list, both in the service area and in the pharmaceuticals area. So the people at the lower end of the income scale who have to depend on Medicare are paying a great deal and getting far less than they were getting a few years ago.

The number of public hospital beds under Labor has declined by more than 10 per cent at the same time as this Government's policies have meant that there are more people in the queues. Many of them could afford to cover themselves with health insurance but they do not have to. They are in the queues keeping the people who need to be there and who are entitled to be there at the back of the queue. If we look at the annual report of the Department of Health we find that in 1986 the number of public hospital beds was 66,159, whereas in 1983 there were 74,229 public hospital beds. With a policy like Medicare one would have expected the numbers to have gone in the other direction.

There are many reasons why children are living in poverty. I have referred only to some of them. I remind the Government that it cannot rely on the Child Support Bill to get it off the hook in regard to its promise that by 1990 no child will live in poverty. There are many other things the Government needs to do in addition to smartening up the arrangements for the collection of money which ought to be paid by way of maintenance.

In the minds of many the question of access to the children of the marriage is very significant. Many non-custodial parents, men and women, take the view that why should they pay maintenance if they are not getting access. It is a real and deep problem. The question of access, of having adequate resources for Family Court counsellors really to get close to the people who have problems in coming to terms with their situation, is essential. I will not develop that thesis tonight. However, we cannot talk about maintenance without acknowledging that access is a very significant area which I hope the Government will focus on before too long.

I urge the Senate to support our amendment for the reasons I have referred to. I believe that the Bill should be amended to accommodate it. I also believe that the Senate should set up a monitoring committee to oversee the regulations of which, as I have indicated, there will be many, to oversee the problems that will be faced by businesses as they get used to this legislation, accommodate it and attempt to alleviate those problems, and see that generally the legislation works and that parents come to terms with contributing what they should be contributing towards the support of their children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for their support for the Bill and acknowledge the contribution made by many of them to this debate. Unlike some debates in this place, generally speaking it was of a high standard, with only a couple of exceptions. There would appear to be general agreement that there must be some reform to ensure that more parents provide support for their children. There would appear to be general agreement that as a key issue for government the poverty of Australian children looms large.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall go through the complaints and the criticisms of the Bill, so far as we have been able to record them, taking them one by one. First, Opposition senators, in particular Senators Vanstone, Walters and Knowles, complained about the Government's delay in introducing the child support scheme. I think we should look at the history of how long it has taken to get the Bill in before we talk about delay. Immediately after the Government's election in 1983 it moved to establish the national maintenance collection inquiry. That inquiry reported in 1984. The Government did not act on all of its recommendations, for three main reasons: one, it did not adequately address the question of the amount of maintenance orders; two, it did nothing about seeing that maintenance orders are regularly updated; and three, it did not address the problem of the small number of custodial parents with maintenance arrangements. The Government therefore decided that far more fundamental and far-reaching reform was necessary. Cabinet then established a special sub-committee on maintenance and it published a discussion paper in October of 1986. In March 1987 we announced that we were proceeding with the child support scheme, and that is the centrepiece of this Bill that we are debating tonight.

It is interesting to note that Mr Howe, the Minister for Social Security, in his tour of the United States in January came across a great many people who had set up similar child support schemes in the various States of the United States and their main comment to him was that they were impressed at just how fast the Australian Government had been able to move. They understand the complexities that are involved in a move of this kind. They know that we have not delayed; rather, that we have been thorough, careful and have made sure that all of the issues have been resolved. The people in the United States know that we have not delayed; it is only people here who do not seem to be able to get the message. The other claim that I find even more irritating--

TALK.START.PARA: —Only because of what has happened in the past. Nothing was done in 1975.

—I will devote some special time tonight to Senator Walters. Just be patient. We are going to get there. Senators Vanstone and Reid-and I might say Senator Walters as well-have continually made the point that the Government has done no more than implement that which Senator Durack proposed some time back. I think we should have a look at what Senator Durack proposed. His propositions included a number of methods of dealing with these problems. For instance, he suggested that we should deal with defaulters by throwing them in goal. I would have thought that most modern societies had decided that debtors prisons should have been got rid of 100 years ago. In some places it took a long time to do so but one would not have thought that such a harsh and ineffective means of punishment would be appropriate in the modern day. Senator Reid suggested we are simply implementing Senator Durack's Bill but I think she will have to look long and hard to find any provision like that in the Bill that is before us tonight.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is misrepresenting, as I understand it, the speeches of both--
—You don't know your Standing Orders.

—If the honourable senator wouldn't mind I would like to finish my point or order before he says whether it is a point of order or not. My point of order is that Senator Reid, Senator Walters and I are being misrepresented. What we have been saying is that the Government should have accepted Senator Durack's amendments, not that that is simply all it is doing now. If the Minister does not understand that, I suggest that he refer to the Hansard.
—Minister, will you accept the explanation from Senator Vanstone?
—No, I certainly will not, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—All right. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I was trying to point out that we believe that there were great deficiencies in the legislation Senator Durack proposed and that that was why it was not accepted. Furthermore, Senator Durack proposed to prevent the courts looking at social security entitlements when assessing maintenance. Again, one will not find that in this Bill. The family law amendment legislation completely overhauls the criteria for the courts to consider social security entitlements.
—Has your speech writer spoken to one of your other Ministers?

—One good thing about speech writers is that fortunately they have, in me, someone who can read, and who does not battle like the honourable senator did earlier. If one turns to the real argument in the Opposition's amendment, the question of compulsion, one realises what the Opposition is all about. The Opposition's amendment refers to people who are supporting their children without resort to pensions and benefits and expresses concern that agreements in those cases not be required to be registered with the Child Support Agency. I think that is a fair rendition of what the honourable senator proposed. There is clearly great confusion in the Opposition about what is being proposed, so I hope that I will be given the opportunity to explain the Government's policy in some detail.

SPEECH.PARA: A major defect in child support is the lack of any national register of child support orders and agreements. Currently they are filed in magistrates courts, supreme courts, in Family Court of Australia registries and in all sorts of places all over the country. In the end that creates enormous problems for those who deal with the system. I will give an example. If someone gets an order in a far-flung part of Australia, shall we say, Broome, Kununurra or wherever, and then the custodial parent chooses to move to a capital city, say on the east coast, be it Sydney or Melbourne, any attempt to vary that order obviously meets with immediate problems. Often it has to be dealt with in the place of origin of the order. If that is the case, that involves enormous difficulties for parents in relation to travel and it becomes a real trial for anyone to participate in enforcement proceedings. Getting orders from the clerk of the court on one side of the country across to the other is an extraordinarily difficult exercise for anyone to undertake, let alone a person who is a single custodial parent who is very often suffering from deprived circumstances.

The first thing we wish to do is to move to a comprehensive national register so that separated parents can enforce orders without the practical difficulties I have just outlined coming into play wherever they live in Australia. Whenever a custodial parent is not on a pension or benefit there is no compulsion to participate in this scheme in any way. I think that is the fundamental misunderstanding. All orders of the courts made after the commencement of the Child Support Act will be entered on the register, so we will achieve the national register that I mentioned before. But whenever the custodial parent is not on a pension he or she can simply choose not to participate in the scheme by just notifying the Registrar to do nothing. If that occurs nothing will happen. The order is simply on the national register for either parent to enforce or to vary if they choose to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they will be on the register.

—Senator Vanstone, in speaking about the amendment, referred to cases where the parties agree not to participate. The Bill looks after this by permitting the custodial parent to opt out. What it does not do is what Senator Walters thinks that it should do.
—But they will need to get themselves off the register.

—I will answer Senator Vanstone's interjection in a moment. The scheme permits the non-custodial parent to choose to have the scheme not apply. Surely the whole ethos, the whole ethic, of the Bill runs against that. If the non-custodial parent could decide it could force more and more custodial parents into putting up with lengthy delays in receiving maintenance, lengthy delays which ensure their children have to live in poverty. That is something we will simply not allow. That is why in those cases where the custodial parent wants it to happen collection will occur. The Government is committed to ensuring that custodial parents receive their maintenance on a timely, regular basis. If we were to listen to the Opposition on this occasion, that just would not be possible.
—That is rubbish.

—I think the honourable senator's suggestions are rubbish, and I am trying to outline why. If a custodial parent makes the judgment that he or she needs the assistance of the Child Support Agency to get that maintenance on a timely, regular basis, we do not believe that we should say, `You cannot use this agency to get your money, you have to go out and get it yourself. If there are delays, if something goes wrong, then you can notify us'. What does that mean? That means we are going to say to those custodial parents, `For a few months you will have to put up with nothing and explain to the children why there is not enough food on the table every night'. I do not expect Senator Vanstone or anyone on that side to understand the problems of the poor. Nonetheless, we are going to make sure that the poor are looked after, and that is what this is about. I assure the Senate that where a custodial parent, who is not on a pension or benefit--

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is a well known fact, and it has been said by so many people, that the Labor Government is out of touch with the poor and that we are the ones who are well aware of what the poor are going through. Senator Richardson can in no way say that.
—Order! There is no point of order, Senator Walters.
—I assure the Senate that where a custodial parent, who is not on a pension or benefit, does not want to use the agency, he or she will not be compelled to do so.
—But they will still be registered.

—Yes, they will still be registered; the order will still be registered. However, they will not be compelled to use the agency. I know that the issues are complex but I cannot give a more simple, clear or unequivocal assurance than that. Even Senator Vanstone will have to concede that.

SPEECH.PARA: I said I would give Senator Walters an honourable mention, and this is only the beginning as I want to get to the main part later. Senator Walters also argued that non-custodial parents should be required to have maintenance automatically deducted from their salaries only if they default. The whole basis of the Bill runs against this and we do not want to continue any uncertainty in the income of custodial parents or any difficulty. As far as is possible we aim to ensure that those parents can count on a regular amount of maintenance. That is what we are on about, but no-one is ever sure what the honourable senator is on about. (Quorum formed)

We believe there is no stigma attached to automatic withholding. We do not want to create such a stigma. If we were to agree with the suggestion that Senator Walters and Senator Vanstone have put up, default would be the trigger, and that is when there would be an automatic stigma. We just do not see the need for that. We will not put custodial parents through any period of insecurity, especially when there is no need. I think they have had years and years of that and, if we are going to end that insecurity and difficulty, we ought to end it now.

The next question that was raised by a number of Opposition speakers was the burden on employers. I understand that this places a burden on employers, and obviously any scheme of this kind must. I think the trick is to try to minimise those burdens. There has been extensive consultation with employer groups in an attempt to do just that. Employers will have to make deductions only when advised to do so by the Child Support Agency. They do not have to seek information from the employees on whatever maintenance orders might be in force against them. They will deduct the same amount each pay day, just as they do for credit unions and other organisations. They will be required to do a great deal less than under the present system of garnishee orders which Senator Panizza referred to. I would have thought that we could have done no more.

I assure Senator Newman that the penalties about which she complained are maximum amounts. There is no doubt about that. I understand that the Commissioner of Taxation is aware of the difficulties faced by employers who use tax stamps. I think that was raised by Senator Powell earlier in the debate. He will certainly be taking steps to inform them of their duties and will make sure that adequate information is sent to them. I think Senator Powell and perhaps Senator Newman raised the question of marriage counselling and the level of funding for that. The Government remains strongly committed to maintaining that service to families, to help them form stable and healthy marriages. We will continue, even in tight budgetary circumstances, to review that amount, and I hope we can make more available.

Senator Walters made some extraordinary claims which I believe I should attempt to answer in the time left to me. First was what I think was a fairly typical claim by Senator Walters, that means testing the family allowance has forced people into the gutter. The reality is that a family has to be on $50,000 or more a year to be affected by the family allowance income test. That just shows her empathy with the poor. If she really believes that anyone on $50,000 has that big a problem, I feel more sorry for her now than I did before. She also said that the Government has not provided one additional cent for families with children and a dependent spouse. I do not know what the families who have just started receiving the family allowance supplement think of that-$22 a week for each child and $28 a week for older children. The Government's approach in hard economic times is to target the assistance to the families who need it most. Senator Walters, that is not the people on $50,000 a year or more; it is the people on a great deal less than that. Let us remember that it was the Opposition that wanted to cut $11 billion from expenditures. I wonder what poor families would escape. I know that Senator Reid referred to the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) in trying to support her argument. I will quote the Director, Mark Lyon, who said this in reference to the family allowance supplement:
. . . is the first significant move that any government has made in trying to reduce the number of families living in poverty.

When we look at the record of the Fraser-Howard Government on that score, we see that in 1976 the number of children under the poverty line was 370,000. After seven years of those clumsy hands at the tiller, in 1983 Howard and Fraser had managed to increase that number to 830,000. The legacy that we got from Howard and Fraser was a lousy $10 a week for families on social security as child payment. The Hawke Labor Government has increased those payments in every Budget since then. The $500m family package introduced the family allowance supplement. That is 120 per cent higher than the equivalent in March 1983, and 180 per cent higher for older children. Child payments have been increased for both families on social security and for working families.

I will give honourable senators some more comparisons. Additional pension benefits were cut by 4.2 per cent for each year that Senator Walters's lot was in power. They have increased by 10.2 per cent a year in real terms under Labor, and 16 per cent, by the way, for 13- to 15-year-olds. Overall, pensions and benefits relating to children fell by 35 per cent in real terms under the previous Government; they have increased by 59 per cent in real terms under this Government. That is the real difference in approach between the parties. We have done something for the poor; the Opposition has done nothing except to remark that the only people who are poor are those receiving under $50,000 a year.

If one looks at the targeting that I mentioned earlier, one sees that today about 60 per cent of spending on family assistance goes to the poorest 30 per cent of families. A family in receipt of $400 a week with two teenagers and paying rent will get $27 a week. That is equivalent to a pay rise of $45 a week or 11 per cent. Liberal Party election promises threatened to cut $28 a week from the income of that same family. That is the difference in approach between the parties.

Senator Reid referred to a research institute. Let me refer to the Australian Institute of Family Studies, which stated that up to one-third of families with children would be worse off under a Howard government. So one is faced with a comparison between a policy characterised by inequity and one that targets assistance for the most needy. If one gets down to the bare bones of those people whom we are trying to help, a low income family with four children aged eight, 10, 13 and 15 would get $15 a week under Howard's child care allowance and $100 a week under the family package. I would have thought that that sort of comparison, even for Senator Walters, was pretty obvious. That characterises the differences in approach. Senator Powell made a number of other points.

TALK.START.PARA: —Remember the poverty traps.

—I gave Senator Walters's contribution five minutes. I think that is about all it was worth. (Quorum formed) I want to answer some of the queries raised by Senator Powell in her contribution. She raised the issue of advance maintenance for those not helped by this scheme. The Government will address the adequacy of income support for sole parents who do not get maintenance in the context of the Cass review and the Fogarty report-the report of the Child Support Consultative Group. I hope that she can hang on until we have done that. She also raised the question of legal aid funding. I think the Government is considering the likely impact of this scheme on legal aid funding. We shall examine our response. We take into account her comments on the role of community legal centres.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell also raised the question of the centre at Wollongong as against the Noble Park family conciliation centre. We need to understand that there was a pilot scheme at Noble Park to test different ways of providing family conciliation. On the one hand, the evaluator reported that it was a unique model of service which holds great promise in the family area. On the other hand, the scheme adopted at Wollongong, which was on a one-step basis with all the counselling and advisory services under one roof, was found to duplicate services in other parts of the community. Therefore, we have decided to continue funding Noble Park but not to continue to fund Wollongong.

The Hawke Government is maintaining its commitment to helping children in poverty. We will establish a Register and a method of collection so that custodial parents who for so long have had so much difficulty in ensuring regular maintenance payments-for the majority, maintenance payments have been not only rare but impossible to receive-can all get some hope of a fair go. A system will now operate which will enable parents to contribute appropriately to the welfare of their children. Some have never done this in the past. For all the talk of the Hawke Government being slow to act, the reality is that in seven years the Fraser Government did nothing on this score except to announce a promise in its death throes in the election campaign in 1983.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions for the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), partly in relation to specific clauses of the Child Support Bill 1987. I will tie them into certain comments that he made in response to the second reading debate. As I understood the Minister's reply with respect to the Opposition's amendment, it was that, if we were successful in our amendment and couples who were not making a drain on the taxpayer could not only opt out, as they can, but were not registered, having regard to other clauses in the Bill, the success of pursuing them down that path would mean that at a later date, if a custodial parent changed his or her mind-that is, the arrangement between the parents failed and he or she, whoever was the payer, failed to pay-there would be some extraordinary delay in the custodial parent getting his or her agreement registered. As I understood the Minister's remarks, the amendment that we put forward ought not be proceeded with because it would mean an inordinate delay when there was a breakdown between two parties. At this stage we are talking about parties who make no drain on the taxpayer. It was suggested that if they were not registered at all there would be some sort of delay. As I noted the Minister's comment-and I am not a shorthand expert-he said something like, `We do not think it is appropriate to say, ``You can't use this Agency and make those people wait''.' In other words, that means that they ought not be able to exclude themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of those remarks of the Minister, I ask whether they apply to people who, but for regulations made under clause 19 of this legislation, the Government is going to exclude. It is all very well for the Minister, as I understand it, to attempt to dish some sort of mini-bucket over the Opposition for suggesting that certain people ought not even be put on the Register and for the Government then to have, by virtue of clause 19, the opportunity-the Minister may well seek advice on this point-to exclude by regulation vast categories of people. The Minister and I both know that the reason is that at the moment his administration cannot cope with providing this maintenance system to all those people. I ask the Minister to respond in terms of the people that his Government intends excluding under clause 19. Will he relate them to his second reading remarks and will he also give us a detailed list of his current proposals of who ought be excluded under clause 19 by regulation?

TALK.START.PARA: —If we go back to the explanatory memorandum, of which all honourable senators have a copy, I will read out the answer. It is on page 3, down towards the bottom, if the honourable senator would care to look:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Regulations, it is possible to exclude specified liabilities or liabilities of a specified class. It is intended that this exclusion power will be used to restrict the collection of child maintenance to the types announced by the Minister for Social Security in his statement of 24 March 1987.

Broadly speaking, the Registrar will be authorised to collect periodic amounts payable under all orders and maintenance agreements that relate to children of parents who separate after the commencement of this Bill, or-where the parents have not co-habited-to children born after that date. Where the payee is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit, the Registrar will be able, upon application, to collect the maintenance whether the child was born before or after the commencement of this Act-
whether the parties separated before or after the commencement of the Act. It continues:

In his statement, the Minister for Social Security also proposed that, where a child maintenance order or agreement has been lodged for collection with a State or Territory collection agency (including a court), maintenance will be collected by the Registrar. This will now extend to spousal maintenance orders or agreements lodged for collection with such an agency. To enable all these cases to be transferred to the Register, the Bill provides for formal arrangements to be entered into between the Governor-General and the Governor of a State or the Administrator of the Northern Territory or Norfolk Island. In respect of other Territories (including the Australian Capital Territory), the Registrar may make arrangements for the transfer directly.

Other categories of orders and agreements may be excluded by regulation. For example, it is expected that certain classes of spousal maintenance will be excluded in accordance with the announcement of the rules for the extension of the scheme to spousal maintenance on introduction of this Bill in the Parliament. Spousal maintenance will also be collectable where there is a child maintenance liability, or the person is over the age of 45 . . .
Does that answer Senator Vanstone's question?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am sorry, but it does not. Let me be somewhat more specific. Let us turn to page 4 of the explanatory memorandum-and I thank the Minister for reading it to me at a pace roughly that at which I would normally read it. As I understand it, that leaves out people who have separated prior to the commencement of this Bill or, where the parents have not cohabited, children born prior to that date. Those people who are not draining the state are totally left out. Is that the case?
—That is the case.

—I thought I had understood that part properly. Given that that is the case, is not the Government saying-and let me put my language on it rather than the Minister's-that this child maintenance scheme is not a child maintenance scheme; it is not designed to help all mothers who want to gain or collect maintenance from fathers who have ticked off and are not paying; it is a scheme designed to assist the Government to recoup the cost of the sole parent's benefit, and anyone who is not collecting that benefit, quite frankly, can go jump? Is that not what the clause says? Has not the Minister just agreed with me that it says that? Has not the Minister told me that he could not give a hoot what happens to people who are not drawing from the state? I would be happy for an answer to that question before I proceed to further ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes it is a matter of achieving the possible. The figure of 200,000 that Senator Vanstone referred to earlier probably is correct. We would not have wanted them all to turn up at the agency on the first day. But that does not mean that we will not get around to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it absolutely extraordinary. Honourable senators here, and people who have been listening on broadcast days when the Child Support Bill has been debated in this chamber and in the other place, have heard members and senators on the other side pass this Bill off as a Bill designed to reform the maintenance system, a Bill that will give benefit to all families, and heard them raving on about what they are doing with the family assistance package, when-with the greatest of respect-that applies to a limited proportion of the population. That is yet another example of where the Government's so-called family concern stops. The Minister has admitted exactly that. I cannot believe that he has admitted it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give the Minister the opportunity to give a better answer because for him to say that the top paragraph on page 4 of the explanatory memorandum basically means that unless people are drawing on the government, the Government does not give a hoot about whether they are having trouble collecting their maintenance payments, indicates that this Bill is not about maintenance collection and about making life easier for sole parents who are left with children: it is only a Bill about the Government recouping some of the costs of sole parents who are draining the Commonwealth. For the Minister to respond, saying, `They are excluded now but we might get around to them'-hunky-dory, kneecap New South Wales-that is just not acceptable and I want a better answer. I give the Minister the opportunity to give a better answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want a better question.
—The Minister could not get a better question. Whether this Government cares about all children in the community or only the children of pension beneficiaries-that is the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill sets out for the future of Australia and Australian children, new hope. That is what it does. No government can attempt to redress every problem of the past in one Bill. That just never will be possible. What I said in the second reading debate, as anyone who had listened would know, is that we will be moving to the Register. I did not say that the Register would happen tomorrow afternoon. That cannot be done. I said `moving to the Register'.
—Totally misleading.

—Senator Newman should have listened to what I said but she did not, as usual. So I have not misled anybody. I have talked about moving to the Register. That is exactly what this Government is going to do. This Bill provides the hope for Australian families that those opposite never provided in all their years in government.

—I am somewhat bemused because it seems to me that the Opposition lost out on the amendment to the second reading motion, which, on my reading-and I will ask the Minister a question on this-asked the Government to do, in large measure, the very thing the Opposition is now suggesting the Government should not be doing; that is, that the Register should include people who are not a drain on the government purse, as I think Senator Vanstone referred to them. The Minister has explained to us that the Register will operate for all people who are not in receipt of pensions or benefits, only beyond the date of the passage of this legislation. The Minister is ruling out any kind of retrospectivity of people going on the Register. Another point, which I would have thought the Opposition would be interested in, is whether the Minister feels that this is what is happening in this part of the committee stage, that he is now under fire for doing something which he did not do in not accepting the second reading motion amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Minister would like to respond, I am happy to sit down but what I want to raise relates to that point, so it might save him getting up twice. The comments we have just heard from Senator Powell clarify for me why all the people I know vote either Liberal or Labor and not Democrat. I do not need to say any more than that. I cannot understand that an honourable senator in this place believes that to say that certain people should not be included does not mean that they would be deprived of the option of being included if they so desired. What we were seeking to achieve in that amendment was that people who were no drain on the taxpayer would not only be able to opt out, as the Bill provides, but would also not have their agreement registered on this Register. By some extraordinary feat Senator Powell has managed to turn that into--
—Gymnastics.

—It is intellectual gymnastics, if that is not putting it at too high a point. She implies that the Opposition means by that that people ought not be able to opt in. That is quite a ludicrous proposition. She dangles the favourite words used by a lot of honourable senators and honourable members who would like honourable senators in the Opposition to oppose something-that there is a retrospective element in the question that I am putting to the Minister about catching people who have either separated prior to the commencement of this Bill or who have children born prior to the commencement of this Bill. The honourable senator is suggesting that for me to seek to move that those people ought to have the opportunity to opt in is, in some way, making the legislation retrospective. I think the honourable senator ought to have a quick look at several of the classic debates on retrospective legislation and she will see that in this case it simply does not apply.

SPEECH.PARA: We are asking the Minister to explain why those people who are not beneficiaries of a pension, who separated prior to the commencement of this Bill and had children born prior to this, will not be able to opt in. He begs the question. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in the other place has made the point in the second paragraph of the second reading speech that if a person is on a State Register for the collection of a maintenance agreement and is not getting welfare, that person will be lucky enough to be grabbed by this Bill. What that means is that if a person is in the category of people we are talking about-not receiving maintenance, with children and separated before the commencement of this Bill, and not going through a State collection agency-that person misses out. A person cannot opt into this Bill by choice. Is that not the case? A person cannot opt in.

If I am right in that, and that is the way it was explained to me, I would like to ask this question: What action will the Government take to advertise to people in that category who are now looking after themselves that in order to cover their backs they ought to pass up looking after themselves and paying maintenance arrangements privately and register with a State agency because that is the only way they will get the benefit of this Bill? What will the Government do to advertise to people who will be excluded by virtue of the first paragraph of the Minister second reading speech when under the second paragraph they could get some benefit but in order to get that benefit they have to register with a State agency to collect their maintenance? That is the only way the legislation will catch them; otherwise all these 200,000 people will be left out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just go through what the Bill covers and what it can do from here.
—You have done that.

—Sometimes I have to do it a lot of times to get it through to the honourable senator, but I am actually addressing Senator Vanstone at the moment. The Bill covers everybody who separates from here on in. That is not in debate. It covers those who are most in need from the past; that is, those on pensions and benefits. There is no dispute about that. It covers all those people who are in dire straits and desperate need. It gives the Government the power to act by regulation in the future to cover those who separated prior to the passing of the Bill and that is what the Government will do. In so far as advocating the course of action that Senator Vanstone has outlined, the Government has no objection with people doing that. At least in coming to terms with the State agencies the Government will have control of the timing. What we are really talking about here is the administrative necessity of introducing a very big scheme and making sure that it is done in stages. These stages mean that those who are most in need are dealt with first. Surely that is just another demonstration, another example, of the Government's commitment to equity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just briefly ask the Minister to give roughly a yes or no answer to this matter. I agree with what he is saying, that people on pensions, the people prior to the commencement of the Bill that we are talking about-I will not repeat all the words; honourable senators know who I am talking about-will be dealt with. There is no disagreement about that. The Minister says that these are the people who are most in need. The proposition being put to the Minister is that he is not looking after the woman who tries to save the taxpayer-that is not to say that anyone on a pension is not trying-by getting some sort of job and getting off the pension. She is off the pension, but she has still got the essence of a maintenance problem-the problem we are trying to get at with this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We agree with the Bill because we think far too many women have a gigantic hassle in collecting their maintenance. So here is a woman who is not on a pension or benefit. She has got a job by luck or by hook or crook. She has decided that she has got the option-some women do not have the option-of getting a job and not being a burden on the taxpayer. She is battling to look after her kids and she is married to some creep who ticks off. The Minister is telling me that her need to have that maintenance is somehow less just because she is earning her money and someone else is getting it on a pension or benefit. The income they are receiving might be the same. The woman who is earning might be earning an amount just equivalent to the pension. But the Minister is saying that he is not going to help her collect her maintenance.

That is one example I put before the committee to indicate the point I am trying to make. This Bill is not about pensions; it is about maintenance. People on pensions are in one category when it comes to collecting maintenance. But there is another category; that is the person who has a job which pays just at, or maybe just above, the pension level. What about the woman-I will not use the words `by luck, hook or crook'-who remarries? Nonetheless there is still a family there-children born of a previous marriage with a maintenance liability. Let us not confuse it with pensions. There is a maintenance liability there. The Minister is saying that because she has chosen to remarry he will not help her or her family to collect the maintenance. What he is basically saying to the women of Australia is, `We will help you collect your maintenance but, my heavens, if you remarry, watch out'. All the people who are included because they are collecting a benefit will do anything to release themselves from getting that benefit and the Minister is going to drop them off or, more specifically, he is not including them now.
