TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that these people are not being included now. There can be no denying that. As I have said, it is a staged process. What we are dealing with in the first stage are those who are in most need. Nothing Senator Vanstone has just said changes that. That is not to say that there are not others who have some need. The people who have some need will be dealt with. They will come under the ambit of powers in the Bill, but it will be dealt with by regulation. That is all we are saying. We are covering the bulk now and, over time, we will get to the others. As to the specific commitment about when this will occur, I think we will have to wait to see how the Register goes, but we are not putting this matter on the never-never. It is a matter of high priority and as soon as it is possible it will be done.

—Mr Chairman, I wish to refer to the example that Senator Vanstone put so very clearly to the Minister, of who is in greatest need. We have the two categories of supporting parents. Both may have been issued orders of maintenance against their defaulting partners. One is doing some part time work, perhaps through no fault of her own, and getting a small pension. Another, who has been more successful, has a job and is determined not to be a burden on the taxpayer. That woman is paying child-minding fees and struggling with her low paid job to keep her family together because her defaulting ex-spouse does not give her a penny. Yet the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has the effrontery to say that the woman getting a pension or benefit is more in need than the woman who is struggling to keep her family together and not become a burden on the taxpayer. How can the Minister possibly say that a supporting parent on a regular pension is more in need than the woman I have just described? The only reason the Government has given priority to the woman on a supporting parent's benefit over the woman struggling to keep a job and bring up her children without gathering in maintenance from her defaulting partner is that the Government will recoup $192.8m in 1989-90. That is the only reason in the book the Government could possibly have for giving a woman who has the security of a continuing pension coming in priority over the woman I have described. That is the reason we say the Government is not interested and never has been interested in giving true priority to women with families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make the general point first in relation to the people about whom Senator Walters is speaking that the Government has made it more and more attractive for women in that situation to opt out of the social security benefit schemes and into the work force. That has been part of the packages that the Government has announced in the last two Budgets. It has done so by working on poverty traps, and I believe in that respect the Government has had some success. But in referring exactly to the woman in the situation about which Senator Walters is speaking, if that woman wants to collect maintenance the odds are-I think pretty strong odds-that she will be registered with a State agency and the Commonwealth can pick her up anyway.

—So she literally has to go and register with a State agency before the Government will pick her up? Is that what the Minister is saying? The Australian Democrats, who are accusing us of not being interested in the real poor and of making all sorts of odd amendments, do not understand the situation in any way. Surely to heavens Senator Powell will now agree with us that this group of women who are desperately trying to keep themselves and their families out of this area of social security need the Government's first priority-not its second priority; not later when time permits-and not just take into account the fact that if the Government gives handouts to those who are dependent on the taxpayers' money, the Government, through this legislation, will get all that lovely money back. If the Government gives first priority to the people who really deserve it, I will begin to believe the Government has its priorities right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill will establish a method of collecting money so that it can be paid out. I resent and reject the criticism that it is all about getting money in. I do not think we should get too carried away with the use of the word `agency' as though being registered with a State agency is in some way a big deal. In most cases that will mean a local magistrates court, which is where the great majority of people get their maintenance orders anyway. This woman will not have suddenly to decide to go and register; she is almost certainly registered already. What the Government is saying is that those State agencies will be picked up by the Commonwealth.
—How many of these women are already registered in the States?
—There are no figures on that, Senator Walters. No-one in the country can answer that question.

—If the Government is going to pick up the State agencies, and is going to do the registering, can it not get from the States the number of people that will be involved? How in the heck has the Government made an estimate for 1987-88 of gains of $7.6m and how has it made its estimate for 1989-90 of $192m to be grabbed in if it has not got those figures and cannot get them and no one knows them? I would be very interested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that people do not understand the complexity of even attempting to get these figures. Around Australia there are something like 900 magistrates courts. All of them file these orders, written on bits of paper, in all sorts of little drawers. In Queensland alone there are more than 200 of these courts. There is no central register of any of their information. They are all filed in drawers in the basements of magistrates courts spread over the length and breadth of Australia. The Government is saying that it will now set up a central register so that, finally, the chaotic administration of maintenance orders that currently exists right across the country will come to an end. I cannot wave a magic wand over those 900 courthouses and suddenly put all the information they have on a register. It takes time, and time is what the Government will take.

—The Minister has not answered my question. I asked him how there can be an estimate in the Minister's second reading speech, if the Government has no idea of the figures, that the net gains for 1987-88 will be $7.6m and by 1989-90 will reach $192.8m. How come those estimates have been made if the Government has no idea of the figures that the States will hand over?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does have figures available on social security recipients. It can, therefore, make estimates on the basis of the figures it has on them and on the basis of those who are likely to receive social security benefits in the future. One can make projections. That does not change the answer I just gave Senator Walters, and there would not seem to be much point in repeating what I have just said, for it does not seem to be getting through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be appropriate at this stage to acknowledge the presence in the gallery on the Government side of Meredith Edwards who has made such a contribution to the presentation of this legislation. I am sure that all honourable senators wish her well in any contribution that she may be seeking to make in the development of a formula which is suspected of being the second part of this legislation. I think she will need all the luck in the world in getting to that point.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the point that Senator Walters and I are trying to get the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) to concede. I do not move among the sorts of rich mates that the Minister moves among, so perhaps he does not understand the point. We are referring to a woman who either has a child born or separates from her husband before the commencement of this Act, who is earning an income roughly the equivalent of a pension and who is not receiving a benefit. If any publicity is given to this little let-out clause that the Government has allowed itself-clause 19-she will be given the greatest incentive that ever was to give up her job and get on a pension quick smart. The Government is asking such a person to make a decision, between the time when she hears about this provision and the time when the Act commences, on whether she can continue to look after herself and bear the burden of trying to get the maintenance out of her husband or whether she would rather go on the pension in order to get the Government to get the maintenance out of her husband.

Surely the Minister understands that women who are earning no more than or roughly the equivalent of the pension or who have remarried-not into the sort of wealthy family with whom the Minister may be accustomed to mixing-may regard the opportunity to get the Government to collect her maintenance payments as being all too much to pass up and may shift onto receiving benefits. The Minister still has not explained why he judges those people who are earning no more than the pension to be somehow in less need.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments are directed to you, Mr Chairman. When Senator Vanstone resumed her seat a while ago I immediately sought the call but did not receive it. I thought then that probably it would be best if my comments were to wait until the consideration of this clause had concluded. However, I am not sure how long it will take for that to happen, so perhaps I should make my comments now. When Senator Vanstone was speaking she used some rather colourful language which I do not think added to the dignity of the Senate. I ask you whether it is possible, even with Senator Vanstone's concurrence, to have that colourful language expunged from the record when the printed report of this debate is published.

—Order! I do not think I want to have a debate on this subject. I have been in correspondence with Senator Vanstone. Senator Vanstone has told me that she did not say what I understood her to say. We will discuss that matter later. I do not want a debate on particular words at this point. We will leave it to the Hansard record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be necessary for me to repeat what I have already said a few times. I would have thought that the main incentive for the woman in the position to which Senator Vanstone refers would be to ensure that she is registered with a State agency, which, as I explained, is usually a local magistrates court, rather than to opt out of the work force. A woman who does that does so in the certain knowledge that by being registered with that State agency she will be picked up by the Child Support Agency in the very near future. I would have thought that that is what she would do.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as publicity is concerned, the Department of Social Security has already taken steps to begin to notify community groups, lawyers, accountants and what have you of the details of what this legislation seeks to do. That being the case, it is hoped that the message can be spread throughout the community at the earliest possible moment. But a register of this size cannot be prepared and an undertaking of this dimension cannot be achieved without time being taken. It cannot happen tomorrow afternoon. No government could ever make it so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that this will be my final question. I think the Opposition accepts that all these things cannot be done at once. What we have been asking for is some indication as to why the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) judges people receiving roughly the same income as others to be in less need. What we have said is that the Minister obviously is choosing that which he thinks can save the Government money rather than accepting the principle that all of those women are in need. But we have got nowhere pressing that point. It has been put to the Minister four or five times. Each time we have done so it has been a little like hitting our heads against a brick wall.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the second point. Given that the Opposition accepts that it would be difficult to do all these things at once and given that the Government obviously has decided that it can do a portion of these things immediately and that therefore the Government has some idea of its administrative capacity to shift into this area, why is it then not possible for the Government to provide some sort of schedule which would give not only the Opposition but also members of the public an insight into what is intended by the provisions in clause 19?

What exclusions are intended and at what rate will the Government deal with these other areas which the Minister glibly says that the Government will get around to dealing with? Given that the Government understands what it is doing, why can it not provide us with some idea of its timing in dealing with the groups that it seeks to get to?

TALK.START.PARA: —Its priorities.
—Its priorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are repeatedly faced with what I consider to be a slight distortion from Senator Vanstone. She puts the proposition that the woman to whom she refers is receiving the same or virtually the same amount as the pension. When one examines the tests that one must meet to receive a pension and associated benefits, the reality is that the odds are overwhelming that the great majority of people in desperate need will be receiving pensions and benefits rather than be in the work force. There is absolutely no doubt about that. I do not deny that there may be some people who will not immediately be covered by the provisions of this Bill and who will be in some difficulty. However, the reality is that the great majority of those in real need will be covered.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of the Bill is to cover some 55,000 to 60,000 parents in as short a time as possible. We will need to deal with the obvious complexities of negotiating with the six States and the Territories about access to their records and we will need to ensure that those records can be compiled properly. While we are dealing with those 55,000 to 60,000 cases, we will also have to carry out negotiations with the States. I am sure that it will be possible to monitor the progress of setting up the Register and getting the scheme under way. After the Government has watched the operation of the scheme for some short period, I am sure that it will be in a position to announce a timetable. However, as I said, it is a huge undertaking. I would have thought that we would be better off ensuring that we can go at it as hard as we can, monitoring it, and undertaking to provide a timetable as soon as we have determined how fast we can implement the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guarantee that, once the scheme is generating $192.8m by 1989-90, those women who are not able to give the Government back any money will be absolutely ignored by the Government. The Government's only interest is in those women who will be able to get off the Government payroll. The Government will wash its hands of the battler, of the woman who has had to work her heart out in the work force to support her family as a result of her ex-spouse refusing to pay maintenance. The Government is just not interested in supporting such people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Senator Walters grossly exaggerates the number of people in that position. Secondly, I have repeatedly said that the Government will move to make sure that they are covered. Thirdly, the Fogarty group is monitoring what we do. It is not as if we are not in a position of being watched over to make sure that our efforts are not only efficient but also are performed with some compassion and speed. When it comes to compassion and speed, anyone who has listened to this debate will have no doubt from which side of the chamber it comes-they will know that it comes from the Government.

—I was interested to hear the Minister's little speech: `We will not send anyone to gaol in this day and age for not paying maintenance. We are well beyond that. If a fellow does not pay his maintenance we will not send him to gaol, as the Opposition has suggested'. Senator Richardson put forward a distortion of Senator Durack's Bill. Can the Minister tell me what happens when the very large penalties of $1,000, under clause 23 (7), clause 34 (2) and all the way through the Bill, are not paid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot tell Senator Walters what the law is in each State. People who default in respect of fines under the Act will be dealt with in accordance with the laws of those States.
—I find that most interesting, because in Senator Richardson's State the penalty is gaol. We all remember Jamie Partlic, who failed to pay a parking fine and was thrown into goal and bashed up.
—That's the Unsworth Government, is it?

—That is the Unsworth Government's gaol. Jamie Partlic-just a boy-was thrown into gaol and bashed up for not paying a parking fine, and the Government accuses us of using gaol sentences under Senator Durack's Bill. That is a distortion of his Bill. There is no use the Minister wiping his brow so often. He has to face it. Under his Bill if people in New South Wales-the Minister's State, under the Unsworth Government-will not pay their penalty they are thrown into gaol. What on earth has the Minister been talking about?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In my State, as Senator Walters calls it, as she would be aware the Unsworth Government has done away with the system of gaoling fine defaulters like Jamie Partlic.
—Last week?

—No, not last week. Senator Panizza, from far away places, probably does not read the Sydney newspapers. It was some time ago. What we have to understand is that whatever the Commonwealth does and whatever Bill it might be the only form of reasonable deterrent in these situations is fines. That is why they are in this Bill and why they are in so many other Bills when we talk of breaches, whatever they may be. There is no alternative but to deal with the situation in the way I have just mentioned.

—In the recent exchanges what has emerged quite clearly is the importance to many women, in particular those women who are not on pensions or benefits, of the functioning of State agencies and of the relationship between the State agencies and the newly emerging Federal agency. Could the Minister provide the Senate with an up to date appraisal, from his point of view, of how the negotiations are proceeding in areas where he perceives there are, perhaps, significant problems so that we may know in which areas those women are likely to strike most difficulty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst it is true that the Commonwealth can proceed to negotiate with the States only after it has seen the Bill pass through the Parliament, informal negotiations are already taking place with the States. I would not have thought, though, that there was much point in giving Senator Powell a progress report of informal negotiations except to say that most States appear to be anxious to co-operate but, as usual, not all. I will let Senator Powell guess about which State might not be as willing to co-operate as some of the others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Walsh's second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government rejects the suggestion that automatic withholding be imposed only when default in payment occurs . . . Stigma attaches to automatic withholding if it is imposed upon default and this would detract from the success of the scheme.
If the Government believes that, why does it allow an opting out clause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is what people wish, the Government does not intend to stand in their road. Obviously they can opt back in if arrangements are upset at some later date.

—The Minister has misunderstood me. I am saying that if the Government believes that stigma is attached to automatic withholding if it is not automatic, as stated in Minister Walsh's second reading speech, why does the Government allow an opting out clause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just given the reason. I am not sure how many times I should repeat answers. I have done so a lot tonight.
—Try a better answer.

—As I said to Senator Vanstone earlier `Try better questions'. When it comes to the stigma question, one has to look at what happens with the employers, whose responsibility it is to deduct the payments. If one has a payment withheld only if one defaults the stigma is automatic. The employer knows straight away that any person from whom he has to deduct payments is in some way at fault. With the system the Government has announced there is no stigma whatsoever on anyone. All that is know by the employer is that there is a maintenance order. I would have thought that was a far better system for all concerned. I cannot understand what the argument is about.

—The Minister need not wipe his brow. Why would an employer not say to his employee, `Why don't you opt out?'. If he is not able to opt out, a stigma is attached, according to the Government's opting out clause. The Government allows an opting out clause. By allowing an opting out clause an employer could say to his employee, `Why don't you get your ex-spouse to allow you to opt out? Doesn't she trust you?'. There is confusion about this matter. The Government does not really believe the stigma bit or it would not allow an opting out clause. As soon as the Government allows opting out the employer is going to say, `Joe Blow, why don't you get yourself in order?. If you paid your maintenance regularly your little woman would allow you to opt out. You obviously do not pay it regularly and therefore she won't allow you to opt out'. The Minister is really confusing the whole issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Over an hour ago in my summing up to the second reading debate I thought I covered the point that Senator Walters had attempted to suggest that the non-custodial parent should have the right to opt out. The Government rejected that. We believe that if anyone is to opt out it ought to be the custodial parent-that is, the parent with the responsibility of bringing up the children and of putting the food in their mouths. We said that if the custodial parent chooses to opt out that parent can write to the Registrar and simply say, `I do not wish you to take any action to enforce collection'. If that is what is said in no way would we be seen to be hindering or hampering that operation. But we would not permit the non-custodial parent to have the right of opting out. In the end, we are about providing not just the money, the cash in the hand; the real provision is for security to try to take some of the worry away from custodial parents. That is what we are about and that is what this Bill achieves.

—I was grateful for the Minister's answer to what I said I thought would be my last question. It was about people who would be left out. He indicated in his answer that he thought it was now impossible to calculate the number of such people but that eventually it would be possible. I ask the Minister: Given that he has acknowledged there is this group of people who are left out-we might disagree as to why, but given he does know how many he can handle now-surely he can now produce some sort of schedule as to when he will be able to take on other liabilities? He must know how many now will be covered by this Bill. Is it not a simple process of extrapolation on an annual basis as to picking up those who are now left out? In any event, if the Minister says no to that, will he at least give an undertaking that within six months or 12 months, when he has had some experience of this Bill, he will produce such a schedule to give the people who are currently excluded from this Bill-or will be by his regulations-an opportunity of coming under it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I have to repeat myself about the complexity of the Bill. Earlier I did give a figure of, I think, 55,000 to 60,000 cases that we estimated would be picked up now. In terms of seeing how we can implement the scheme, we have to judge not only the number of cases. We not only have to go through negotiation with the States, we also have to find out how many parents will choose to use the Child Support Agency as a collection agency. At the moment that can only be speculation. The Government would like to be able to judge that as time goes by. We do not ask the honourable senator to wait on the never-never but if we are given a few months to see how it goes we will be able to announce some sort of program for incorporating the rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister envisage the situation in which a father regularly visits his children and takes a delight in making sure the children understand that his care and concern for them also entails his handing over money to their mother so that they can be looked after in the way in which he would like them to be? In that situation I believe there can be a very healthy relationship between the children and the father. Why should not that father in those circumstances, where he has been paying maintenance for a considerable time regularly on time without defaulting every time he visits his kids, be able to opt out?

SPEECH.PARA: Under this Bill the only way he can do so is to persuade his ex-wife, the custodial parent, herself to put in for an exemption. He may never have defaulted. The Government is taking away from him the opportunity of having a very healthy relationship with his children by taking from him the right of saying to them, `I hope everything is all right and I am able to support you'. I think it is terribly important for him to be able to show his children that he is indeed financially supporting them. Under the Bill it will be his word against his ex-wife's because he cannot prove to his children he is handing over money if his ex-spouse is saying to the children, `The Government has to take it out of his wages, otherwise he would not be paying it'. That is the situation the Government is setting up. As we are all well aware, divorces can involve so much bitterness. The Bill is enabling the mother to say to the children, `He won't pay. The Government is making him pay. It actually garnishees his wages. It takes the money out of his wages every week. The Government makes him pay through the Register and I do not get the money from him; I get it from the Registrar when it is taken from him'. Why is the Government creating that problem for the children after the divorce where otherwise the father could allow his children to see that his love and devotion for them includes his payment for their support?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to repeat some things I said earlier in the debate. I seem to say that each time I stand up. I would not have thought it normal in these situations for the children to be marched into the front room to witness the handing over of the money from dad to mum. I would have thought that would be a pretty rare old case. I doubt very much that that is the norm. Nonetheless, let us assume--
—They are not dumb.

—No, that is right; they are not nearly as dumb as Senator Walters is taking them for. I have to say again that it is the custodial parent who can opt not to use the Child Support Agency as a collection agency. If the maintenance is being paid over regularly in the form of cash, it is pretty easy to walk out of the room and spend it on necessities. In that circumstance I would think very few women would be anxious to do other than inform the Registrar that they did not wish the Registrar to collect the money. That immediately obviates any problem with dad convincing the children that he really cares. However, to take that a bit further, I would have thought that, even in a situation where bitterness persists and where the custodial parent insists on the collection being taken up, it will not be very difficult if, as the honourable senator says, `they are not that dumb' for the father to explain that the Government is taking the money not because he would not pay it but because the new system requires all fathers to do it in that way, except where the custodial parent opts out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to some remarks made earlier in the debate which were not debated quite properly. For the benefit of honourable senators who were here and perhaps for those who were not, the suggestion was made that I had made some remarks that might be considered unparliamentary. In fact, if what was put to me was what I had said, I would agree that it was unparliamentary and I would have been happy to withdraw it. I indicated to the Chairman at the time by several nods that I had not in my view said that. For the benefit of honourable senators present, I inform them that I have just received a copy of the `pink', and the sentence reads:

SPEECH.PARA: She is battling to look after her kids and she is married to some-
this is where the consternation comes in-
creep who ticks off.
For the benefit of honourable senators here, and anybody else who might want to read Hansard, I will not put before the chamber what it was suggested I did say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who suggested that, Senator?

—I understand someone on the other side of the chamber said that. Senator Colston raised the point. Nonetheless, I am very pleased to see that the Hansard record confirms my recollection of the events. I certainly did not recall the exact words I said, but I was quite clear in my mind that I had not said what it was put to me I had said.

—I accept the remarks that Senator Vanstone has made. I would hope that Senator Vanstone realises that I made the remarks in what I considered was a proper way. I certainly did not interrupt Senator Vanstone's speech. I deliberately waited until the end so that I could then make my remarks, but I did not get the call at that stage and had to wait until some time later. I made the remark only out of good faith for the sake of the Senate, not to take any objection to Senator Vanstone herself. I must have mis- heard. Senator Durack made a comment about who made the suggestion. I think I was not the only person in the chamber who misheard. Having said that, I hope that Senator Vanstone will realise that I did it out of the dignity of the Senate and not because of the remark itself. I do accept the remarks that Senator Vanstone has now made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard what Senator Vanstone just said, I was not aware of the controversy that had arisen, but I certainly accept that she said `creep who ticks off', which I do not find offensive. It is probably an accurate statement in the circumstances to which she was referring.

—I ask the Minister to say just how much consultation the Government had with employer groups before it introduced this system whereby the employer is used as a collection agency and, I might add, a free collection agency. As I mentioned in an earlier speech, there are various penalties on the employer under the Bill-$5,000 for this, $1,000 for that and $2,000 for something else. Even though the Minister said there would be no gaoling for this offence, if I understand him correctly, for the employer, I do not think there is much provision for the gaoling of the true dodgers of the system, the ones who do not pay their maintenance. I ask: How much consultation did the Government have with employer groups before it put in a scheme such as this? It is another load onto the employer. I do not know how much experience the Minister has had as an employer, but I have certainly had plenty.
—He has tried a few famous people.

—I am talking about direct experience. I have had experience, as an employer, of a policeman or bailiff presenting me with a garnishee order requiring money to be taken out of an employee's wages and the next day all the marital problems were given as reasons why that person should not pay, such as, `My wife often lives with someone else'. I have had to put up with this and the next week I have sometimes had to find a new operator because the law has caught up with that one. I ask the Minister to put himself in an employer's shoes and tell me how he relates to that and, more importantly, how much consultation the Government had with employers groups before it lumbered them with another hefty piece of legislation under which they have to do the collections or answer to the Government for their failure to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The consultation has been over a long period and it has been with every major employer group, not just nationally but also in the States. It has even extended to some of the major employers themselves, some of the big employers of labour. I am not sure what else both the Commissioner of Taxation and the Department of Social Security could have done because, as I understand it, both have had these consultations, not simply one of them. As I said in summing up the debate some time back, the provisions for employers were made as light as possible in light of those consultations.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the penalties are concerned, they are less than what employers can expect with other problems that they may have with tax collections-considerably less in fact. I would not have thought that the penalties were all that high. I certainly will not say that the employer groups have endorsed the Government's actions. Obviously any extra impost is something they would prefer not to have. I think generally speaking their view would be that the impost they are to have has been applied in as sensitive a manner as possible.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 February.
Clause 9.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee last dealt with the Bill, it was considering clause 9, as amended. The question is that clause 9, as amended, be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill was last being considered, Senator Durack asked me for a little more detail about the notion of Judicial Registrar. I point out that the Judicial Registrar is required to have the same qualifications as a judge. He or she will be delegated judicial powers in respect of contested matters and in respect of undefended divorce applications. A meeting was held with then Chief Judge Elizabeth Evatt, some other judges and officials in April last year. Apparently, it was indicated that the judges would be prepared to consider delegation in respect of unlimited property jurisdiction where the parties agree to a matter being dealt with by a judicial registrar; contested property jurisdiction to $100,000 without consent of the parties; approval of section 87 deeds; ex parte applications; interlocutory proceedings; and children's matters. Obviously no decision has been made in that regard, but that was the scope that was indicated. I hope that that information will assist Senator Durack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly give us a little more knowledge about the Bill than Senator Tate gave us the other night, but he really has not answered the point that I was pressing when consideration of the Bill was adjourned-that is, having decided to go down this track of having judicial registrars whose qualifications as he said, would be similar to those required for appointment as a judge, the Family Court judges would be prepared to delegate some contentious work of a perhaps less serious or important kind to those judicial registrars. I can understand that concept, but I do not understand why the Government, having decided to create the office of Judicial Registrar, has provided in clause 12 of the Bill for the fullest delegation to the ordinary registrars.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that I find so odd about this scheme is that the Government has totally extended the power of delegation to registrars, thus removing the one restriction that existed on the power of delegation to registrars. Therefore, why is it necessary to go through all this palaver and create an Office of Judicial Registrar? It almost seems that the Government is providing a way to create a higher salary for this office. I know that the Government will leave this point to the Remuneration Tribunal; of course we do not object to that. The salary of the Judicial Registrar will be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. But when the Remuneration Tribunal looks at what can be done by a judicial registrar as against what can be done by a registrar, how will it determine the difference in status?

In understand that the original proposals were that there ought to be created in the Family Court the office of Master of the Court which, of course, is a well-known concept in the court system. The position of master in the supreme courts of the States has been a major feature of the administration of justice for as long as we have had the British common law system of justice in Australia. The notion of a master is well known in law. It is a more intelligible notion, but the Government has not chosen to create an office of master. Perhaps the Minister for Justice can tell us why that is so. It proposes to create this Office of Judicial Registrar, and the judicial registrars seem to be virtually indistinguishable from the registrars, who have been a very important feature of the Family Court since it was created. They have carried out a lot of important work, particularly in the conference area. Their powers to deal with delegated judicial work have been greatly increased as a result of amendments in 1985. The one restriction imposed upon that power of delegation in the 1985 amendments to the Family Law Act is now removed by clause 12 of this Bill. That is the point about which I was seeking some explanation from the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —In trying to point out the status of those who will be appointed as judicial registrars-they will have to have the same qualifications as a judge-and having pointed out the sorts of delegated judicial powers that they might be able to exercise, I was trying to distinguish them from registrars who, as we know, exercise many ordinary administrative functions. It is true that they exercise certain powers that are delegated by judges. There is limited jurisdiction with respect to urgent maintenance, interim maintenance pending final resolution by a court, and so on. As we know, most registrars spend a lot of time administering the case management flow through the registry to ensure that orderly disposal of cases throughout the court. Indeed, whilst it is true that the proposed amendment to section 37a (2) permits judges to delegate powers to registrars in respect of undefended divorce applications, the judges have not indicated any disposition to undertake such a delegation. I think that that distinction between the actual effective practical work of registrars and judicial registrars will remain.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to Senator Durack's question about the concept of masters being a more understood concept, it is true that it is a well recognised office within our court systems. Indeed, the Judicial Registrar is really a master, or mistress, under another name. I say that because, to be quite frank, as I understand it, the term `judicial registrar' has been chosen rather than `master' simply to avoid some of the-as it is put-sexist overtones of the language characterising that office. Whilst the position of master has a strong and noble historical lineage, I think one can appreciate that when given this new opportunity, and given the possibility that women will hold that office of judicial registrars, as they hold the office of judges of the Family Court, it was thought an appropriate time to use the title `judicial registrar' rather than `master'. Senator Durack was quite right to point to the similarity of the sorts of functions that may be undertaken by judicial registrars to those which are associated with masters in, say, the supreme courts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an interesting revelation of the power of the sisterhood in the Caucus of the Australian Labor Party. I wonder whether women are likely to refuse being appointed as masters of supreme courts. No doubt, as time goes by, they will hold these positions in the State supreme court systems. It is a pathetic example of the level of thinking of this Government. If we are to think of judicial registrars as being similar to masters of supreme courts, that may help to clarify the position. It still does not explain to me why such very wide powers of delegation have been given to registrars. I might pursue that matter when we come to clause 12. In relation to the status of the new judicial registrars, the Minister has earlier given us some indication of the type of work they will do and its important character and has pointed out that, under proposed new section 26h, the person will have the same qualifications as required to be appointed a judge of the court.

SPEECH.PARA: Why has it been decided in two other subclauses that, first, the judicial registrar may be appointed on a full time or part time basis, which is hardly consistent with judicial office-the concept of part time judges is not known to me-and that, secondly, and even more importantly, a judicial registrar is to be appointed for a term not exceeding seven years? That is certainly inconsistent with the notion of judicial office. Can the Minister explain why these limitations are imposed on a person who is supposed to be, we now learn, a mini-judge, if not a Master?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the short answer is that he is not a mini-judge; he is a master exercising certain delegated powers. That explains why the seven-year term is thought to be appropriate. As far as the question of full time or part time is concerned, I am advised that the part time position will allow for those no doubt uncommon instances where a retired judge may wish to make himself available for this type of work, does not want to commit himself or herself to a full time role, but has the skills, experience and ability to well fulfil the requirements of the office of judicial registrar. It may be that in such a situation one could take advantage of that willingness to be committed on a part time basis.

—I can understand the Minister's answer in relation to why part time work is available, even though it may seem inconsistent with the higher status that is sought to be accorded to these people. But the term of seven years can hardly be brushed off by the Minister's saying that it is quite appropriate for a person who is not a judge but is only equivalent to a master of a Supreme Court. I would have thought that the general concept nowadays for all judges, whether they be of Supreme Court, district courts or magistrate courts, is that they be given security of tenure, do not have appointment for a term of years and, subject to behaviour and capacity, have a permanency.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not thought that the office is so akin to the full status of a judge as to require that absolute security of tenure until the attaining of a certain age-65, as it probably would be in this jurisdiction, 70 or 75, whatever it might be.
—The age of 65 is all right because judges retire at 65.

—That is right, they do now. All I can say is that the Government has made a decision that the term should not exceed seven years. If one were appointing a judge, one would not have such a limitation. In so far as the registrar is not absolutely holding that office, it is thought that this limitation is acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —With all respect, all the Minister has done is state the obvious, namely, that the Government has decided that appointment should be only for a term of not more than seven years. That is not consistent with the explanation the Minister is giving generally of this new office of high quasi-judicial status. I presume that the Minister regards this position as being senior to a magistrate's position. Perhaps the Government does not. It is certainly not the way in which I understood this proposal had been set up. I understood that it was a proposal to create, in the Family Court system, positions that were analogous to masters of Supreme Courts. The Government has now decided that it cannot call them that because of pressure from its feminists on the back bench. It is understandable, I suppose, that the Government gives in to such pressures.

SPEECH.PARA: Why should this office not be accorded the type of tenure which would normally be sought to get people to take on this job? Maybe that will not be a problem with retired judges, but I would be surprised to learn that the Government is seeking only retired judges or retired lawyers. Is it suggested that this is going to be an easy job for a few years for a lawyer who is retiring from active practice at the age of 60? Is that really the Government's notion? I find the answers quite unsatisfactory and quite inadequate on just what is the Government's thinking on this new office which the Government, and certainly the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in his second reading speech, have indicated is very important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in proposed new subsection 26i (1) (b), subparagraphs (i) and (ii) are disjunctive. In other words, a judicial registrar can be appointed:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . for such term (not exceeding 7 years) as is specified in the instrument of appointment, but is eligible for re-appointment; or
(ii) if the instrument of appointment so provides, until attaining 65 years of age, but is eligible for re-appointment on a part time basis.

I am advised that the two possibilities are there, the second being the one that would normally be made available for a full time appointment of a judicial registrar and the first one being the arrangement that might be made in relation to a part time registrar.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation does not say that. Am I to take it that that is Government policy? It is not translated in the legislation, but I take it that the policy is that hale and hearty people in the prime of life who are going to be appointed as judicial registrars will be appointed until they are the age of 65? A semi-retired lawyer or judge will be appointed only for the term. Is that what the Minister is saying?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that I can make such an absolute distinction between the two grades. Perhaps we should also read proposed new subsection 26i (2):

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General shall not appoint a person as a Judicial Registrar on a full time basis for a term that extends beyond the day on which the person will attain 65 years of age.
Perhaps Senator Durack's teasing out of this section has enabled me to get a better understanding of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not enable me to get one.

—But we are getting there. It could be important, when Senator Durack retires, whether he is appointed under new sub- section 26i (1) (b) (i) or (ii). Subsection 26i (2) makes it clear that a judicial registrar on a full time basis cannot be appointed beyond a time at which he attains 65 years of age. He would then be able to go back, though, to clause 26i (1) (b) (i) and appoint such a person for a term perhaps until he is age 70. That is the way those proposed sections would be utilised.

—The result of that is that the constitutional requirement that judges of the Family Court have to retire at 65 years of age will not be observed in relation to the minor office of judicial registrar. Presumably we can have judicial registrars appointed at 80 years of age even for a term of up to seven years. Is that the case? It seems to be an extraordinary conflict between not only the statutory policy in relation to the age at which judges retire, but also the constitutional requirement that Family Court judges have to retire at 65 years of age. Having retired at 65 years of age they, or some other retired judge, can be appointed as a judicial registrar for a period of years. Is that the position?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, as I understand it, such a person could be appointed on a part time basis though he is over 65 years of age.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 10 to 14-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 12 which deals with the power of delegation to registrars. I refer to what I have already said about this question of registrars. I ask the Minister to explain to the Committee why we now have the situation where ordinary registrars can have delegated to them all the powers that can be delegated to judicial registrars even though the judicial registrar is supposed to have a higher status. After what we have just been told about judicial registrars I do not know how the Government thinks that they can be seen to have a higher status. Let us assume that the Government achieves the unlikely, if not the impossible, status it wants to establish for judicial registrars. Nevertheless, in the same Bill the Government is removing any limits that exist now on the powers of delegation to registrars. I would like the Minister to explain what his thinking is in relation to that. I can understand his taking away the limits on the delegation to registrars if he was not creating the office of judicial registrar, but having gone to all this trouble-and we have been over that enough-he now removes all the limits. And it is not just in regard to undefended divorces. As I see it, the power limits delegation to a registrar to make a decree of dissolution of marriage, annulment, et cetera. Clause 12 simply removes that subsection with that limitation. It seems that the power of delegation to registrars is complete if the judges wish to so exercise it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is correct. If the Act is amended by omitting the present provision that would be the effect but, as I understand it, the judges have indicated that if this important power were to be delegated to registrars it would be in respect of undefended dissolution applications. I agree that that would be their decision, narrowing it down. But there has certainly been no clear indication from the judges as yet as to which of the functions they will delegate, or in what terms, following the omission of this particular subsection.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that it is not expected that this will be a commonly delegated or, if delegated, used power, but it may be useful in some situations where a registrar is on circuit on a more regular basis and therefore more available to deal with the matter than judges who are less frequently on a circuit in a particular geographical area. It may be useful on some occasions to delegate the power to the registrar in those limited situations, but this is a matter for the judges.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens if the parties don't want it delegated? Are you saying that the judge makes the decision?
—The judges will make rules of court which will clarify and make clear the extent to which, the conditions under which, and those circumstances in which the delegated power should be exercised.
—What if the people concerned actually want a judge to hear it in a contested action? Is there any provision for them to say, `I don't want it to go to the registrar'?

—No, I do not think there is. If the rules of court provide that the judges may make a delegation of this power to the registrar, then that is judged by them to be a proper and sufficient repository of that power and they would have confidence that the matter would be dealt with in a proper way. But I am saying that what indications there are at present are that the judges would certainly not be prepared to delegate any power outside the area of undefended dissolution applications. But in the absence of the rules of court that they might wish to make, I am not in a position to give an absolute guarantee on that.

—I am sorry to have to return to the status of judicial registrar. I thought I understood the Minister to say, when he answered earlier, that judicial registrars would have delegated to them power to grant undefended divorces. Did the Minister say that?
—Yes.
—But not defended divorces? Is that the position?
—That is right.
—That is judicial registrars?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is right. Naturally we would expect the same with registrars but all I am saying is that these are the discussions that have been held so far with the judges of the Family Court and officers, but it would be quite wrong for me to stand here and substitute myself for the judges making those rules of court. I am indicating that it is intended, in so far as one can fathom it from the judges, that they will be prepared to give this delegated power to judicial registrars in respect of undefended divorce applications. If they were minded at all to give any power to registrars in that field it obviously would not be in any greater field than they are prepared to give to judicial registrars.

—Is it the Government's policy though in providing for these powers of delegation that not only will a judicial registrar be able to grant an undefended divorce but that registrars will be able to grant an undefended divorce? We come back to this total confusion again between the office of judicial registrar and ordinary registrar. The Minister should have left the legislation as it is with the limit in the 1985 Act of allowing delegation to registrars in pretty well every power of the court except to grant a dissolution. The legislation does not say whether it is defended or undefended; registrars cannot grant a dissolution. Now the Minister is taking that away and suggesting that there may be a delegation to registrars to grant divorces. Is it the Government's policy that it is all right to allow delegation to a registrar to grant an undefended divorce?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. The Government's policy reflected in the Bill is to enable the judges, if they so decide, to permit to a registrar that particular power to grant an undefended divorce application.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate to now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 October last year I raised in the adjournment debate the problems being faced by Mr Robert Wenham, an Australian citizen who had been detained in Saudi Arabia for seven years by a Saudi Arabian prince, Ahmed Al Sudairi, after a failed business deal in which they were both involved. It is a pleasure to be able to report to the Senate that Mr Wenham was finally allowed to leave Saudi Arabia at the end of last year and returned home to Australia to a joyous and relieved Christmas reception from his family.

SPEECH.PARA: His release was in large measure due to the relentless pursuit by so many members of his family of every avenue available to them to secure his release. I am sure we would all wish to have such dedicated and loving support in similar circumstances. The Australian media is also to be praised, for by giving publicity to Mr Wenham's plight and the family's fight to have him released they, too, played an important part in helping him to leave Saudi Arabia.

I hope I may also have played a part by raising the matter in the Senate. If the reaction of the Saudi Government to my raising it here is anything to go by, it must have added to the pressure on that Government to find an amicable solution to the impasse between Mr Wenham and his Saudi captors. In addition praise must go to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for the role it played in trying to find a resolution to the impasse. The role played by that Department is the main reason I have risen to comment further on the matter tonight.

In speaking to the matter on 7 October I made it clear that the material I put then before the Senate was provided to me by the Wenham family and represented their side of what was then a very worrying story. Since that time a member of my staff has been allowed to examine departmental files in response to a freedom of information request. After examining these files he has formed the view which I expressed a moment ago, that is, that the Department had been assiduous in assisting Mr Wenham in his attempts to leave Saudi Arabia. My officer found that departmental officers had spent a considerable amount of time trying to clarify the issues in dispute between Mr Wenham and his captor. Further my officer felt that the Department had done its best to advise Mr Wenham on how to proceed in order to enable him to leave Saudi Arabia-of course, an outcome which we finally did achieve.

Therefore, to the extent that my comments, as reported on page 841 of the Hansard of 7 October 1987, might have seemed critical of the efforts of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade I would now wish to revise them and replace them with the foregoing comment I have just put before the Senate. I should also add that it was a particularly difficult situation, and I can understand fully why the Wenham family felt that the Department was not doing enough. All they wanted was their father and family member home. However, it is important that we all understand that by undertaking a private business venture in a foreign country an Australian citizen impliedly consents to be bound by the law and custom of that country. When a citizen voluntarily places himself or herself in this situation he or she cannot expect the same protection that he or she would have had in Australia. The Government must recognise the local private dispute settling procedures. So the Australian Government's role tends to be advisory, and while it can make approaches to the other Government, as was done in this case, it is not in a position to make demands of that Government. My staff member considers that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade adequately undertook this role.
I have written to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade setting out my views on this matter, and I seek to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
THE SENATE
6 January, 1988
Dear Mr Cotsell
I refer to your letter of 24 November, 1987 and the review of your files on Mr Wenham's detention in Saudi Arabia by a member of my staff, Mr Crawford, on 15 December, 1987.

Mr Crawford has reported to me that his review of your files demonstrated to his satisfaction that your Department had been assiduous in assisting Mr Wenham in his attempts to leave Saudi Arabia. He considers that your Department has used all reasonable means available to it in its efforts to resolve this difficult situation.

When the Senate resumes sitting in February, I intend to draw this matter to its attention, so as to correct some of the information I provided to the Senate on behalf of the Wenham family on 7 October, 1987. I will also draw Mr Crawford's findings to the attention of the Wenham family.

The only concern Mr Crawford raised with me was that the arbitration procedure may be biased against Mr Wenham in a way that it would not be if Australian law applied to it. He has told me that cables from the Embassy to the Department indicate both that an arbitration decision would be difficult to enforce against royal interests and that the plaintiff's lawyer appeared to have too cosy a relationship with Saudi Departmental officials.

These factors make it easy to understand Mr Wenham's reluctance to enter into arbitration. However, I realise that these are Mr Wenham's problems, as he impliedly consented to be bound by Saudi law and custom when he undertook a business venture in Saudi Arabia as a private citizen.

As Mr Wenham has now returned to Australia after having been allowed to leave Saudi Arabia, I do not wish to take my Freedom of Information request any further. Therefore, I withdraw my request as of this date and I do not require you to provide me with any documents. Would you let me know if there are any outstanding fees in respect of this matter.
Yours sincerely
