TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the Senate on the subject of civil disobedience seeing that I have been twice arrested. I want to explain my rationale for deciding on such a course of action. I begin by quoting from the Gospel of St John, chapter 8, verse 32:

SPEECH.PARA: You will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.

It is the never ending and often frustrating search for truth which is a constant motivation in my work for peace. An informed public in a democracy will generally make sensible decisions for the general well-being. Unfortunately, it is in the interest of the few to control the masses by keeping them uninformed and therefore unable to contribute as intelligently as they would like to the decision making processes. It is the age old mushroom treatment-keep them in the dark. Unfortunately, truth is constantly sacrificed on the low altars of politics, power and profit.

It seems to be considered dangerous in Australia to allow the public free access to information. The increasing monopolisation of the media in this country is a very real threat to alternative viewpoints getting an airing. Look at the media giants headed by business people with vested interests to protect, who wield power in the less-and-less investigative journalistic circles. It is a case of `No questions, please. Don't rock the boat. Tread carefully, journos, or you're out of a job'.

It is not that this lack of information or misinformation is new on the Australian political scene but media monopolisation highlights it to a painful degree-painful that is to people who like to know what is going on, to people who-perish the thought-cherish the notion that ordinary people have a right to information which affects their lives and their children's collective future. The mushroom treatment has been the norm ever since convict days when decisions were made by so-called superior beings about not only the majority of white settlers in chains, but also about the original inhabitants of this land. There was no pretence at consultation then.

Successive governments have kept generations of Australians in the dark on a whole range of topics. Of special concern to me are the areas of foreign affairs and defence. Secrecy, paranoia and fawning colonialism in these crucial areas of decision-making have affected the way we perceive ourselves, how we relate to other nations, how we have been prepared to die in other nations' wars and to assist other nations in their quest for power and nuclear supremacy. Consider the secret decision Menzies made to `lend Australia to the British Government' for its nuclear weapons testing program.

Consider, too, the establishment of American base after base to suit the United States Government's needs for listening posts and communication facilities in this region of the world-all arrangements secret, of course. It turns out that a worried Menzies Government invited the United States to put facilities here to shore up its anxieties at the loose wording of the 1951 ANZUS Treaty. The bases were meant to act as insurance that the United States would intervene to protect its own interests because there was no guarantee in the ANZUS Treaty that the parties would do more than consult. As Des Ball points out:

American installations in Australia have been the subjects, both of continued lack of candour on the part of the United States and of extraordinary secrecy, evasion and deception on the part of the Australian Government.

As a peace activist and senator I have become acutely aware of this secrecy, evasion and deception on the part of our Government doing another government's bidding in contravention of international law. Having exhausted, but not abandoned, the usual methods of information extraction and lobbying, I found myself increasingly led to civil disobedience as a vehicle for exposing the truth. Of course the letters, questions, delegations and huge public demonstrations of Australians challenging our foreign affairs and defence policies must continue. But on their own, they have been singularly unsuccessful in either exposing the whole truth or in changing government policy. Of course a thorough expose of the role of the United States bases in Australia would very likely lead to public demands for their closure. And a significant number of Australians are already demanding that-but not the 70 per cent, give or take a few, which the Government could hardly ignore.

The question is: How can more people become informed to the point of outrage-outrage at successive Australian governments' secrecy and their co-operation with foreign governments in direct contravention of Australian interest; outraged enough to demand public inquiries into outside interference in Australia's domestic affairs; outraged enough to act in defiance of a government committing Australia to action which a majority of its citizens consider illegal or immoral, or both?

For me, the issue is not only a public one because I am an elected representative of the people of Western Australia, but it is also a very personal one because, as a Quaker, truth is of fundamental importance. Quakers are encouraged to `let their lives speak'-in other words, to act as believed, to ensure a correspondence between our outward, visible lives giving expression to our inward, spiritual lives.

This notion of integrity calls for faithfulness to conscience illuminated by the light within. It is not grounded in dogma, creeds, abstract philosophical ideas on theological affirmations. It is not to be found in religious textbooks. It is grounded in the living faith and experience of the present moment. It is the basis for Quaker testimonies-living witnesses to the inward leading of the spirit in our lives. Once it lays hold of us, truth will not let us go until we have acted upon it. It is like that for me. Acting upon the truth, or that part of it which I know, and the tantalising part of it which I seek, compels me to act in every possible non-violent way to expose more of the truth, for the sake of humanity. If that means putting myself at risk by committing civil disobedience, so be it. I cannot be content only to speak, write and lobby in the search for peace; I must act with my whole being, with every fibre of my body. As Martin Luther observed at his trial after he had hammered his 95 theses to the door in Wittenberg over 400 years ago:
Here stand I, I can do no other.

The call to civil disobedience as a tool towards the uncovering of truth is not merely intuitive; it is certainly spiritual in nature. The example of others has been a strong influencing factor, backed up by enlightenment from traditional and radical religious sources. These happen to be mostly Christian in origin, because that is my background, but I am sure the inspiration could have come from other religious faiths. The Quaker Peace Testimony, first declared in 1660 after the restoration of the monarchy in England, is a useful starting point. The refusal to take up arms for any purpose whatsoever has landed Quakers in jail ever since. Their witness for non-violence has been active rather than passive, and very expensive at times in terms of personal costs. For 300 years Quakers have been absolutely convinced of the immorality of engaging in killing and conversely by the power of non-violence.
The potentialities of non-violence are inexhaustible. The world's people are slowly realising that we must move in that direction. As Martin Luther King said:
We have a choice and the choice is clear. It is no longer between violence and non-violence, but between non-violence and non-existence.

Of course this challenges us as individuals, groups and nations. At every level of society we need to look to solving our problems non-violently. The violence we confront in our lives may be physical, verbal or structural and we must learn ways of overcoming it. The most powerful force for good in the world is the transforming power of love. Without it, without the spirit of reconciliation, without looking for the good in every person, we shall neither find, nor deserve, peace. Violence must be faced as a crucial issue and firmly renounced.

The immediate impact of commitment to non-violence is to liberate individuals to act morally and responsibly on the daily problems of the world community. This means much more than an individual adding to the useful witness of a permanent minority. Rather, it is the essential moral and political act of our time, the initial impetus for the pioneering effort that humanity must make to escape disaster. There have been many shining examples of this witness beginning in small ways but eventually having enormous impact, the most recent outstanding ones being Gandhi's campaign for independence in India and Martin Luther King's civil rights campaign in the United States of America. The political effectiveness of these successful, although long, difficult, and sometimes bloody campaigns was always underscored by goodwill; that is, goodwill on behalf of the social change agents, but not always of their opponents, who tried very hard to resist such changes. Goodwill and love are the spiritual tools of non-violence, just as civil disobedience is its physical tool.

No government can maintain power without the approval and co-operation of the majority of the population, even where a regime is prepared to use brutal force. If the majority of the people withdraw their co-operation in the daily running of a country's affairs, systems will grind to a halt. Change must occur. Thus Archbishop Hunthausen of Seattle argues:

As a general rule the laws of the State must be obeyed. However, we may peacefully disobey certain laws under serious conditions . . . In certain cases, where issues of great moral import are at stake, disobedience to a law in a peaceful manner and accompanied by certain safeguards that help preserve respect of the institution of the law is not only allowed but may be an obligation of conscience . . . I believe that the present issue is as serious as any that the world has faced. The very existence of humanity is at stake.

Of course Archbishop Hunthausen was referring there to the insanity of the build-up of nuclear weapons. What we are faced with today is a world armed to the teeth with weapons of mass destruction-nuclear, chemical and biological. There can be no moral justification whatsoever for their use, or even their possession. Weapons of mass destruction are evil, and the threat to use them is evil.

Why are the world's people allowing themselves to be pawns in the so-called superpowers supremacy battle? The nuclear superpowers are the ultimate terrorists, holding the world's people to ransom. Is it because we have lost faith in the sanctity of human life, in the power of good to overcome evil, in the interconnections which exist between all people as spiritual creatures? I suspect that we have replaced faith in those positive forces with dependency on weapons. We would indeed inhabit a spiritual desert if we allowed weapons instead of faith, or violence instead of non-violence, to provide our security. There can be no security in the immorality in the arms race. It is suicidal. At the same time that the world is committing billions of dollars a day to the weapons industry, millions of people are undernourished, millions do not have fresh water or adequate housing, millions have no access to medicine or education and 40,000 children die each day. As former President Eisenhower of the United States said:
Every weapon that is tested, every missile that is deployed is a theft from the poor and hungry of this world.

The links between disarmament and development are indisputable. To continue funding weapons systems is morally indefensible. The biblical injunction to love one's neighbour has become the global imperative.

Those who profess to be followers of any of the world's great religious teachers ought to ask whether their gurus would be involved in our present struggles. When I try to place Jesus Christ in the mid-1980s, I feel sure that he would be working with the poor and oppressed peoples of the world, working to rid the so-called superpowers of the fear which feeds the arms race instead of feeding people. It is my belief that Jesus Christ was strung up on the cross because he was a stirrer. That is referred to in Luke, chapter 23, verse 5. His questions were making the authorities uncomfortable. He was challenging the status quo, and doing so non-violently. It is my guess that that would still be his position today. Radical Christians around the world agree with that. So we have at least half a dozen Catholic bishops in the United States prepared to commit civil disobedience to highlight the immorality of their own country's nuclear weapons testing program. They do this as witnesses to the gospel, to the teachings of Jesus Christ.

Another point I want to clarify is the reference used by many Christians to criticise those of us who break the law in an act of civil disobedience. I refer to Paul's injunctions in Romans, chapter 13, to be subject to the government authorities. This injunction applied to authorities which in turn were subject to a higher authority. If they should turn away from God then the Christian has to choose between obeying God or obeying Caesar. This was the dilemma of Franz Jaggerstatter in Austria when the Bishop of Linz cited the scriptures to argue that all good citizens should serve in the armies of the Third Reich, the duly constituted authority. It is a dilemma for Christians in South Africa today where the Christian National apartheid government cites scripture to demand loyalty which includes military service in the defence of that regime. It has been a dilemma for pacifists since the early church abandoned pacifism for the Just War and every war since then has been a Just War blessed by the Church. We must remind ourselves of this ancient truth:

That love endures and overcomes; that hatred destroys; that what is obtained by love is retained, but what is obtained by hatred proves a burden. This truth, fundamental to the position which reflects reliance on the method of war, is ultimately a religious perception, a belief that stands outside of history.

I now wish to address the question of the illegality of weapons of mass destruction. It is evident that weapons of mass destruction have properties which are illegal according to international law. Briefly, their effects include the indiscriminate dispersal of toxic and carcinogenic chemicals; the exposure of combatants and civilians alike to irreversible biological and genetic damage; and the creation of unpredictable, uncontrollable and unprecedented environmental destruction of such temporal longevity as to threaten the biological identity of the human race and even the physical integrity of the planet.

Several international treaties outlaw weapons which have such effects. I shall just list the names of those treaties, although I have the details of them if honourable senators require further information: the Hague conventions of 1899 and 1907, the 1925 Geneva Gas Protocol, the Nuremberg Charter, Article 2.4 of the United Nations Charter, the four 1949 Geneva Conventions on the Humanitarian Conduct of War, the Geneva Protocol of 1977 and the United Nations General Assembly Protocol 1653 (IV), which declares the use of nuclear weapons to be, inter alia, contrary to the rules of international law and the laws of humanity.

An international lawyers conference met in 1987 in New York to discuss nuclear weapons and international law. It was sponsored by the Lawyers Committee on Nuclear Policy in the United States and the Association of Soviet Lawyers. It laid the foundation for a global association--

Standing Order 406 says that no senator shall read his speech. I suggest that on this occasion the Chair would not only be entitled to enforce that standing order but, given Romans, chapter 13, Senator Vallentine would gladly abide by your ruling.
—Senator Vallentine, please take note that you are not supposed to read your speech.

—Certainly. This international body of lawyers has met and decided to form an international association, with the probable result that countries will be taken to the International Court of Justice and will be held responsible by their own countries' citizens for violating such international law. Both the United States and the Soviet Union have, on previous experience, shown that they do not take very much notice of such international conventions and law. However, like the Medical Association for the Prevention of War, the international organisation which is having quite a significant effect on policy-making decisions around the world, this international lawyers association will probably have a similar effect. It is very important that lawyers around the world work together, both in the East and the West, to challenge their countries on this point of international law being denied by the presence of and threat to use weapons of mass destruction.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to talk about civil disobedience as a tool for social change. It is true that there have been criticisms about my commitment to civil disobedience, but much of it indicates a lack of understanding of the concept of civil disobedience and its history. We need to remember how earlier civil disobedience campaigns led to the establishment of a number of basic freedoms we now enjoy. Civil disobedience is essentially a withdrawal of obedience, a refusal by individuals to give support to a wrong action or law. It involves the breaking of existing laws in the hope that the laws will be changed, an action based on conscience or obedience to a higher law. Those who break the law have to accept the consequences of their actions, which in Western society usually means fines or imprisonment.

Civil disobedience can be associated with individual actions or mass actions. In this century civil disobedience is best known in association with the mass actions I have already referred to, inspired by the work of people like Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King. There are also many instances of individuals committing very effective civil disobedience. The best known record of civil disobedience can be found in Gene Sharp's book The Politics of Nonviolent Action. He gives many examples from all around the world of both mass actions and individual actions, dating right back to ancient Rome when the plebians struck against the authorities in 494 BC and withdrew to the Sacred Mount until an agreement was reached on improvements in their life and status. So civil disobedience has a very long history.

Probably the best known dissertation on civil disobedience was written by the American Henry David Thoreau in about 1849. He was imprisoned for refusing to pay taxes to finance the Mexican war, of which he disapproved. The story is told of his friend Ralph Waldo Emerson visiting him in gaol and asking, `Henry, why are you here?' to which Thoreau replied, `Why are you not here?'. Thoreau's appeal is basically for individual action to wash one's hands clean of the evil and refuse to give it practical support. Before conservatives jump up and down in criticism of Thoreau's essay, I should remind them that his essay begins with the words, `I heartily accept the motto that government is best which governs least'. So he was not exactly a radical in every way.

Mahatma Gandhi read a copy of Thoreau's essay when he was in gaol in South Africa and recognised its significance. He borrowed the title to explain this movement to Europeans. With Gandhi, civil disobedience was widely developed, along with other forms of non-violent action, as a substitute for violent rebellion. Gandhi's legacy has been of utmost importance. Gene Sharp writes:

It was Gandhi who made the most significant personal contribution in the history of the nonviolent technique, with his personal experiments in the use of noncooperation, disobedience and defiance to control rulers, to alter government policies and to undermine political systems.

What Gandhi was demonstrating was the doctrine of soul force. Just as there are physical forces which move bodies, so there is, claimed Gandhi, a soul force capable of moving souls. The object of `satyagraha' was `not to achieve physical domination, but to initiate those psychological processes which could make it possible for minds and hearts to meet'. Soul force is aimed not at the head but at the heart, the source of our values. Soul force enables us to resist oppressors, while at the same time to love them. The one who is using soul force in its various non-violent forms has embarked on an adventure of love. Adventure implies risk and hence the possibility of sacrifice. For a cause like the abolition of war, at least one thing is certain. The cause will not be won by argument alone. That may win some ground, but it will not take the citadel. Only love in action can do that.

In the West, Gandhi's ideas were taken up by the civil rights movement in the United States under the leadership of Martin Luther King. His classic work on civil disobedience, Letter from Birmingham Jail, was written in 1963 on scraps of newspaper and pieces of writing paper supplied by another prisoner in response to a statement by eight fellow clergymen from Alabama who had described his activities as `unwise and untimely'. The civil rights movement grew out of the Montgomery bus boycott in 1955 and led to sit-ins and many other tactics of non-co-operation.

This civil rights movement had an impact in Australia when Aboriginal people organised freedom rides in New South Wales and set up their tent embassy in Canberra in 1972 until the authorities removed it. Other Australian examples of non-violent resistance have been in New South Wales where the green bans raised the wrath of the developers. The Franklin blockade saved the last free-flowing wild river in Tasmania. Civil disobedience is the last resort in this respect and is not something to be taken on lightly.

It is often said that civil disobedience can be practised only in a relatively humane society, but there are many examples of where it has been effective against brutal tyranny. Examples would include the Danish resistance to the nazis when the penalty for hiding Jews was death or the resistance of the Norwegian teachers to the nazi-quisling regime when many died in Arctic concentration camps during their eight-month struggle against the Government. There was the non-violent overthrow of military dictatorships in Guatemala and El Salvador in 1944. Civil disobedience is not a guarantee of success, but neither is the resort to armed force. It has been the main tool leading to the end of colonialism this century and many a Prime Minister has emerged from gaol to lead his country. Even today we see non-violent tactics being used in Kanaky, or New Caledonia, despite French attempts to provoke the Kanak people with a massive presence of armed police and soldiers.

One characteristic of civil disobedience is that those who adopt it either as a principle or as a tactic must expect to be rubbished for it, as I am being rubbished here tonight, or face gaol or a fine. It is only in the last 30 years that civil disobedience has become a tactic of those of us who choose to resist the nuclear arms race. In the early 1950s a few Quakers and their friends in the Direct Action Committee entered United States military bases in the east of England-the forerunners of the campaign for nuclear disarmament. In 1958 the first Americans tried to sail into the United States nuclear testing area in the Marshall Islands and were promptly arrested. In the early 1970s a number of Australians were on small boats that sailed into the French nuclear testing area around Mururoa and several of them were beaten or arrested.

Advocates of civil disobedience draw their defence from the Nuremberg principles-simply that people break a national law in allegiance to a higher law. The strength of civil disobedience involves an appeal to a higher moral authority than that of any individual nation serving its own interests. It was exactly this higher law that American woman Katya Komisaruka was guided by when, in June 1987, she quietly entered an American base at Vandenburg and disabled the Navstar missile guidance system which is part of the Government's nuclear first strike strategy. This brave woman's act of civil disobedience is costing her several years in prison. Her defence was based on Nuremberg principles.

As long as people have any choice in the matter they cannot abdicate personal responsibility in committing immoral actions by claiming that they were merely following orders. It is interesting that in the coming months we will be discussing under the War Crimes Amendment Bill exactly this situation in relation to events that happened in Europe 40 years ago. I think it is important that we update our commitment to the Nuremberg principles and understand that crimes against humanity, punishable under international law, include planning for, preparation for, initiation of, or the waging of, war. So clearly, testing of weapons of mass destruction is in violation of the Nuremberg principles. As citizens of the world first, people belonging to any nation involved in preparation of acts of genocide should endeavour to stop their government. I believe that is an obligation under the Nuremberg principles.

This is a lesson also clearly demonstrated by the long-standing witness against cruise missiles made by the brave women of Greenham Common and at numerous other sites in Western Europe. We are fed the line that nuclear weapons are a deterrent but they are there to be used in the event of a conflict between East and West. The military are planning to use them in such an eventuality and our leaders are prepared to give the orders to launch those missiles. United States bases in Australia are a vital part of such a scenario. In a war situation the United States is not going to ask our permission, just as it did not during the Yom Kippur war in the Middle East in 1973. On that occasion the bases were put on red alert. Australia has the ability to terminate agreements on the bases but if there is a war that escalates to a nuclear confrontation this Government will not have the time to give the United States 12 months or 180 days notice to quit.

In Australia we are using civil disobedience as a last resort. We have tried for many years to explain to the people of this country what the US bases are really about but we have been met with a blanket of silence or, at best, sheer misinformation. `Truth is the first casualty of war' goes the old dictum but the same can be said of the nuclear state. To break the secrecy some of us have chosen to draw attention to Australia's role in preparations for nuclear war by breaking the law. We walked on to our own land, the land of Aboriginal people who were never consulted when that secret agreement about Pine Gap was signed in 1966, and we were arrested for it. Ironically, it was also on native people's land where I was arrested last year at the United States nuclear test site in Nevada, just as it was Aboriginal land in Australia which the British Government was given for its nuclear weapons testing program in the 1950s.

Pine Gap is a crucial part of the Unites States military machine. Our Government admits to only one of the three roles of Pine Gap; that is, its benign monitoring and verification role which was merely an afterthought to justify its existence. The arms control agreements it is meant to monitor did not even exist in 1966. Pine Gap is first and foremost a ground control station for US signals intelligence satellites and was in fact established for this purpose. Its two main roles are to receive and transmit information from satellites as well as technological and human operatives-in other words, spies-and, most significantly, it controls the Rhyolite satellites stationed in pairs over the Horn of Africa and over Borneo. These satellites intercept electronic signals, including national and international telephone and radio communications. They suck up like a vacuum cleaner a wide range of communications from throughout the world and beam them back to Pine Gap for transmission to the United States. They also gather information on potential target sites in the Soviet Union and wherever else the Unites States sees fit. By intercepting radar signals, the US is able to map the location of targets such as Soviet early warning, air defence, anti-ballistic missile systems, air bases, satellite tracking--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to descend to a more mundane level. I wish to speak about a report or a purported report which has been handed down by the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council entitled Privatisation-The Consumer Perspective. This document claims to be an attempt to examine objectively the issues involved in privatisation and to identify key questions which the Government, the community at large and the business world need to address. One might have thought that that was a laudable objective and what would then follow would be an impartial assessment of the issue, which the report acknowledges is quite controversial. Instead, what we get is a tirade of abuse and a litany of anti-privatisation crusaders ranging from such notables as Professor Wheelwright through to Hugh Stretton, Frank Walker, the New South Wales Minister for Housing, Bill Pollock, the former managing director of Telecom Australia and, finally, one John Langmore.
—It is predictable, isn't it?

—It is an utterly tendentious document because with that sort of cast one could expect only one outcome and, indeed, that is the outcome that is generated. I find the document particularly disappointing because it purports to be an intellectual assessment of an important subject, yet it descends to being a very poorly argued case against an important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I give one example of the way in which it verges on intellectual dishonesty. The report says:
Studies in the US and the UK have shown that there is nothing intrinsically superior about performance under private ownership.

The sole authority cited for that proposition is John Langmore. He wrote that in an article in a book which was published recently. That is the level of shoddy academic workmanship that is contained in this document. It proceeds to quote people such as Frank Walker as though they are experts on the subject. He says:

Many essential public services are unprofitable and all the privatisation in the world won't alter that. Most public enterprises have valid social and political goals beyond private sector perspectives and the only way they could be successfully privatised would be by massive government subsidies.

That is the sort of level of debate contained in this document. The term `massive privatisation' recurs throughout the document. Obviously it is a loaded term designed to suggest that somehow privatisation can be done only in massive doses. Walker's comment does not go anywhere near the logical extension of the argument because there is nothing intrinsically wrong with government subsidies. They need to be justified, targeted and socially desirable but they should not be ruled out per se. Yet Walker's conclusion seems to be that, horror of horrors, privatisation would have to be accompanied by some forms of subsidy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is Walker?

—Frank Walker; he is a mate of yours. He is Minister for Housing in New South Wales. I acknowledge that he is a non-entity. He is a Labor Minister of some years standing but is quoted as an expert on this subject. That is a ludicrous proposition, but it is the sort of intellectual integrity that is contained in this document. That is utterly regrettable and disgraceful because this report has been paid for entirely by the taxpayers. It is published by the Australian Government Publishing Service and purports to be an objective assessment of an important issue. I think that is a disgraceful state of affairs. It is an intellectually dishonest document which does nothing to advance the cause of rational debate about competition and efficiency in the public sector. It provides virtually no advice on matters of national consumer interest and, indeed, one would be justified in asking what possible relevance there is for an outfit such as this to buy into the matter of privatisation. There is a very slender justification.
—Are they all members of the Centre Left?

—I was about to say that I found it most disturbing that the composition of the Council should be basically a collection of non-entities but that the Chairman should be one Justice Paul Stein who, I am told, is a judge of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court. In view of the fact that he has lent his name to this document, which is little more than a political pamphlet, and which is clearly a one-sided pseudoanalysis of an important issue, I consider that he should resign his position as Chairman of the Land and Environment Court because he has hopelessly compromised the standards of integrity and impartiality that should attach to judicial office. If he is in any way qualified to pronounce on issues of efficiency and competition, he has lamentably failed to discharge that obligation. The document is riddled with self-serving statements. Its ultimate conclusion, however, is that partial privatisation is all right. It cites the example of the New Zealand Government, which has recently issued shares in the Bank of New Zealand. It quotes from other sources to support that proposition. One would have thought that was a pretty feeble outcome from such trenchant criticism of the very notion of privatisation. For instance, the document quotes the Assistant Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Bill Mansfield. It is not stated where he came from, but we know that he came from the Telecommunications Employees Association. It says that Mr Mansfield claims that:

SPEECH.PARA: far from being inherently inefficient, public enterprises are required to be efficient--
So I suppose it follows that they are. It quotes Mr Mansfield as giving the figures in support of his argument. Then he trots out the bottom line, so-called:
Telecom is self-financing and returns . . . a . . . profit . . . of $385m.

What does that prove? All it proves is that its prices are fixed in such a way that it is able to generate a particular amount of money. It could be compelled to return a profit of twice that amount because it is a monopoly. It is able to earn, so-called, whatever it chooses to earn subject to the Government deciding that it wants more of the take, if Senator Walsh is getting short of a quid, and asking it to pay $600m in interest because there is a desperate need to finance the deficit.

Australia Post is given great marks for achieving an operating surplus of $23m in 1984-85. Why the report did not quote figures for 1985-86, let alone for 1986-87, I do not know, because this document came out only a couple of days ago. One would have thought that that figure is not terribly impressive. It also states that the Commonwealth Bank had an after tax profit of $23.6m in 1983-84. That is even more ancient history. It is ludicrous to suggest that because a very significant public sector enterprise is able to generate a very meagre profit, somehow that demonstrates efficiency. The whole notion of privatisation should be concerned with competition, with efficiency and with delivering a service at the lowest possible price, and it should concentrate on the gains that derive from those situations, from taking a monopoly out of a protected, cosseted and sheltered environment and putting it into an area where it has to face up to real life competition. The end result of that sort of exercise, such as the deregulation of the airlines in the United States of America or the deregulation and opening up to competition of three of the world's five largest telecommunications industries-the monopolies-has been that prices generally have fallen quite substantially. That is the sort of bottom line test that should be applied to privatisation concepts. It might not be the be-all and end-all, but it has a lot more going for it than simply maintaining public sector monopolies with no competition and no practical pressure for incentives to make it become more efficient. I regard this document as disgraceful. It is designed simply to advance a cause that is intellectually dishonest and which is riddled with left wing quotations but which does nothing to acknowledge the growing body of literature on the subject.

I mention in passing that Professor John Kay recently published a book on deregulation and privatisation, that Cento Veljanovski has published a book called Selling off the State and that Oliver Letwin has published a book called Privatising the World. There is a plethora of material on privatisation. It might be of varying quality, but the fact is that it is there and it is able to be drawn upon. An abundance of documents have come out from the United Kingdom Treasury because the concept has been so successful that Britain is besieged with inquiries about how to emulate its performance. France and the Federal Republic of Germany are only two of the most recent European countries to embark on virtually wholesale privatisation exercises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the document quote any of Senator Gareth Evans's arguments in favour of privatisation?

—No, the only one that gets a guernsey in that regard is Mr Dawkins. He is quoted as saying that we already have a very highly privatised economy and that there is no need to interfere with the public sector. I am sure that Mr Dawkins has recanted or that that was simply an outburst of lunacy that does not typify his current position. He was quoted as saying, `Australia has a small public sector and it is already highly privatised by international standards'. But, no, the honourable Gareth certainly does not get a run, and no doubt a lot of what Senator Walsh has had to say--
—Perhaps no-one takes him seriously.

—Yes, and perhaps that is the case with Senator Walsh too. But there is no shortage of material around that demonstrates his enthusiasm for various forms of privatisation and real competition. That is why I conclude by saying that I regard the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council as having done a gross disservice to the debate in this country. It is a body which is obviously out of its depth and has been chaired by a person who is not fit to occupy that office and who should retreat to the judiciary and proceed to deal with matters of the land and the environment because he simply is not competent to cope with consumer affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Vallentine, I wish to say this: Most of the people in this Government were being vilified in the 1960s and 1970s for opposing the then coalition Government which was conscripting and dispatching Australian youth to the Vietnam war. We deeply resent being subjected to sanctimonious sermons about peace and truth from people like Senator Vallentine, who joined the Country Party at the time when the Country Party was a partner in that coalition government sending those conscripts to the Vietnam war. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 14 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the exercise of so-called `privatisation' begin in the United States commercial airline industry.
(2) To what stage has that `privatisation' reached, and which airlines previously owned by the United States Government or its instrumentalities have been turned over to private enterprise.
(3) What has been the cost benefit to the United States taxpayer of this exercise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The commercial airline industry in the United States, from the time it began early this century, has been characterised by private ownership of the commercial passenger airlines.
(2) I know of no commercial airline which has been owned by the United States Government and subsequently privatised.
(3) It is therefore not possible to comment on the benefits or otherwise to the United States taxpayer of privatisation in that country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 26 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to the Queensland Government's `Open Skies' policy adopted on 11 May 1987 has the Minister seen the State guidelines provided to companies operating, or applying to operate, intra-state air routes in Queensland.
(2) Is it correct that these guidelines require that operators meet specific requirements on ``safety and reliability'' and that applicants establish that they are of ``good repute and character''.
(3) Has the Federal Government been informed by the Queensland Government that Talair has met these specific requirements.
(4) Can the Minister advise if the applicant must also demonstrate that it conforms to the guidelines by obtaining a Commonwealth supplementary airline licence.
(5) Can the Minister advise if Talair's Queensland operator Flightwest holds such a licence.

(6) If Flightwest is not now in receipt of such a licence, does this constitute a breach of the guidelines; if a company is in breach of the guidelines what penalties can be imposed by the State Government.

(7) Has the Minister seen the reported comments of the Queensland Minister for Transport in the Townsville Bulletin of 31 June 1987; if so, is he aware that the Queensland Minister stated that his Department was in receipt of a letter from the Commonwealth Department of Aviation assuring the Queensland Minister for Transport and the Department that Talair had a satisfactory safety record.
(8) Can the Minister confirm that the Commonwealth Department of Aviation has provided such assurances and if so were these assurances given in the case of Talair or Flightwest or both.
(9) Has the Minister seen the Queensland Minister's comments on the Commonwealth Bureau of Air Safety and if so has this body conducted any investigation into Talair or Flightwest.

(10) Can the Minister provide any information on the comparable safety records of other airline companies operating in Papua New Guinea, or other similar regions such as Indonesia or remote areas in the U.S.A. and Canada, during the same period of time in which Talair was operating in Papua New Guinea; and is it true that these companies were not involved in a similar number of fatal accidents as Talair.

(11) Can the Minister provide any information on the circumstances surrounding Solair and the recent intervention of the Solomon Islands Government into the affairs of this airline then under the control of Talair, and did the intervention relate to the non-payment of taxes and charges by Solair to the Solomon Islands Government.
(12) Was Talair's Australian operation, based in Cairns, charged and convicted last year with breaches of Australian aviation regulations.

(13) Does the Minister believe that the check, training and management policies of Talair, if applied to Flightwest, its Australian operator, give concern that Flightwest may be an undesirable operator in this country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. However I have received a briefing which covered the principles outlined in the policy.
(2) The Queensland Government's ``Open Skies'' policy requires that operators meet certain qualitative criteria. However I am not aware of the details of the criteria.
(3) No formal advice has been received on whether Talair or its subsidiaries have met the Queensland Government's criteria.
(4) Federal and State requirements are separate issues. An operator must comply with Federal requirements before a supplementary airline licence can be issued.

(5) Following compliance with all Federal operational requirements for issue of the respective licences, a charter licence was issued to the company on 1 June 1987 and a supplementary airline licence was issued on 16 July 1987.
(6) I refer the Honourable Senator to my answer to question 5.

(7) I have not seen the Queensland Minister for Transport's comments reported in the Townsville Bulletin but I am aware that the Department of Aviation had advised the Queensland Government that Talair had a satisfactory safety record based on examination of records of Australian Air Safety occurrences.
(8) The letter from the Department of Aviation commented on the Australian safety record of Talair.
(9) I have not seen the Queensland Minister's comments on the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. The Bureau has not conducted any investigation into Talair or Flightwest.

(10) The PNG environment is much more demanding and hazardous than most others in the world. The only valid comparison possible in this case is an operators record to the overall record in the country of operation.

Information received from the PNG Civil Aviation Authorities has indicated that although Talair has been involved in about one third of all accidents in PNG the company has flown more than half the total hours flown by all operators in that country. Talair's record is, therefore better than the PNG average.
(11) The information requested by the Honourable Senator in this question is not available from within my Portfolio.

(13) Flightwest as the holder of Australian air service licences, is required to satisfy Australian operational standards. The company is subject to the same surveillance as any other operator in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 19 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Now that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has decided that the Department of Transport and Communications must allow a colour-blind pilot, Arthur Pape, to fly at night, will the Department now amend procedures to remove restrictions for all colour blind pilots; if not, why not.
(2) Why did the Department make the totally unrealistic demand that Arthur Pape have a fully T.S.O.'D. second V.H.F. radio on an independent electrical bus.
(3) Will the Department take steps to change obstruction lights from flashing red to flashing white to remove any possible difficulties encountered by colour blind pilots; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal's decision in regard to Dr Pape acknowledged that he did not meet the required medical standard, in that he has defective colour vision, and therefore could not be granted unconditional licences. The Tribunal's decision affirmed the Department's decision that Dr Pape could not fly at night at all on his Commercial Licence. It permits him to fly at night on his Private Licence, but only subject to a number of restrictions which the Tribunal considered appropriate to his particular level of skill and experience, and the nature of his colour vision defect.

With regard to other colour defective pilots, the Tribunal said ``the fact that a decision has been made in respect of one person with a particular medical condition cannot be taken to require necessarily that a similar decision be made in respect of another person with the same medical condition''. Any applications to fly at night by these pilots would be considered on their merits, taking into account the Tribunal's decision in the Pape case. There is no basis in the Tribunal's decision for a blanket removal of restrictions on colour defective pilots.
(2) The Department did not make such a demand.

(3) No. The proposed system would be contrary to international practice. The suggested change may be of some advantage to some but not all colour defective pilots, but this gain would be more than offset by the significant expenditure involved and disruption caused to those pilots with normal colour vision who greatly outnumber the colour defectives.

(d) The total number of manhours lost as a result of these disputes is not recorded by the Department except in the case of disputes involving stevedoring unions. The disputes relating to second tier claims in the stevedoring industry by the Australian Stevedoring Supervisors' Association during October resulted in the loss of 10,279 manhours. The figures for November are not yet available.

(e) Details of the effect on exports as a result of any of these disputes in terms of the amount, nature, destination and value of cargo held up are not available. The statistics generally do not distinguish between various types of ship or cargo delayed or otherwise affected by such disputes.

However, in the case of the first two disputes listed in the above table, the class of vessel can be distinguished because the bans specifically affected container vessels. Container vessels trading to Australia during 1986-87 on average carried 6700 tonnes of exports. During 1986/87 the average value per tonne of container cargo exports was around $2,000 per tonne. Consequently, the estimated value of export cargo on container ships was about $13.4 million per vessel. There were 36 ships affected by the first two industrial disputes listed so that the estimated value of export cargo delayed in these disputes would be around $480 million.

(f) The total estimated direct and indirect costs of such disputes to various parties which may be affected cannot be reliably estimated because of the large number of variable factors involved. Although the costs to shipowners of delays are reasonably attributable, even these vary with differences in the nature of the ship, the number of crew, rates of pay and charges applied by port authorities. A reasonable broad estimate on the cost of a day's delay to a vessel is $25,000. On this basis, the cost to shipowners of industrial disputes recorded in relation to the second tier pay rise would be around $9.7 million from March 1987 until 31 December 1987. It cannot be assumed, however, that all of the additional costs accruing to shipowners will necessarily be passed on to Australian shippers or importers by way of increased freight rates or vessel charter costs because of the highly competitive nature of the shipping industry.

The costs of disputes to shippers are more difficult to ascertain, however a possibly indicative estimate in the case of the first two disputes given in the table might be derived. If these disputes resulted in customers' payments being delayed by a period equal to the length of the dispute, additional costs (by way of finance costs on cargo) of around $380,000 would have been incurred by the shippers whose cargo was affected.
